englishGloss: to sail or row a yak skin boat.

examples.english: That river is deep. We'd better row a yak skin boat (across it). (i.e., the river is deep so unless we row a boat we won't get across.)

What expertise those fishermen have at sailing (their) coracles! I don't know how to manoeuvre a yak skin boat at all. (Note that the speaker pronounces {gtong stangs} as {btang stangs}, reflecting the standard practice in Lhasa dialect. Tibetans from Tsang typically say {gtong stangs}.)

commentsEnglish: {ko ba gtong} refers only to rowing a yak skin boat. {ko ba} means 'leather' or 'hide'. The generic expression for 'to row a boat' is {gru gtong} or the more formal {skya ba rgyag}. {skya ba} are 'oars' or 'paddles.'

examples.english: He's always poking fun at me. I was only joking with you. In fact, I don't know about that situation.
Because he made fun of the leader, (he) suffered a loss. (i.e., he got into some sort of trouble.) Don't mess around. Come quickly.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Today, at the Jokhang, the Gang Gyur scriptures are being read aloud. He reads the scriptures well.
He knows how to read and write English. I read a poetry book last night. (Note that in Lhasa dialect the present tense {klog} is used for the past tense.)
It's important to not only read scriptures but also to be able to comprehend the meaning.

commentsEnglish: All tenses for this verb are pronounced {klog}, with the imperative being pronounced the way it is written. This verb usually refers to reading aloud. The {bka' 'gyur}, mentioned in the first sentence in example one, refers to the translated words of the Buddha.

examples.english: I got really tired over this exam I just took. A. Did you get tired? B. I didn't get very tired.
Since you came a long way today, you are probably tired.

commentsEnglish: The meaning of the first sentence in example one also covers the study preparation time as well as the time spent doing the exam.

examples.english: My house isn't that great, but I built it through my own hard work.
You've laboured really hard on this work.
Isn't it pointless if you work hard, but get no fruit from your labours? ({stong pa} means 'empty.')
That child is talking indiscriminately and causing hardship for his parents. I really do not want to cause you difficulties.
I bothered you today. Let me apologise.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to make a cermonial white line.

examples.english: There must be a celebration inside that courtyard as ceremonial white lines have been drawn by the gate.
It seems that a deceased person was taken away this morning as ceremonial white lines have been marked on the road.

englishGloss: to disturb, agitate, stir up or cause havoc.

examples.english: If you shake the apricot tree, you will get apricots to eat. You're asking for a lawsuit if you interfere with a marriage!
That girl has messed with my heart. (lit. 'disturbed me greatly.') Did you mix up the mahjong that I set out again?
A. Have I agitated you? B. Not at all.
This stimulating work is challenging.
The road was extremely bad so the car shook (us) around a lot.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to create disunity by spreading rumours.

examples.english: You'd better not stir up trouble or you could end up in court. She spread divisive gossip which caused that marriage to break up.
He's definitely after something if you observe the way he is stirring up animosity between people. (lit. 'he has a particular goal'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to cause trouble by inciting or spreading rumours.

examples.english: He spread many rumours about me. ({'ga' rab} is pronounced {'ga' ro} and means 'quite a lot'.) If you cause trouble by spreading rumours in public, you must bear the responsibility yourself. (i.e., dont spread rumours.)
It was probably only rumour that a leader had been assassinated.

commentsEnglish: Note that {'gan 'khri}, in the second sentence of example one, is also spelled {'gan dkri}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I know how to play a musical instrument. When monks have a religious ceremony, nice music is played. ({rol mo} is also translated 'cymbals'.)

commentsTibetan: རོལ་མོ་དཀྲོལ། དྲི་བུ་དཀྲོལ། སྒྲ་སྙན་གཏོང་། སྒྲ་སྙན་དཀྲོལ། ང་སྒྲ་སྙན་དཀྲོལ་གཏོང་བྱེད་ཀྱི་ཡོད། ང་སྒྲ་སྙན་དཀྲོལ་གཏོང་བྱེད་ཀྱི་ཡིན། ང་སྒྲ་སྙན་དཀྲོལ་གཏོང་བྱེད་པ་ཡིན། ཁོང་གིས་གླིང་བུ་སྙན་པོ་གཅིག་བཏང་སོང་།
commentsEnglish: For expressions related to playing musical instruments, the verbaliser {btang} is most commonly used. For example, {sgra snyan gtong} - 'to play the Tibetan guitar'.

examples.english: The region will be made filthy if unseemly behaviours are not prohibited. (i.e., urinating in public places etc.)
He really obstructed my work.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to keep in custody, to detain.

examples.english: Credible evidence is required if someone is to be kept in custody.
They are keeping that suspicious person in custody and interrogating him.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to organise, to plan, to arrange.
to deploy, to dispatch, to adjust.

examples.english: My father is coming to Tibet next week, so please arrange a bedroom for him for the tenth of this month.
Please arrange for a car. I still have to do the homework that the teacher set.
The teacher gave the students instructions. I listen to the commands of the leader.
He is talented at ordering others around, but he is not so good at doing his own work.
That thief was shackled with leg irons, yet (he) still escaped!
He must be the main criminal as both his legs and hands are shackled.

englishGloss: to stamp one's feet and clap one's hands in anger.

examples.english: He got angry and told (someone) off by stamping his feet and clapping his hands. She's angry and is stamping her feet and clapping her hands.
It's rude to stamp your feet and clap your hands in anger in front of guests.
If you do bad deeds, it will be a dishonour to (your) parents and relatives.
When playing soccer, even if one person doesn't play well it will disgrace the team.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to go bankrupt, to go under.

examples.english: Who would want to have their business go bankrupt like that?
This year's merchandise caused many businessmen to go broke. Last year, I took on construction work and went completely under. ({lza nyin} is often pronounced {na ning}.)

commentsEnglish: This entry literally means 'to have one's bottom cave in'.

englishGloss: to be very frightened or scared.

examples.english: Because a gun was shot in front (of him), he got very frightened. I was very startled today because I nearly collided with a car.
A. This field is full of weeds and needs to be weeded. B. The field has just been irrigated so it can't be weeded now.

englishGloss: to stretch out one's arms or legs.

examples.english: According to what Tibetans say, if you stretch out right after eating, in your next life you will take on the body of a wolf. (Note that stretching out is considered a bad habit because wolves and dogs stretch out after they have eaten.)
(People) who stretch out after eating are considered (by others) as undignified.

englishGloss: to communicate without using the voice.

examples.english: Honestly, there is a lot of expertise involved with using sign language. I know how to use sign language well.
Because I don't know Chinese, I'm forced to use gestures. (i.e., in order to communicate.)
It's as if she's gesturing to me not to come.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The enemy listened to us in secret and found out our situation. To listen in secret to someone else's phone calls is breaking the law.

commentsEnglish: This is seldom used in the spoken language.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: That culprit hid a great deal of public money and goods. It appears that recently the secret police discovered that a few businessmen had stashed away some drugs.

commentsEnglish: This is rarely said in Lhasa dialect.

examples.english: The thief stakes out a place during the day, with the intention of stealing at night.
That guy is probably out of his mind. He does nothing but peep in on the place where women wash themselves.

commentsEnglish: {lkog lta byed} is more of a literary expression. In everyday speech, {mi kha kha la ltas} is more common.

examples.english: A. Below our window are two people talking in secret. B. Oh, maybe they're burglars.

(You'd) better not talk that much in secret, my ears are thin! (This sentence means that the speaker has sensitive ears and will be able to hear what others are talking about. {srab se} is pronounced {krab se}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to shout, to yell, to scream.

examples.english: This car is really old. Noise is coming from everywhere. If you don't call out a little loudly, no one will hear.

Don't complain so much! People won't give you (what you want.) Today, a crow is really crowing. Perhaps this will be a lucky omen for me. (Note that a crow's caw is considered an auspicious omen by some Tibetans.)

commentsEnglish: The expression {ster gyi ni ma red} in example two is very common in Lhasa dialect.

englishGloss: to make a lot of noise.
to make a racket, uproar or hullabuloo.

examples.english: The teacher is probably not there. The students in the class are making a lot of noise.
What is the benefit of making a racket? He must have got totally scared. He really made a racket.
A. Has it been settled when you are leaving tomorrow morning? B. We're still to discuss that.
Unless this is discussed thoroughly now, problems will arise later on.
Presently, both parents are discussing that situation.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. I will call out to you early tomorrow. B. Then, please call out. I will wait for you. (i.e., to call me).
He invited me, but I wasn't able to go. I neglected to ask him to my wedding. (i.e., I accidentally left out asking him to my wedding. Note that {lus} is pronounced {las}.)

commentsEnglish: In Shigatse dialect, {bos} is more commonly used than {skad gtong}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: They sent me a parcel. Did you receive the parcel I sent?
I sent a message to her. Did she say anything? (i.e., that she received it or not?)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The tenth Panchen Lama was born in an area of Amdo. Buddha Shaykamuni's birth was the third of his twelve great deeds.

commentsEnglish: This compound is used only for lamas or very esteemed people.

englishGloss: to draw back, to pull in.

examples.english: That person has his arms pulled in. Unless I shorten (my) work time by one month, I won't be able to go to a foreign country.
Originally, our courtyard was a lot bigger than it is now. After a public road was built, it had to be shortened a lot.
In Tibetan, there are many ways to write words in a shortened form.
How could someone dare denigrate a sacred, holy lama? ({phod} is the literary form of {nus}.)
Those people are being very irreverant towards the system of Karma.
He's good at persuading others to do work. I wasn't able to succesfully complete the homework set by the teacher.
It is easy to persuade young people to do things (for you), just as it is to ride a small horse. (This proverb is said when an older person repeatedly makes a younger person do the work.)

commentsEnglish: This verb is similar to {byed ru bcug} - forcing or compelling someone to do something.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: After watching that movie, my heart was really moved to help other people.
After hearing about that situation, we were all greatly inspired. (lit. 'oneself and others'.)

englishGloss: to motivate, to stimulate, to inspire.

examples.english: Good parents always encourage their children over and over. I advised you many times, but you didn't listen well.
I am reminding you again of the matter that I had requested the other day.
You greatly encourage me. (Note that {gtong} is the verbaliser and not {byed}.) He inspires everyone.

commentsEnglish: This entry is used in the same way as {skul ma gtong} and {skul ma byed}, but {skul lcags gtong} seems most common in Lhasa dialect.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Our local government roused the people and a new damn was built. (The word {shang} is a Chinese loan word and means township or county level government.)
It is the responsibility of a teacher to motivate students well.

commentsEnglish: {skul slong byed} is often translated as 'to mobilise', but the more common usage seems to be 'to motivate'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: That wicked man strangled his wife and killed her. How could suffering not result from strangling yaks and sheep to death?

commentsEnglish: This entry is not prevalent in Lhasa dialect, rather {og brtsir gtong} seems to be more common.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I am going to call my children. Soon a large meeting will be convened in Lhasa.
That person was summoned by our work unit.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to hang up, to hook on.

examples.english: I hung my bag on the side of the wall. Please hang the rope on top of the beam.
Hook the mooring rope on the peg. (Note that 'peg' is the mooring area of a boat.)

commentsEnglish: The second meaning, 'to put on', refers to dressing someone else. This sense is not commonly used in Lhasa dialect. {g.yogs} is commonly used for 'to clothe/dress' or 'to put something on someone', whereas {gyon} is used for dressing oneself.

englishGloss: to turn around, to rotate, to spin something around
to make a circuit, to make rounds.

examples.english: Everyone spins that big prayer wheel. (You) could circumnavigate the oceans if (you) take a ship like this.
We can't cross this water. If we go around from the bridge, it will be quicker.
If this grain is exchanged for money, (one) could get around 200 yuan.

englishGloss: to talk in a roundabout way.

examples.english: He only speaks in a roundabout way without being direct.
She likes to speak in a roundabout way.
He spoke to them in a roundabout way and left them not knowing what to say.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to make a lap, to orbit, to revolve.

examples.english: Everyday, elderly women circumambulate the inner circle of the Barkhor.
Today must be an auspicious day as many people are circumambulating the Barkhor.
I went around all the markets in Lhasa, but I didn't find any shoes that suited me.
Because she spoke solely in a round about way, I was utterly confused.
Everyday, after getting up, the first thing I do is boil water. This tea is delicious. (lit.'you have boiled some delicious tea'.)
A. Who made such delicious tea? (lit. 'who boiled such delicious tea?') B. The monk made it.
I am boiling water. It is better to boil milk and then drink it.
I have never told a lie. If you tell many lies, who will believe you?
Please don't lie. You have promised to give the jewellery to (your) daughter.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He has completely spoiled his own child. From now on, young children are not to be spoiled!
The mother is near the point of over-indulging (her) children.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Since the parents did not routinely discipline their children well, they have ended up spoiled. ({ba red} is pronounced {pa red}. See Pronunciation Changes.)
If the children are not given good advice from now on, they will turn out spoiled. I've been addicted to smoking from a young age.
That dog is completely spoiled. It doesn't eat anything else but meat.
He's fallen into the bad habit of just aimlessly wandering about.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He left his homeland and sought refuge in another place. I am seeking refuge in you. (In this context the speaker is talking to a highly respected lama.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is not a commonly used verbalised compound.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I am taking refuge in the Three Jewels. If you take refuge in Buddha, you should not prostrate before earthly dieties.

englishGloss: to have or go on a picnic.

examples.english: In summer, all Lhasa people go on picnics. Today, the Norbulingkha is full of picnickers.
A. Shall we go on a picnic together? B. I don't have time.
Since she has not been able to repay the money I loaned her, she has not been coming to our house lately.
Is there a need to replace this small thing which has been broken? (It is implied here that there is no need to since it is only a small thing.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: (He) got drunk and vomited everywhere. I went bankrupt and had to pay back a lot of money.
Because the thief was interrogated peacefully yet forcefully, it seems that he couldn't help but tell everything. (lit. 'vomited up everything' or more naturally 'he spilled the beans.')

commentsEnglish: The volitional sense, 'to pay or give back', is transitive and the verbal argument is direct ergative.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: She vomited in front of the doctor. I vomit when I drink too much chang.
A. Why did you throw up? B. Perhaps I've got morning sickness.
I wonder what this dog ate. It is vomiting. He is vomiting.
When he has some chang, he makes a total nuisance of himself. I don't want to say annoying things.

commentsEnglish: {skyur 'gong shod} usually refers to someone who is saying annoying things when he/she is drunk.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be born, to give birth, to have a baby.

examples.english: That girl gave birth to a child at a young age. A beautiful plant has grown. (Note that {me tok} also refers to flowers.)
If twins are born, this will be troublesome for the parents for a period of time.
After hearing that person speak, (I) was really amazed. Spring has likely arrived as many shoots have sprouted.

commentsEnglish: {skye} is a common verbaliser and is listed with many other verbalised compounds. It can also be used in a volitional, transitive way such as {nga phru gu skyes ba yin}, 'I gave birth to a child' or {nga phru gu skye gi min}, 'I'm not going to have any children'.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to enhance, increase, develop or expand.

examples.english: It is written (here) that this medicine is good for increasing body strength. We should develop greater hearts for helping others. (This statement is a motivational directive.)

englishGloss: to deliver, to carry or bring, to move.
to see off, to put in to.
to pass time, to live one's life.
to send letters, to lose something.

examples.english: I always take (my) son to school. ({slob grwa} is often pronounced {slab grwa}.) I spent three years in Beijing as a student. (i.e., I spent three years in Beijing living the life of a student.)
Some people lead lives of poverty in the city. Today, I lost all my money on (the game of) mahjong. (This sense is non-volitional.)
Helping in times both good and bad is the basis of the life I will share together with her.
Don't worry, I will ease your sadness. (lit. I will console you.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to criticise in a positive way.

examples.english: The teacher gave me some constructive criticism. If I make a mistake, please correct me straight away.
Every year, we hold a meeting to discuss each other's short comings. A real friend is one who points out your faults. (i.e., criticises in a positive way.)

commentsEnglish: {skyon 'dzug byed} means to criticise in a negative way.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to accuse, to blame, to criticise.

examples.english: I was accused by our leader, but I didn't do that despicable work!
If the decision comes from the top (down), then people could really criticise it.
The public had a lot of criticism for the leader's behaviour.

commentsEnglish: {skyon 'dzugs byed} literally means 'to point out faults', whereas {skyon brjod byed} means to offer constructive criticism.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: At the time of the fire, the fire fighters fought untiringly and saved many people and livestock from danger.
The doctor saved the lives of many destitute patients. ({sman pa} is a more literary term for doctor. Lhasa dialect speakers usually say {am chi}, which is also written {em chi} and {em rje}.)
The child sank into the water and someone saved him. It is our responsibilty to protect wildlife.

englishGloss: to expel, to drive out, to kick out.

examples.english: The government completely expelled the criminals from this place. At the time of King Lang Tar (Ma), there was an edict expelling Buddhist practitioners to remote areas.
It seems that the lama exorcised demons from this place many times. Demons are driven away from places of natural disasters.

commentsEnglish: This entry is found in the literary register and is rarely used in Lhasa dialect. The colloquial equivalent is {'phud} which is pronounced {pid}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Because we are about to have an exam, we are reviewing all the work.
The teacher gave us a review questions.
Whatever (you) want to say, it's better to say it clearly. I am not speaking to him.

A. Are you speaking to her? (i.e., Are you on speaking terms with her?) B. I am not. If you hadn't spoken to me, I wouldn't know who you are. (Note that the speaker here has not seen her friend for along time.)

commentsEnglish: This compound is usually used in a negative sense. For example, when two people are not on speaking terms with each other {kha krag} is used - as in {nga khong la kha krag gi med} - 'I'm not speaking to him'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Yesterday, I lost my friend at the market and we all spread out to look for him.
We spread out (from each other) yesterday. Hadnt we better spread out and look for Tashi?
The enemy has dispersed (their) soldiers on the mountains.
A. Are you thirsty? B. I'm not thirsty.
That rabbit must be thirsty. It's licking the ice. ({lce ldag} is pronounced {lce lag}.)
If (you) drink boiled cold water when (you) are thirsty, it will be of benefit to (your) body.

englishGloss: to be embarrassed, to be ashamed.

examples.english: Yesterday when riding my bike, I fell in the middle of a crowd of people and was very embarrassed.
If you speak carelessly, she will be embarrassed. What is there to be embarrassed about? There is nothing embarrassing.

commentsEnglish: The compound {ngo tsha} is more prevalent than {kha skyengs}.

englishGloss: to put a lid on, to cover over.

examples.english: Please put the lid on the thermos. The tea will get cold. Please put the lid on father's bowl.
It's not at all easy to put the lid on that pressure cooker. ({ka'o ya ko'o} is a Chinese loan word meaning 'pressure cooker'.)

commentsEnglish: {kha gcod} is also spelled {khebs gcod}.

englishGloss: to make a promise, oral agreement or contract.

examples.english: The two of us agreed to go to the market tomorrow. They definitely reached an agreement and fled.
We often meet in the teahouse, even though we don't agree to it (before hand).
They agreed to meet tomorrow.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to leave or make a will or last testament.

examples.english: Since he did not leave a will before he died, (we) don't know who to give those things to.
He died without having the time to leave his children a will.

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense is {'jog}, but this is rarely said.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to sue, to file a lawsuit.

examples.english: I had no choice but to get into a dispute over her because she was so beautiful. If counterfeit things are sold, then of course there will be disputes about this.
He took the matter of (his) business to court and is presently undertaking a lawsuit.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The uncle and aunt of Milarepa conspired together and inflicted incredible suffering upon those three; his mother, his sister and Milarepa himself. ({A ku} and {A ni} refer to one's paternal uncle and {zhang zhang} and {sun mo} refer to one's maternal uncle and aunt.)

Perhaps the three of them agreed to go and just hang out. (The word {'khyams} has a wide range of meaning. Some of them are: 'to wander around', 'to hit the town', 'to go bar-hopping', 'to go window shopping'. In literary Tibetan, {'khyams} also has the sense of wandering aimlessly.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He is hooked on foreign food. (i.e.,'foreign' as in western style.) He got away with steaing once, so he's now hooked on it.

englishGloss: to recite or chant out loud.

examples.english: Every morning, my mother recites prayers. The monks have most likely finished reciting liturgies.
I pray out loud every morning.
They are chatting idly and not doing any work at all. If you sit there (just) chatting, the leader will see you.

commentsEnglish: This entry literally means 'to grind the mouth.' This is equivalent to the American expression - 'to chew the fat'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. What have you put in your box? B. Open it and have a look. Then (you'll) see.
That puppy has just been born, so now it is yet to open its eyes. Now lots of problems have been revealed! (lit. 'problems have been opened up from a small box.')

commentsTibetan: ཇ་དམ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། སྟོད་ཕད་ཕྱེ། དེབ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ཁ་པར་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ཉལ་ཆས་ཁ་ཕྱེ། མེ་ཏོག་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ཁ་ཅོད་ཁ་ཕྱེ། སྒེའུ་ཁུང་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ཞལ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། གདང་།
commentsEnglish: {kha bye} means to open something that has a door, lid or a mouth. {mig kha phye} in example three is only used for dogs. For humans, one may say {mig gdangs}. In Shigatse and Gyantse dialect, {kha phye} is pronounced {kha phe}.

examples.english: A. I phoned you a few times yesterday, but probably no one was home. B. Oh, yesterday I didn't stay at home.
Why is he ringing her? I'll go and make the phone call. (Note that {kha par gtong} is not as prevalent in Lhasa dialect as {kha par rgyag}.)

commentsEnglish: {kha par gtong} is heard more often in areas outside of Lhasa.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: That person seems to recognise me. She is really grinning.
Those people from the countryside are smiling a lot.

englishGloss: to gang up and attack someone verbally.

examples.english: Over some trivial matter, they ganged up and verbally attacked him for inappropriate (behaviour).
Even though I was right, when they ganged up on me, I couldn't say anything.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: That child doesn't obey his parents, but he does obey the teacher.
I do obey you! Oh my! Obey your parents!

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to talk back, to answer back.

examples.english: It is totally inappropriate to talk back to older people. That child does nothing but sass back to (her) parents.
I have never answered back to a teacher.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to steer, to turn a wheel.

examples.english: Other than being able to barely turn the wheel, that driver doesn't have any other skills.
Only after many years of struggle were we able to control the enemy. England steered the course of India for a long time.

englishGloss: to make up a shortage or deficiency.

examples.english: Tomorrow, I will make up the lesson I missed today. The lost wages of last month, will be made up by the work unit this time.
Please continue to work at our company. We will further add to (your) salary. (i.e., your salary will be increased. {kung si} is a Chinese loan word meaning 'company'.)
Some characters have been left out of this book and need to be put in. (Note that {yi ge} here means letters of the alphabet.)
Your children made the mistake and yet they are still blaming someone else.
He accused me, but I didn't do it. Don't accuse me.
Always claiming to have other assignments, he never fully accomplishes the work of the office. (Note that {las khungs} is often translated as 'work unit' in the context of the P.R.C.)
Tomorrow, you must come to our house. Don't look for some other excuse (not to come). (i.e., don't try to worm your way out of it.)
On the pretext of being ill, he didn't help me.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Have (you) finished loading up the pack animals? B. (I) have finished.
This morning the nomads loaded up the yaks and left. The farmer loaded up the donkey and went to sell dung.

englishGloss: to act as a guarantor or backer.

examples.english: I will act as the backer for the business of you two.
Guarantors for borrowing money are rare these days.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to agree, acknowledge, accept or recognise.
to own up to, to consent to.

examples.english: A. Do you believe in reincarnation? (lit. 'Do you accept that there are future rebirths'?) B. (We) do, but (our) philosophy is different.
I agreed to help him. Before the sacred image of Buddha, he vowed not to drink alcohol.
I didn't promise you anything. ({gan yang} is pronounced {ga'i}.) Work that has been agreed upon should definitely be completed.
I promised my mother that from now on I would not go out and wander around aimlessly.

commentsEnglish: This entry is often used without {byed} as the compound verb {khas len}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He is a great scholar, but in front of other people he acts with great humility.
However great one's knowledge, modesty should be shown in greater measure.

englishGloss: to spread vicious rumours with the intent to cause harm.

examples.english: His bad friend filled his head with ideas and so consequently he ended up in jail. ({mtha' mjug} is pronounced {gzhu gu}.
Doshi incited Ashi to do something bad. (lit. Ashi's stomach was filled by Doshi. The absence of an auxiliary verb in this sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)

commentsEnglish: This literally means, 'to fill/stuff a stomach.' The present tense is {khog pa rgyong} but this is rarely said.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to dig out information using underhand means.

examples.english: He tried to dig it out of me, but I didn't utter a single word.
I don't like digging things out of people.

commentsEnglish: This entry literally means 'to dig the belly'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: When (her) children say troublesome things, she's always patient with them.
If a couple is not tolerant of each other, (they) will always fight.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: These days, that new saying has spread everywhere. The fame of the female singer Tseden Drolma has become widespread.
The cold disease is very easily spread. It is especially easy for children to catch it.
Aspects of Tibetan culture are gradually spreading to many places in the world.
If weeds spread over all the fields, then the harvest will be extremely poor.
Today, the work unit promulgated a new document.
It was decided that his situation would be announced to the public.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: That young child is able to deceive very well. That shopkeeper swindled me by selling me fake things.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. When will they be judged? B. Judgment will be passed next week.
The court passed a harsh sentence on the criminal.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to give a verdict or sentence.

examples.english: His father always disciplines him.
The imperative of a judge is to be fair in rendering a verdict.

englishGloss: to laugh at someone in a sarcastic way.

examples.english: Putting to one side the fact that he didn't listen to my advice, furthermore he ridiculed me.
If you talk about things that you dont understand yourself, other people will ridicule you.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: What's the matter with him these days? (He's) really angry with me. She gets angry very easily.
Don't say very much to that person, as (he) gets angry quickly. What have I done wrong? She is completely angry with me.
Don't sulk. You will bring harm to yourself.
The people protested to demonstrate their opinion.
The people demonstrated about protecting the environment.
A. Are you spinning yarn? B. Yes. (I've) nearly finished.
He spun that thread.

commentsEnglish: This verb refers to spinning yarn, thread, cotton, wool or yak hair.

englishGloss: to be folded, to crouch up.
to freeze, to cringe in terror or fear.

examples.english: A. If I wash these clothes, will they shrink? B. Unless you dry clean them, they will definitely shrink.
When those new soldiers were fighting in a war, (they) were frightened and froze in terror. That soldier was extremely terrified. (lit. 'his courage was completely frozen.')
Animal hide shrinks quickly if singed with fire. These clothes have completely shrunk.

englishGloss: to fall on, to coincide with.
to get settled, decided or confirmed.

examples.english: Today, it has been decided that I will go to mainland China. I finally got my punishment. (lit. 'in the end, the punishment fell on my head'.)
Our work unit's function has fallen on the fifth day of the month. I need to take this medicine. (lit. 'eat medicine'.)
I have to go to the countryside. There is nothing that (I) can do about it. (i.e., it has been decided that I must go to the countryside, so therefore I have to go.)

commentsEnglish: This verb is frequent in Lhasa dialect and is used in the sense of needing to do something. For example, {nga sman 'di za rgyu 'khel gyis} 'I need to take this medicine'. The implication here is, 'This is something I need to do, regardless of my desire to do it or not.' In many cases, one's leader has required that a particular action must take place.

englishGloss: to be labelled, to be called.

examples.english: The history of when this monastery was built has been recorded on the monastery's mural.
A. In which magazine is that story written? ({sgrung} is pronounced {sgrum}.) B. I don't remember.
The Tibetan written language was created after King Song Tsen Gampo became king.

englishGloss: to level, to even, to equalize.

examples.english: It appears as though we need to level the ground around this area.
It would be very convenient if the road in front of our house was levelled out. Please level out this ground.
It is extremely difficult to even out (the discrepancy between) poverty and wealth.

englishGloss: to be blocked, to be stuck.
to accidentally get hooked or caught.
to have feelings of hatred or malice.

examples.english: A. What happened to your chuba? B. Just now my chuba got caught in a tree and ripped.

These days, it seems that the two of them are at odds (with each other). (i.e., they are very angry towards each other.) My kite got caught in the electric wires. ({bya 'phur} is pronounced {bya 'phir}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to regard or look at with hatred or enmity.

examples.english: If you don't like someone, taking it out on their kids is really barbaric. (i.e., if you hate the parents, acting cruelly towards the children is totally barbaric.)
He continually despises me. However, I have absolutely no hatred towards him.
He really hates me now because I fought with his father before.
A. Do you despise him? B. Not too much. (i.e., I don't really despise him.)

englishGloss: to revolve, to rotate, to spin around.

examples.english: This water mill is spinning well. The wind is blowing the prayer wheel around.

Did you come back from Australia? By the look of the birds gliding in the sky, (I would say) there is probably some (dead) flesh around the place. (Note that the speaker is probably near a sky burial site.)
Due to karmic retribution, she must experience such suffering.
The girl is pregnant.

commentsTibetan: བསམ་བློ་འཁོར། དུས་ཚོད་འཁོར། ངན་འབྲས་འཁོར། སྨུག་པ་འཁོར། མགོ་ཡུར་འཁོར། གཟུགས་པོ་འཁོར།
commentsEnglish: {'khor} acts as a verbaliser to many nouns. This verb also has the meaning 'to get an idea', as in the verbalised compound {bsam blo 'khor}.

englishGloss: to request a leave of absence.

examples.english: A. Are you requesting to take this semester off? B. For many years I have not been granted any home leave. So this year, I am going to try to go.
I will ask to be excused to go on home leave this year. (Note that {gro} is the verb in this sentence.)

commentsEnglish: The honorific form of this entry is not very common in Lhasa dialect, but is used predominantly in Shigatse and Gyantse.

examples.english: Tea is boiled and it gets boiled. (This example shows the causative/resultative, transitive/intransitive use of 'to boil'.) If (you) put a kettle on the solar oven when the sun is hot, the water will quickly boil.
The noodles are boiled. Shouldn't we eat? A. Is the water boiled? (i.e., I don't think it is.) B. Perhaps it is.

commentsEnglish: Note that in the second sentence of example one {hu'u} is a Chinese loan word meaning 'kettle' or 'pot'.

examples.english: A. Madam, are you cold? B. No, (I'm) not cold.
If you are cold, warm yourself by the fire. (You) will quickly get warm. ({sros} is pronounced {kros} and {lam seng} as {lam sang}.)

englishGloss: to go down a slippery dip or slippery surface.

examples.english: If you are not careful when ice skating, it can be very dangerous. When she was young, she liked to ice skate.
My child went down a slippery dip and completely ripped his trousers. (Note that 'slippery dip' in this context could be a playground slide or a big slippery rock.)

commentsEnglish: Note that {gangs shur glod} means 'to snow ski.'

englishGloss: to bind, to tie, to fasten.

examples.english: Long ago, there was a custom of binding prisoners hands and feet and leading them to a public market place. Please fasten the top of the sack well.
The way of killing livestock by binding their mouths is very bad. There is a bouquet of flowers tied together over there.

Two nights ago, it rained and there is still a puddle in the courtyard. (lit. 'water is still accumulated in the courtyard.') What happened? There is a puddle of oil here. (lit. 'oil accumulated like this!')
Look, that snake is coiled up.

englishGloss: to climb up a rope or tree.

examples.english: That adept person can cling to the branchless (trunk) of a tree and scale (to the top). (Note that {hreng hreng} here means branchless and is usually used in the sense of 'single' or 'alone'.)
That flower grows by winding around rope and so is called a 'winding flower.' (i.e., a twine.) A monkey can't stay on a tree around which a poisonous snake is coiled. (This is a proverbial saying.)

commentsEnglish: Note that {me tog} in the first sentence of example two can also mean 'plant'. The proverbial saying in the second sentence of example two, highlights the Buddhist view of the perpetual connection between cause and effect.

examples.english: Yesterday, I brought a good book for you. He brought a brand new radio.
During the summertime, the river swells and there is danger of people being carried away. Airplanes are able to carry things of any size.
A. Did you bring (a) book? B. I did. A. Did he bring (a) book? B. Perhaps he has.

commentsEnglish: {khur ba} and {'khyer ba} seem to have a similar meaning, though in general, one uses {khur} for larger, heavier things and {'khyer} for smaller, lighter things. However, the two are still often used interchangeably. In Shigatse dialect, {khur ba} is more commonly used.

examples.english: The author has greatly distorted religion. You shouldn't misrepresent the truth. (lit. 'the true meaning of things'.)
There's no difference between the misrepresentation of culture and history and the awful deception of the next generation.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Is this car able to reach Lhoka? B. I doubt it. (The implication is that the car is not very good.) I couldn't reach the top of the mountain, but he made it right to the top.
A. Are you able to make ends meet? (i.e., manage OK in life?) B. (I) can barely make ends meet. ({thebs chag} is also spelled {thabs chags.)
A. Were you able to finish that work? B. (I'm) about to finish.

That person is wasting his life. (This is a common idiomatic expression said about someone who has is lazy and lacking ambition. In this example {'khyol} is used as a modifying adjective with {gang}.)

commentsEnglish: {'khyol} is used in contrast to {tshar} to indicate that the work is difficult and that there has been hardship involved. {'khyol} isn't used for easy or everyday tasks, and the usage of this verb depends on the speaker's knowledge of the task at hand. When {'khyol} is used in interrogative sentences, the sense is 'Are you able to finish the action or not?'.

examples.english: A. The Shol opera group will perform the story of Namsa Wobum during the yoghurt festival. B. Will we be allowed to go to the opera? A. Of course.
The story of the journey to the West has been very realistically performed.
Many Tibetan movie actors are perfoming well in movies these days.
I know how to perform Tibetan opera, but these days I don't want to perform.

commentsEnglish: The Tibetan opera {snang sa od 'bum}, mentioned in example one, is a famous story about the life of a girl who dies and comes back to life. Note that the honorific {gnang} is only added to {'khrab} when talking about an individual actor. It is not used for groups or performing troupes.

examples.english: He teaches lessons well. The farmers are now planning to lead water through the viaduct. He teaches scriptures well.
Our teacher led all the students to the sports ground.
There is a story of Yonden Gyatso from Ku Lung, who diverted hail with his finger. (The use of {yod} in this sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)

commentsEnglish: Regarding the sentence in Related Words and Expressions, according to Tibetan tradition, lamas with special powers can lead hail, wind and rain from one place to another.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to get disturbed, shaken up or mixed up.
to get into a fight or quarrel.

examples.english: She is disturbed (about something). If the order is mixed up, it is difficult to do work.
Since the road was bad, my insides got all shaken about from being in the car.
These days, those two are going out together. (Note that this use of {'khrug} is particular to Lhasa dialect and implies a romantic relationship.)
Before eating, (one) must wash (one's) hands well. Before eating, please wash your hands.
If the monk's clothes are not washed in the river, they will not become clean.
A. Are you washing clothes? B. No. I'm washing a quilt cover.

englishGloss: to hallucinate, to have an illusion.

examples.english: I was deluded and mistakenly gave fifty yuan instead of ten. (lit. I mistook ten and fifty yuan and gave the larger amount.)
I suppose that when you inhale drugs, you hallucinate that you have arrived in the realm of the gods.

commentsTibetan: མིག་འཁྲུལ། འཁྲུལ་བཤད། འཁྲུལ་སྣང་ཤར། འཁྲུལ་གཏམ། འཁྲུལ་བཅུག རྦད་དེ་འཁྲུལ་སྣང་རེད། བུ་མོ་དེ་འཁྲུལ་ཚ་པོ་ཡོད་རེད།

englishGloss: to get damage from snow fall.

examples.english: In Nagchu, there was a very damaging snowstorm in which many livestock died.
There are some areas of Tibet which are often devastated by snowstorms.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: I have to sweep the classroom today. Grandmother always sweeps the courtyard.
If (you) don't sweep up, the rubbish won't clean itself. (lit. 'go out by it's own accord.')
If water is sprinkled in the courtyard, dust won't billow up. (i.e., it will keep the dust down.)
The monks have sprinkled the lama's path with water and are about to sweep it.

commentsEnglish: This is usually done to help keep dust down.

examples.english: A. When I actually take the photograph will you please smile. B. The other day we smiled all our smiles away. (Note that this phrase is a joke meaning that we dont have any smiles left for the photograph.)
When he said such a strange thing, all the guests couldn't help but laugh.
Please smile.

englishGloss: to laugh, to break into laughter.

examples.english: Please dont say that. It's making me laugh a lot. (It is also common to say in this context {mi gad mo shor kyi red} - 'people will laugh').
I laughed very much at last night's comedy routine. My father also laughed a lot.

One must never analyse the circumstances of history in a way that will cause others to laugh. (The implication is that the person doesnt know what they are talking about. This phrase is used sarcastically.)
I'm laughing at the way they work.
I am sorry. Sometimes I do things that make people laugh. (This phrase is usually said after the speaker has made a mistake as a way to say sorry and to acknowledge the mistake.)
That child always makes me laugh. I told a joke and made him laugh.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to draw up or sign a contract.

examples.english: To draw up a contract, you need to both sign it and stamp it with a red seal. A contract was signed between our factory and the government.
Today, I actually signed the contract to take on the lease of that dance hall. (Note that {'gan gtsang len} means to take on the full responsibilities of something without actually owning it.)
Unless (you) are quite careful, it is not easy to get a contract in this business.

commentsEnglish: {gan rgya bzhag} is used for all tenses.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. When I came, did you hide from me? B. No, I didn't. Why do I need to hide from you?
Because the scary person was about to arrive, he went to hide. A. Who are you hiding from? B. I'm hiding from my older brother.
That thief hid in the shop and stole much gold and silver jewellery.
I hid under the desk. Didn't you see me?

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to do something back to front or the wrong way round.

examples.english: Oh, I have put my jacket on back to front.
He said everything the wrong way round.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Putting up a tent on the grasslands and camping there is pleasant. Setting up a tent on a mountain isn't easy at all.
Since there are homes in nomad areas these days, some nomads don't know how to put up a tent.

commentsEnglish: {gur} is also commonly verbalised with {phibs}, ( which is pronounced {pid}). This verbalised compound is used for putting up a tent when camping or on a picnic.

examples.english: I show respect to my parents. A genuinely good person shows respect to anyone.
You should know how to respect others first, before receiving respect yourself. (This statement is a motivational directive.)

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound seems to function in the same way as {gus bkur byed}. {gus zhabs zu}, listed in the 'humilific form', means 'to pay one's respects to someone'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. I hear the noise of an airplane. Do you hear it? (Note that this question is asked without the ergative particle {gis}. This question is commonly said without the ergative particle, though one could also say {khyed rang gis...}.) B. I also hear it.
I don't understand the meaning of the Geshe's debate at all. (A Geshe is a Gelukpa monk who has obtained a high academic degree and is fit to teach others. There are four levels of Geshe.)

commentsEnglish: This verb is traditionally categorised as intransitive {tha mi dad pa}, but Kesang Gyurme considers this verb to be transitive and non-volitional. See glossary for more details on verbal arguments.

englishGloss: to imply, hint or say indirectly.
to say something with a double meaning.

examples.english: She made sarcastic implications to me. I said many indirect things to him, yet he still didn't understand. (Note that {blugs} is used here instead of {gzhu}. In this context, {blugs} is more common.)
That person is an expert at saying things with a double meaning.

commentsEnglish: In Lhasa dialect, {go rgyu blugs} is more common than {go rgyu gzhu}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to put in order, to rank, to arrange.

examples.english: The leaders sat in order (of rank) at the large meeting. We have arranged this dictionary in alphabetical order.

commentsEnglish: This entry is not commonly used in Lhasa dialect.

examples.english: After this bridge was built, those people's lives improved. (We) need to read more books in order to advance our level of learning. ({rig gnas} can also be translated as 'Culture'. This is a motivational directive and reflects literary Tibetan.)
We need to improve the standard of living of the masses. (This is a slogan or motivational directive.)
We need to develop the skill level of citizens, if (we) want society to advance. (This is a slogan or motivational directive.)
That country is developing quickly. Their live's have improved.

We must all work hard, if we want the entire society to move forward. (This sentence might be seen either in a newspaper or on a red banner. {hril po} is more literary but is still said by some Lhasa dialect speakers.)

The culture development of a nationality is the responsibility of the upcoming generation. (This statement is a motivational directive. The use of {yin} reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.)
The government has spent lots of money on this area and is greatly improving the economy.

englishGloss: to walk or take a step.

examples.english: We walked a very long way. The elderly gentleman is not able to walk very much.
A. Teacher, did you walk (here)? B. No, I came by car.
A. Are you used to foreign food? B. At first it was difficult, but these days I'm completely accustomed to it.
I am completely familiar with that work. He is not really used to driving a car. (Note that {goms po} is used as an adjective.)
If one can familiarise oneself with computers, it will be incredibly helpful with work.
Children need to be made familiar with hygiene from the time they are small.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: At new year, Tibetans wear new clothes. Today, he is wearing very fashionable clothes.
Today, you are wearing a very fashionable hat! Mother is wearing nice clothes.

commentsTibetan: སྒྲོག་དུང་གྱོན། སྒྲོག་གདུབ་གྱོན། སྐེ་ཐག་གྱོན། ཁ་དཀྲིས་གྱོན། ལྷམ་གོག་གྱོན། ལག་ཞུབས་གྱོན། སྤྲས།

examples.english: Most likely our parents are coming to Tibet next week, so you must please prepare a room for them.
Please arrange a table for us. I am preparing to go for a run.
Mum is at home preparing food. We had better get ready as the guests are about to arrive.
A. How many chairs are here? B. Count them and then you'll know.
Here's your change. Please count it. I don't think the amount of books has been counted. (lit. 'books that are here or not here.')

commentsEnglish: Note that the honorific {ljags rtsis bskyon} is only used to refer to counting money or calculating the bill.

examples.english: A. Are you full? B. I'm very full.
This food is not filling. No matter how much money people get, they are never satisfied.
A. I bet you're hungry. B. I am hungry. I'm going to eat something.
A. Did you continue to work through your hunger? B. No, I ate some bread just now.
A. Do you have an upset stomach? B. I wonder what's wrong? (lit. 'what is harming me?') I have a little diarrhoea.
Don't you have diarrhoea? I have diarrhoea really badly.
I don't know when this current meeting finishes. My shoe lace is undone.
A. Has your lesson finished? B. It has.
We will discuss that matter from yesterday. The leaders said they will discuss my report.
Today, we will have a discussion and decide some new directions for our work.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: If you have talks with broad-minded scholars, you will be greatly enriched.
There is a proverb which says, discuss with others but decide yourself. (This means you should discuss with others before making a decision.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: In summer, lots of people like to go for picnics. There are many picnickers in the Norbulingkha.
A. On May 1st, where did you go for a picnic? B. We went to Rainbow Spring.
Before thunder, there is lightening. A flash of lightening is a sign of coming rain.
Last night, there was a lot of lightening.

commentsEnglish: Note that {glog rgyag} is another verbalised compound meaning 'a strike of lightening'.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: The other day when decorating the house, he got an electric shock. If (you) are not careful, (you'll) get an electric shock.
The other day, someone died from an electric shock from a generator.

englishGloss: to release, to let go, to let loose.

examples.english: (I) saw a child flying a kite on the roof. If (that) dog is let loose, it will bite people!
Without releasing the water from the tap, please block it securely. Please let down the chain.
Yet again, that culprit has been released from prison.

commentsTibetan: ཞབས་འཕེན་གློད། སྦར་ག་གློད། རྒྱུག་ཤར་གློད། བྱ་འཕིར་གློད། འཁྱགས་ཤུར་གློད། ཨོག་བཙིར་གློད། ཛོར་རྟགས་གློད། ཁ་བརྡར་གློད། འབབ་རིལ་གློད།

englishGloss: to refute, to object, to contest.

examples.english: He is always refuting what I say. In one essay old customs were strongly denounced.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be glad, to be pleased, to be happy.
to like, to love, to be fond of.
to be better, to be more advantageous.

examples.english: I gave that girl a flower and she was very pleased. If I could be admitted to university, that would be great.
It is better to beg than to steal. I like you very much.
A. I bet he likes Dekyi very much. Doesn't he? B. Oh, that's not it. Dekyi loves him like crazy!
Parents instruct their children through love.

commentsEnglish: Although {dga'} is often translated 'to love', the expression {nga khyed rang la dga' gis} is not a natural way for Tibetans to express the similar sense of 'I love you' in English.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: We are happy now that all our work duties have been completed.
It's not nice at all when there is a drunk saying annoying things at a happy celebration. (lit. 'at a joyful place'.)
In summer, most Lhasa people go to the Norbu Lingkha to have a fun time.
As he accepted his soccer award, he cried with joy. As soon as I received my university acceptance notice, I cried with joy.

englishGloss: to have a party, banquet or celebration.

examples.english: Because a high leader went to Shigatse, a big banquet was held.
In Beijing, the Olympic committee had a grand celebration for the commencement (of preparations).
A. When are you having your wedding celebration? B. I'm not going to have a big wedding banquet.

englishGloss: to like, to be fond of, to love.

examples.english: He and I have liked each other for three years. He likes watching movies.
There are more and more people who are fond of these clothes. He likes the cuisine of the (local) Hui nationality.

commentsEnglish: In contemporary Lhasa dialect, the use of the term {kha che} in example two refers to all Muslims. The term is generally considered a perjorative term by Muslims themselves and many prefer to be called Hui. The historical use of {kha che} in Tibetan texts refers to people from Kashmir.

englishGloss: to be joyous or in high spirits.

examples.english: Because (I) saw her letter, I was very happy. When there is thunder, peacocks are in high spirits.
The authorities should be asked their opinion whether this plan can be implemented or not.
I will ask my mother and father their thoughts on whether I can go or not.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The other day I was completely wrong. I would like to apologise to you. The other day I was completely wrong. Can you please forgive (me).

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: It's now late, and I would ask that you excuse me. Unless you ask the teacher if you can be absent, (you) will be scolded.
I am going to ask the leader for leave-of-absence.

commentsEnglish: The expression {dgongs pa zhu} is a common and respectful way of letting someone know you are going to leave.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. What do you want? B. I want a bowl of noodle soup.
Today, I need to go the market and buy a few things. People do not want illness, (just as) trees do not want knots. (This expression is a proverb.)
If (you) want something, say it clearly. If you don't want anything, just leave it.

englishGloss: to divide, to allot, to apportion.

examples.english: (Our) father divided the snacks between myself and my older brother. We are doing our work by dividing (it) amongst several people.
I divided one yuan between a few beggars and gave it to them. Shall we divide this butter?
I didn't get my share!

commentsEnglish: In the first sentence of example one note that {rngan pa} also means 'gifts' or ' tips'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: We will extend the work time a little. Even a prince can lose his place, if he falls three steps behind. (This proverb means 'it is better not to delay, postpone, or be late with anything'.)

It is not good to extend the completion of a task. (i.e., 'the completion time of a task.') The arrival time of the airplane was delayed. (Note that {'gyangs} is the intransitive, non.vol. form of {bgyangs}.)

commentsEnglish: In the proverb in the second sentence of example one, {sdod} is pronounced {bsdad}.

englishGloss: to be full of delight or joy.

examples.english: He is pleasing to everyone. However much you say, it is hard to please that person.
A. Do you fancy this room? B. I do.

englishGloss: to trick, dupe, fool or deceive.

examples.english: People say that the man deceived his wife and sought a mistress outside (the home). ({zur gsal} is also spelled {zur bza'}.)
Those meat sellers always use false scales for weighing and cheat us.
She cheated me.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: They laid their weapons on the ground and surrendered to the enemy.
Weak are those who give up in the face of difficulty.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: To kill an enemy who has surrendered is a breach of international law.
The soldiers surrended to him in a respectful way. (In this example, the soldiers are not necessarily sincere in their respect.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is very similar in meaning and usage to {mgo sgur}
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be turned over, to be rolled over.
to be turned back to front.

examples.english: This morning, the prayer flags on the roof were turned upside down. If a phrase is reversed, the meaning will change. ({tshig phreng} is literally a 'string of words'.)
That car is turned upside down. That photo is turned upside down.
When we were young, we used to roll around on the sand. (lit. 'we used to play by rolling around on the sand'.)
Don't turn over the cup, it is bad luck! ({rnam rtog} refers to the perception that certain behaviour may lead to either harmful or beneficial consequences. The usual sense is in to avoid bad luck.)

englishGloss: to act in a shrewd, cunning way.

examples.english: When some soccer players take the ball, (they) can fake out six or so players. (i.e., they can do fake moves to get past others. {'ga' shas} is pronounced {kha shas}.)
Business people these days have various kinds of methods to trick people.
Don't deceive me.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to know, understand or grasp mentally.

examples.english: A. Do you understand what I said? B. I don't understand what you are talking about.
There is a traditional saying, 'comprehend and lick your brain.' (This proverbial saying means 'first you must understand the work before you do it'.)
I get really dizzy if I ride in a car. My head was spinning, and I vomited.
If you say extremely troublesome things like that, (I) get dizzy. When she says some things that are partly true and partly aren't, it makes my head spin.

commentsEnglish: {mgo yur 'khor} literally means 'to have a spinning head'.

englishGloss: to make a real mess of things.

examples.english: I really made a mess of things. The butter I bought this morning was left in the sun and has completely melted. ({lus} is said {las} and {bzhur} is also spelled {bzhus}.)

Oh, if (you) leave children to their own devices, (they) will cause trouble. (lit. 'if you carelessly release children...') Last night, (I) made a mess of things. (I) forgot to bring in the quilt cover and it got totally soaked with rain. ({lus} is pronounced {las}.)

commentsEnglish: Although often used interchangeably, there is a slight difference in meaning between {mgo log rtse} and {mgo log bzo}. Using {bzo} as the verbaliser carries the sense that the trouble has been caused by carelessness. Using {rtse} as the verbaliser denotes that the trouble was purely accidental.

englishGloss: to send or give a written invitation.

examples.english: I still haven't given out the invitations for my son's wedding. An invitation letter for a tea party was sent to me from the Foreign Affairs Office. (A {ja stong} is an informal social gathering where different beverages are served.)

englishGloss: to be blocked, stopped or obstructed.

examples.english: Since it rained a lot last night, those pipes are blocked.
That crucial letter was stopped by customs.

englishGloss: to bump or run into another sentient being.

examples.english: On the mountain side, the young shepherd met a wolf head on and nearly lost his life. (lit. nearly had his life cut off. {srog} here is pronounced {krog}.)
Yesterday, I bumped into my mother at the market and we returned home together.

commentsEnglish: {'gag thug rgyag} can also mean to meet someone head on.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The food (I ate) didn't seem to have digested. (I) burped a lot. This child is burping, yet still eating.
He burped a lot.

commentsEnglish: There is debate as to whether this entry is volitional.

englishGloss: to be in equal amount or proportion.

examples.english: The sale of this is not going well, so getting the same return as the capital amount will be OK.
Today's sales did not equal the capital expenditure.

commentsEnglish: This compound is used in association with buying and selling things. It is used primarily by business people.

examples.english: The parents were are able to attract the affections of (their) children by rough and smooth means. (i.e., the parents were able to snare their hearts by whatever rough or smooth methods.)
By giving flowers and so forth, the boy is relying on various means to attract the girl's heart.
Since this iron is steel, it is very difficult to bend.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Everyone, do your work with pep! (We'll) finish quickly.
It is beneficial if a sick patient doesn't lie down all day but moves around a little.
That fish is flapping around a lot. Don't move around so much.
Don't move the desk around. (Note that {gtong} is the verbaliser in this phrase.)

commentsEnglish: {'gul skyod} is also verbalised with {gtong} though this construction seems less common.

examples.english: In the Nag Chu region, women like to cover their faces. This is because the sun and the wind are very strong and if their faces are not covered, they will become completely black.
(You) need to cover (your) mouth when (you) cough. Please cover your mouth. (Note that the imperative form is {khob} but is always said {bkab} and so has been written this way here.)
Please put the lid on the kettle. (Note that {ha yang} can also mean 'aluminium' or 'aluminium pot'.)
Think about getting advice and not about concealing your faults.

commentsEnglish: In Lhasa dialect, the present tense {'gebs} is rarely said.

englishGloss: to be infected, to catch a disease.

examples.english: Perhaps I have caught his cold. My son caught a cold from him. (lit.'caught his cold.')
If (you) are not careful, it is easy to catch a disease these days. In order for children not to get infected by disease, (they) must get vaccinations on time.
Some young Tibetans, have recently adopted many foreign ways of doing things.
When it rains, cars get really muddy. (That is, mud gets stuck on them. {'dam bag} is pronounced {tag pa}.)
My shoes got excrement on them.

commentsEnglish: The past tense of this verb is also spelled {'gos} and all tenses of this verb are pronounced {'gos}. Therefore the past tense spelling {'gos} has been used in the example sentences.

examples.english: A. Has the meeting started? B. It's about to start now.
A. When does our lesson start? B. It starts at 9 o'clock.

Now the performance is about to begin! (Note that the correct future tense of {'dzugs} is {gzugs}, but this is rarely said.) That company's business enterprise started one month ago. ({kung si} is a Chinese loan word for 'company'.)
The Monkey King, Sun Wu Khun, got angry and pulled out the entire god tree. (Note that this is a reference to the famous Chinese story 'Journey to the West'.)
A. What are you doing? B. I am picking peaches. ({kham bu} can also be translated as, 'apricots'.)
One of my teeth has become rotten and is causing a lot of pain. (I) will go immediately to the hospital and get it pulled out.

commentsEnglish: {'gog} is pronounced {bkog} for all the tenses.

englishGloss: to ban, to block, to obstruct, to stop.

examples.english: The government prepared instructions on how to block the epidemic.
We have implemented various means for blocking flood damage.

commentsEnglish: {'gog} is pronounced {bkag} for all tenses. An alternative past tense spelling is {'gegs}.

englishGloss: to draw up, to formulate, to plan.

examples.english: Presently, we are formulating next year's plan. He drew up a map of Mt. Everest. ({sa khra} is also spelled {sa bkra}. Both are said {sab khra}.)
That king made everyone happy. (lit. 'made the subjects happy'.) I put that news in the newspaper.
According to Buddhism, the Buddha has put many transmigrators onto the path of liberation.
Oh, that person walked all over my clothes and left. If food containers are walked over, they will get dirty.
Step over the door sill and enter.

englishGloss: to shoot, fire or fling a slingshot.

examples.english: The child fired the slingshot and killed a bird. You kids, don't haphazardly shoot slingshots or you'll break some glass (windows).
You'd better not take a liking to firing slingshots or you could make (others) blind. ({long ba} is pronounced {long nga}.)

englishGloss: to be changed, to be transformed.

examples.english: Our society has completely changed. His clothes have changed colour.
(Her) mind changes as easily as the spring weather.
Last night, lightening struck and electricity poles fell down. I was dizzy and fell.
The old lady slipped and fell over.
If (you) aren't careful, you could fall down the stairs. ({'dzeg} is pronounced {'dzag}.)
When playing soccer, many players always fall over. (Note that in Lhasa dialect, the use of the verb {ril} instead of {'gyel} would be more common in this context.)
Lift up the rock and don't drop it on your foot. This big beam is difficult to lift.
Lift up (your) feet and come here. (i.e., get moving over here.)
One day we will serve you food. (i.e., we'd love to have you over for a meal sometime.)

commentsEnglish: This verb is pronounced {bkyag} for all tenses.

examples.english: I really regret the non virtue I have accumulated. I feel regret today, because I really insulted you yesterday.
The Olympics will be held in Beijing in the year 2008. (lit. 'contested in Beijing'.) I don't like competing against other people.
She is always competing with the way I dress. ({dug slog} is also spelled {dug log}.) Many people have arrived at the horse race.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: On our pilgrimage, we travelled through many places.
A. How many years of school has she gone through? B. Probably a little more than 10 years.

commentsEnglish: This is rarely said in Lhasa dialect. It is more common to use {phyin} or {brgyud}.

examples.english: A. Have you finished this work yet? When you finish it, please tell me. B. I've only just started to prepare. As soon as I finish it, I will tell you first.
A. Have you finished work? B. (I) have finished.
Her getting a promotion like that is definitely the result of previously accumulated merit. (Note that this statement reflects the Tibetan Buddhist view of cause and effect.)

englishGloss: to have mishaps happen when guests are visiting.
to have visitors bring bad luck.

examples.english: My child has many mishaps when guests arrive. Last night, she had a mishap when some people came over and is now very sick.
A. Some people never have mishaps when guests arrive. B. Oh, they probably just don't notice it.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Stallions roll back and forth on sand when they are set free on it. (The use of {yod} in this sentence reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.)
He wasn't able to endure the pain and had to writhe around.
Oh! The children have again spread my things everywhere. In this month, the Tashi Lhungbo monastery will display the big material thankgha. (Note that {gos sku} is a ceremonial thangkha.)
The document was distributed everywhere and publicised. Please spread out those things. (Note that the past tense is used for the imperative. The imperative form {khroms} is rarely used.)

commentsEnglish: In example two, note that {cig} is semantically linked to the verb {bkram} and not the preceding nominal clause. It doesn't mean 'one' in the strict sense but rather implies 'do this now'. {cig} in this sense is often connected with imperatives and appears in many of the example sentences.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Unless each word is explained, they will not be able to understand it. How did this situation happen? Please explain (it to me).
A. Mister, where are you going? B. I am going out. A. Where has my son gone? B. Perhaps (he) has gone to class. (Speaker A uses a hyper-corrective construction. See comments below.)
A. Teacher, where have you been going these days? B. Oh, I have been going around the Lingkhor. (i.e., the sacred circuit of Lhasa.)
A. When did Dekyi go to Australia? B. She left last week. (lit. 'the week before this one.')
This key doesn't go in this lock. This window is difficult to open.

The Panchen Lama will go to Shigatse. Tangsen lama met many obstacles as he went seeking the Dharma. (This sentence reflects literary Tibetan. {thang seng bla ma} is a monk from the Tang dynasty. This is taken from the famous Chinese story, 'Journey to the West'.)

commentsTibetan: ཆིབས་བསྒྱུར་གནང་དགོས། ག་ལེ་ཕེབས་ཨོའོ། སྐད་ཆ་འདི་འགྲོ་གི་མ་རེད། དངུལ་འདི་འགྲོ་གི་མི་འདུག འཕྲོ་བརླག་འགྲོ། ཡར་མར་འགྲོ།
commentsEnglish: In example one, the speaker could also say {ga par phyin song} without the interrogative particle {ngas}. The example has been marked 'hyper-corrective', because the speaker utters both the interrogative pronoun {ga re} and the question particle {ngas}. See 'hyper-corrective' in the glossary for further discussion. Notice the perfective aspect in the common expression {ngas cig phyin} - 'I better be off'. Such usage indicates a second action is required after the first action of leaving has completed. {thegs}, used in example two, is pronounced {thad}. The second meaning 'to function properly' is usually non-volitional. Note that {song} is an auxillary indicating the perfective aspect and is an 'eye-witness' evidential. {song} is the imperative form of {'gro} in literary Tibetan, but in Lhasa dialect the imperative is {rgyugs} - which is non-honorific. {song} is also an alternative past tense of {'gro} in literary Tibetan, and some spoken dialects outside of Lhasa use {song} in this way.

specialForms.writtenForm: བྱོན། ཆས། གཤེགས། དེངས་། འདོང་། བསྐྱོད། བཞུད། བཏེགས།

englishGloss: to set free, to release, to liberate.

examples.english: A. Son, untie your shoe laces. (You) need to take (your) shoes off. ({lham gog} is pronounced {han gog}). B. I don't know how to untie my laces. Dad, could you please help me.
I am untying the string of this sack. Once you unravel the meaning of this verse, it is very profound.

commentsEnglish: {'grol} is commonly pronounced {bkrol} for all tenses.

englishGloss: for an old person to take on monastic vows.
to dedicatedly pursue the Dharma when old.
to become a nun or a monk when you are old.

examples.english: A. Where is your grandmother practicising the Dharma? B. At Chusang monastery.
His mother is presently living as an elderly nun. In the future, as an old person, I'm going take on monastic vows.
A. I will retire next year. B. Have you put in your request for retirement yet? A. Yes, I have already.
He didn't get permission to retire.

commentsEnglish: The Chinese expression {thud zhu}, 'to retire', is frequently said in contemporary Lhasa dialect.

englishGloss: to thrive, to prosper, to bloom.
to flourish, to swell, to rise.

examples.english: These days, Lhasa's river has really risen. (lit. 'the water of Lhasa's river'...) The goats' and sheep's coats have become really full. (The absence of an auxiliary verb in this sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)
When you have a cold, fever arises.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to say sarcastic or biting things.

examples.english: That girl mocked me. (i.e., with her sarcasm.) If you say something like that, it will be interpreted as being sarcastic to other people. (Note that {rgyag par} is often said {rgyag gar}.)
Don't be sarcastic (with me). (That guy) is really sarcastic.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Those two are fighting. B. Why? A. Perhaps the fight broke out over business.
A. That married couple always fights. B. Hence, their living room is a virtual battlefield! (Note that this expression is intended sarcastically.)
What's the point of fighting?

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound is also sometimes spelled {rgyab 'dre rgyab} and pronounced {rgyam 'dre rgyab}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to visit a holy place, statue or thangkha from a distance.
to meet the 'Dharma' from a distance.

examples.english: When the ceremonial thangkha at Tashi Lhunpo monastery was displayed, we undertook a religious encounter from afar. ({'grems} is pronounced {bkram}.)

When the Panchen Rinpoche came to Tibet, there were so many people that it was only possible to seek a religious encounter from a distance. (i.e., to seek an audience with the intention of receiving a blessing from his presence.)

commentsEnglish: This is typically said at sacred places that are very crowded. Pilgrims pay homage to a sacred image or person from a distance because they can not get close.

examples.english: A. Are you gambling? B. We are not gambling, just playing for fun.
He even lost his house by gambling (it away). He doesn't like betting games at all.

commentsEnglish: The expression 'to bet' is often said as {rgyan bzhag} as in the question {rgyan cig bzhag gas} - 'Do you want to bet?'.

englishGloss: to turn one's back on someone.

examples.english: That minister betrayed the king and fled to another country. ({bros} is pronounced {bos}.)
The person who turned his back on your friend is awful!

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: No matter where you go, it's hard to work without some support.
There is no way to support what he has said.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Whatever (you) have to say, it is better to say it up front and not behind one's back.
He always talks about other people behind their backs.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: When faced with hardship, don't retreat. (This is a motivational directive.) Even if we should perish by the enemy's weapons, we shall not retreat.
Because I walked backwards in a line of people, the old lady behind me told me off. ({bang} is pronounced {pang}.)
If everyone steps backwards and sits down, (we) will be able to see the perfomance well.
He is walking backwards.
Please back up the car. (In Australian English: 'Please reverse the car.')

englishGloss: to race, to run, to gallop.

examples.english: Hundreds of horses are galloping back and forth across the grasslands. When I was young I raced horses, but I never won a prize.
Every morning, I run three laps around the sports field.
I nursed him for a long period. There is much virtue in children serving their parents.

commentsEnglish: There are two verbs which have {rgyug} as the present tense. One is transitive and the other is intransitive. They have been listed separately. Keeping this distinction clear is important for correct usage. The expression {lam rgyug pa'i sgang red}, in Related Words and Expressions, is said of someone who is presently going through a time of good fortune.

englishGloss: to flow, to circulate, to run.

examples.english: The Yarlung river flows from west to east. Foreign goods are selling very well in Lhasa.
A. Does this pen work? (lit. 'does the pen flow well.') B. It doesn't work very well.
