commentsEnglish: There are two verbs which have {rgyug} as the present tense. One is transitive and the other is intransitive. They have been listed separately. Keeping this distinction clear is important for correct usage.

englishGloss: to comb or brush one's hair.

examples.english: A. Do you brush your hair every evening just before going to bed? B. Of course. If I don't, then (my) hair will be messy and difficult to brush in the morning.
Since nomad children don't brush (their) hair after washing it, all their hair becomes a long matted mane. (i.e., like dreadlocks.)
Unless you brush your hair, it will be all messed up. (lit. 'unless you brush your head'...)
He returned home running. (Or more naturally, 'He ran home'.) I like running.
I will enter a running race.
If one is able to persist in Tibetan language studies, one will comprehend much Tibetan wisdom.
Our grandfather has a very healthy body because he routinely goes around the Lingkhor. (The Lingkhor is the sacred outer circumambulation circuit in Lhasa.)
Our responsibility is to uphold the good traditions of our ancestors.
He put forward many ideas about maintaining Tibetan culture.
It is more comfortable to ride a horse after saddling it. He is saddling yaks.
I saddled a donkey. ({bong bu} is pronounced {bong gu}.)
A. Can your child crawl? B. She can a little.
A. Does (your) child know how to crawl? B. He nearly knows how to crawl.
When training as a soldier, one should definitely know how to crawl.
Unless (you) crawl, (you) won't get through. (lit. 'come by crawling'. Note that the context refers to someone going through a tunnel, cave or small opening.)

englishGloss: to set up a military camp.

examples.english: The army set up camp at the place of the flooding and day and night did much work for the people. (lit. without looking at whether it was day or night...)
Look, many army encampments have been set up on the side of that mountain over there.
A. Is he waiting for me at the office? B. He is not waiting (for you).

A. What are you doing? B. I'm waiting for someone. A. Who are you waiting for? B. I am waiting for a friend. (Speaker A uses a hyper-corrective construction. This could also be said {su sgug gnang gi yod} as in the previous question. See glossary.)
A. Did he wait for me? B. He waited for you until three o'clock.
Tomorrow, I will wait for you at the Norbulingkha.
Please wait for him.

commentsTibetan: ཡོད་དུས་གཏོར་མ་བཏང་། མེད་དུས་གཏོར་ཆུ་བཏང་། ང་སེན་མོ་གང་སྒུག་ཨཱ། ང་ཚར་གྲབས་ཡོད། ངས་ཁོང་སྒུག་བསྡད་པ་ཡིན། ངས་ཁྱེད་རང་ག་པར་སྒུག་བསྡད་གཱ ག་པར་སྒུག་དགོས་རེད་པས། ཁྱེད་རང་གིས་ང་ག་དུས་སྒུག་གནང་ཀ ང་ཚོས་ཁྱེད་རང་དུས་ཚོད་རིང་པོ་སྒུག་བསྡད་པ་ཡིན། རེ་སྒུག་བq䞄ਜr
commentsEnglish: While {sgug} does require the ergative particle, it is often omitted in Lhasa dialect. See glossary for further discussion. The use of the humilific {phebs sgug zhu} can only be directed to the second and third person. For example, {khyed rang gis khong phebs sgug zhu gi yod pas} 'Are you waiting for her?'. It can not be used to say 'He waited (hon.) for me'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to pour out the last of something from a container.

examples.english: Unless you bend your head down, you'll hit it. (i.e., you'll bump your head on the ceiling. Note that {sgur sgur gnang} is a verbalised compound.) I will not surrender to the enemy.
Unless the last of the tea is poured out of the thermos, it will become sour by midday. ({skyur} also means 'rancid'.)

commentsEnglish: The second meaning, 'to bow', means 'to bow one's head'.

examples.english: Son, when you go out, please close the door. That company has completely shut down. ({kung si} is a Chinese loan word.)
Unless (you) go quickly, the shop will close.

commentsEnglish: {sgo rgyag} is also used to refer to a shop or company that has shut down or gone out of business.

examples.english: Don't lock the door. Mother is inside the house. I am going to lock my bike.
You need to lock up your mouth as everything you say can be over heard. (lit. 'you are saying everything to the outside.')
Mother, I need to get something out. Please unlock the cabinet.
Oh, I have left the house unlocked. Unless I go quickly, something might disappear. ({brlag gtor} is lit. 'wrecked or destroyed.')

englishGloss: to bolt or bar a door.

examples.english: By the manner in which his door is barred, it definitely looks like he has committed a very serious crime.
I wonder why have they barred up their house?

englishGloss: to be left knocking at someone's door.
to knock on a door and get no answer.

examples.english: I called you ahead of time, so that I would not be left knocking at your door for long.
I went to visit you twice, but both times I knocked and got no answer.
When I came to your house, I was left knocking at the door.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. When did this post office open? B. It's been open since yesterday. A. How many years have passed since this shop was opened up? B. Many years have passed.
Older brother, quickly open the door. Mother is coming. Even if (you) go to the market now, the shops won't be open.
A. What deity are you meditating on? (hyper-corrective. See below.) B. I'm mediating on Avalokiteshvara.
When religious people meet hardship, they meditate on joy.

commentsEnglish: The first sentence in example one has been marked 'hyper-corrective'. The speaker here could also say, {khyed rang lha ga re sgom gi yod}, without the additional interrogative particle {pas}. The question has both the interrogative pronoun {ga re} and the question particle {pas}. See 'hyper-corrective' in the glossary for further discussion.

examples.english: A. What is the benefit of meditating? B. The mind is able to be at peace.
That monk meditated in a mountain hermitage for three years.

englishGloss: to change, to transform, to alter.

examples.english: I changed my permanent residence (card) from the countryside to the city. Everyone likes that English storybook which was translated into Tibetan.

My name was changed by my parents when I was a child, because I was not very healthy. During one's obstruction year, the colour of one's clothing is changed. Tibetans say that changing the colour of one's clothes represents a bodily change and a protective layer.
If five is multiplied by three you get fifteen.

commentsEnglish: In the first sentence of example two, a child's name is often changed to help bring better fortune to the child. In the second sentence of example two, changing the colour of one's clothes is done in order to stop harm from coming to the person. The obstruction year is the first year after every 12 year cycle.

englishGloss: to put a " voice over", to dub.

examples.english: This entire English language textbook has had audio recordings made. The way he dubs his voice is superb.
My older sister is a person who does movie voice-overs.
The teacher has disciplined the students well. Our boss has trained the company well. ({kung si} is a Chinese loan word.)
The teacher said that she is going to make the classroom rules again.
Children need to be disciplined well from a young age.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The sun was covered by the clouds and the weather became cool. The tall building in front (of ours) is concealing all the sunlight from us.

The minds of the transmigrators are blocked by the afflictions. ({'gro ba} is usually understood as {'gro ba rigs drug} -the six types of beings caught in the wheel of suffering. This expression reflects literary Tibetan.)

commentsEnglish: The intransitive, non-volitional form {'grib} seems to be rarely used in Lhasa dialect.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: He is winding a thread. I am tightening a screw.
If you concentrate well, there will be a good result in whatever work you do. He now has a great deal of knowledge because he focused on his studies when he went through school.
From now on, all students should concentrate.

commentsEnglish: The primary meaning of {sgrim} is to twist, tighten or wind a screw, wire or string.

englishGloss: to pick up something off the ground.

examples.english: Villagers gather firewood everyday. She gathered many cowry shells from the sea.
I picked some money up from the ground. My rosary fell to the ground. Please pick it up (for me). ({phreng ba} is pronounced {phreng nga}.)
Some people like to pick up on the off-hand remarks of others and refute them.
My friend acquired many things from abroad. If (you) are diligent at (your) work, (you) will be able to accomplish it well.
It is not easy to obtain a personal diety. (Note that a {yi dam} is a tutelary diety who provides guidance and protection during tantric practice.)
It is hard to cut through the misrepresentations of this issue.
By using many forms of reasoning, the Geshe cut away the feathers attached to our doubts. (i.e., he dispelled our misunderstandings and our basis for doubt.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is rarely said. It literally means 'to cut away feathers that have been attached to something'.

englishGloss: to exaggerate. (lit. to stick feathers on something.)

examples.english: They were completely exaggerating their praise for that person.
My opinion is whatever the situation, isn't it better not to exaggerate but rather tell the truth?

commentsEnglish: This verb is commonly used in Buddhist philosophy as it represents one of the two extremes of looking at something, that is, overstatement or understatement. It's counterpart is {skur ba 'debs} which means, 'to understate' or 'underestimate something'. {skur ba 'debs} is also translated, 'to denigrate, profane or blaspheme.'
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to set out, to lay out.

examples.english: A. Is it OK if I take your photo? B. Of course.
I need to put some clothing on that (sacred) image. Tsong Khapa the Victorious put a fresh lump of butter on (the statue of) the Buddha's head.
It is said that if (you) paint gold on a (sacred) image, (you) will accrue unlimited merit.

As soon as (she) heard about that situation, (she) fainted. The mother of this family cried and nearly fell unconscious twice. (i.e., great suffering has come upon her causing her to nearly fall unconscious.)
Suffering causes fainting. (The absence of an auxiliary verb in this sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)

commentsEnglish: This verb is usually associated with suffering of the heart or mind as the cause for fainting or falling unconscious.

examples.english: There are many basic rules in Tibetan that one needs to recite from memory. When students come to grade three, they must be able to recite the Divine Tree. (Note that {ljon pa'i dbang po} is a famous grammar text of the {sum ju ba}.)
I recited all of this book from memory.

commentsEnglish: The entry is more commonly verbalised with {gtong} than {byed}.

englishGloss: to renounce talking for a period.

examples.english: The monk was keeping silent and so I didn't feel comfortable asking him a question. ({shes} lit. means 'to know', but here the sense is of feeling awkward or uneasy about interrupting the monk.)
On every auspicious day, my mother keeps silent and does virtuous deeds.

commentsTibetan: ཁོང་གིས་ངག་བཅད་གནང་ཤག ཕ་ཆེར་སྨྱུང་གནས་ལ་བཞུགས་ཡོད་པ་འདྲ། ངག་སྡོམ། ངག་བཅད་པ། ངག་ཡིན། ངག་ལ་བཞུགས་པ།
commentsEnglish: This entry is often accompanied with fasting - {smyun gnas} - and is usually abbreviated to {nga ngag yin} 'I'm fasting' or {khong ngag la bzhugs pa}, 'She's fasting'.

examples.english: Everyday, we have to write a paragraph from the lesson by memory in front of the teacher.
I can write a short verse of poetry from memory.
That person is someone capable of extreme patience. Though (his) sister spoke patiently with him, he still didn't listen.
You should persevere in (your) studies.
It is useless treating bad people of his ilk with patience, rather (they) can only be treated with severity.
Those who incite the public into various kinds of disturbances are bad.
A few people meddled with that married couple and broke up their relationship. (lit. 'made them unfriendly.')
He incited that child and caused him to steal. ({rku ma} is also spelled {rkun ma}.)

commentsEnglish: {ngan skul byed} literally means 'to goad someone to do evil'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He always conspires against others. They plotted that evil deed together.

commentsEnglish: This literally means 'to carry out an evil plan, scheme or strategy'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to act in a mean or cruel way.

examples.english: He is being cruel to me. Don't be mean to other people.

commentsEnglish: {ngan pa byed} and {gnag sems byed} seem to be interchangeable. See {gnag sems byed} for other example sentences.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to plot, to conspire, to collaborate.

examples.english: In some places of the world, terrorists are plotting these days to cause serious harm to the lives of people.
I think that those two theives conspired together and broke out from prison. ({bros} is pronounced {bos}.)
If (people) conspire together, great harm to society is caused. They conspired together and stole all of his wealth.

commentsEnglish: {ngan pa lag 'brel byed} literally means 'an evil handed relationship'. {rkun ma} in example sentence two, is also spelled {rku ma}.

examples.english: If parents are able to properly discipline their children when young, when they become older they will not be spoiled. (The sense here is non-volitional.)
We should never indulge people who are bad.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound is similar to {skyag lang gtong} - see it's own entry for other example sentences.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: If you don't serve your parents well, bad karma will come back to you. The disaster they experienced is definitely the result of karmic retribution.

commentsEnglish: This literally means 'for bad/evil fruits or results to cycle back'.

englishGloss: to hold or bear a grudge.

examples.english: The bad custom of holding a grudge and taking revenge is still found in some places.
Whatever (you) do, holding a grudge will not be beneficial but will certainly cause great harm.

commentsEnglish: {'chang} is pronounced {bcangs} for all tenses with this verbalised compound.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. What were you crying about? B. I'm sad.
A. When you watched the sad movie did you cry? B. I didn't, but my younger sister really wept.
That girl cries unpredictably. (i.e., there is no standard measure for predicting when that girl will cry.') Don't cry.
Tsering fought with his parents by whining. When a wolf wails, it is certainly not a good sign.
By the look of the way he is wailing, he probably got angry.

commentsEnglish: {ngu skad rgyag} and {ngu skad 'don} both communicate the same meaning, though the latter is less frequent.

englishGloss: to cry, to burst into tears.

examples.english: (I) cry when (I) see those poor beggars.
If you look at the way some people in contemporary society behave, it really makes you burst into tears.
He is not a deceitful person. He doesn't deceive, but speaks directly!
I haven't been deceitful at all with this work.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I recognise her, but can't clearly remember who she is.
A. Do you recognise my voice? B. Oh! Of course (I do). It's hard to recognise the quality of things nowadays. (lit. 'to recognise which things are good or bad.')

commentsEnglish: {ngo chod} is used in the situation when someone is trying to remember the name of a person he or she has just recognised.

examples.english: When needing to accomplish something for themselves, some people really brown-nose. Why should one like praise from others?
Some people really flatter leaders for their own benefit.

commentsEnglish: {sprel lad khrab}, which is more frequent in Lhasa dialect, conveys the same meaning as {ngo bstod byed}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I will introduce you to her. I will briefly acquaint you with some aspects of Lhasa.
That foreigner gave us a clear introduction to his history.
I will recommend a good teacher to you.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He was exposed as a fake by all the people and consequently was ashamed of himself. To be honest, I did not do anything embarrassing. ({gang yang} is pronounced {ga ga'i}.)
That girl was so embarrassed that she fled. I was very ashamed of him. (Note that the verb {'tsher} is used here. It means, 'to be shy, emabarrassed or ashamed.')
There is no need to be shy. We are all close friends. (Note that the hon. {thugs 'tsher} means 'to be shy.' This expression is also used to mean 'make yourself at home' or 'help yourself.')

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Some scoundrels betray their own country by rebelling.
They will never revolt against the government.

englishGloss: to know, to be acquainted with.

examples.english: A. Do you know that driver? B. I don't. I don't know any drivers at all. ({mkhan} is usually pronounced {nyan} though with {mo Ta gtong} it is sometimes pronounced {mkhan}.)
A. Which country is that girl you know from? B. She is an Indian girl. I haven't known her for very long.
I have seen her before, but we don't know each other.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to make too much out of help you've given.
to go on about something you've done.

examples.english: He is going on a lot about the help he gave me. He is going on and on about how he lent me some money the other day.
He's an expert at telling people how much he's done for them.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to show off, to be ostentatious.
to use someone's name for one's own gain.

examples.english: Moral character is truly the nectar of the humble. ({yon tan} means 'good quality' and is often translated as 'wisdom'.) He is using the fact that his parents are leaders and bullying us.
Previously, you really showed off your abilities didn't you? So therefore, the leader doesn't like you.
There is no need to show off things to others.
Monkeys only have their bottoms to show off. (This is a proverb about showing off more than what you have.)

commentsTibetan: མཛེས་པ་ངོམ། དབང་ཆ་ངོམ། ངས་ཁོང་ལ་ཅ་ལག་ངོམ་པ་ཡིན། ངོམ་བཟོ་རྒྱག ངོམ་བཟོ་བྱེད། ངོམ་བཟོ་སྐུལ། ངོམ་སོ་རྒྱག

englishGloss: to boast, to brag, to show off.

examples.english: He bought a new car and is really showing it off to us. That girl put on her ring and really showed it off. ({tshigs gog} is also spelled {tshigs khebs}.)
It is not appropriate to flaunt one's riches if those riches are miniscule. What's a goat doing showing off sheep manure? (This proverbial saying means 'don't show off what's not yours.')

commentsEnglish: Though somewhat less common, this entry can also be verbalised with {byed}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be satisfied, satiated or quenched.

examples.english: A. Has your thirst been quenched? B. Completely. A. Would cold water quench your thirst? B. Sure. No worries.
My thirst hasn't been satisfied. I'm still going to drink a little more.
I regard you as a good person. That boy has been identified as a reincarnate lama.
That person said that he is able to identify all his things which (he) lost.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to confess, to admit, to own up to.

examples.english: He admitted his work mistake to the leader. While I was teaching a lesson, a student owned up to breaking the window.
I wonder who broke this bowl? No one has owned up to it. (Note that {dkar yol} means 'porcelain' but can refer to any kind of plate, bowl or cup.)
When they make a mistake, good children own up to it.

commentsEnglish: {ngos len byed} does not necessarily indicate a feeling of regret. The speaker has simply owned up to the wrongful action.

englishGloss: to be nervous or anxious, to become panicked.
to become frightened, afraid or scared.

examples.english: If (I) don't get to school on time, I become very panicky. If you try to cross the river and don't know how to swim, you'll panic.
When he sees a scary person, he immediately becomes frightened. I was really frightened by (my) dream last night.
A. Are you anxious? B. No, I'm not.

commentsEnglish: {dnangs skrag lang} and {dnangs skrag skye} seem to be used interchangeably.

examples.english: A. Since I am going to Tibet, is there anything (you) would like me to get for (you)? B. If it is convenient, please buy a thangkha. ({thang ga} is also spelled {thang ka} and {thang kha}.)
A. What did you ask him to get you? B. I asked him to buy a camera.
He asked me to get a book for him. I ordered that dictionary from India. (i.e., I sent an order to India for that dictionary.)
This car has already been reserved by someone else.
A. Did you order food from the restaurant? B. (I) have already ordered.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to prophecy, to predict the future.

examples.english: How could an ordinary person possibly predict the future? Lama Marpa passed on many prophecies to the Great Milarepa. (Mila is short for {mi la re pa}. Marpa was Mila's teacher.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to cut crops, grass or plants.

examples.english: We are going to harvest crops. ({bstas ma} means 'crops that are ripe and ready for harvest'.) In our area, grass is cut and put out to dry.
Once (you) have finished harvesting, are you immediately going to thresh the (grain)?

englishGloss: to put on a threatening expression.

examples.english: Even if you put on a threatening expression, we aren't afraid.
They bared their fangs and intimidated us like children.
Immediately after taking that medicine, (I) sweated a lot.
It's extremely hot these days and (I) am perspiring profusely.

englishGloss: to fry, to roast, to parch.

examples.english: To be honest, I don't have the slightest idea how to cook vegetables. Please fry this meat a little.
A. How do farmers roast grain? ({yos} is popped or roasted grain, usually barley or wheat.) B. (They) roast it in hot sand.
Han Chinese are very good at frying vegetables.

commentsEnglish: The present and future tenses are also spelled {rnod} and {brnod}, but these variant spellings seem to be less prevalent.

englishGloss: to lend or give in advance.
to give with the understanding of being repaid.

examples.english: A. I didn't bring any money. Could you please lend me some? B. Sorry, I didn't bring any money either. ({nga yang} is pronounced {nga'i}.)
I will advance you some money.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: They are digging for minerals on the mountain. Small children shouldn't pick their ears a lot.
He is always digging into what I say. (This sentence conveys the idea that he is trying to read into what I say.)

englishGloss: to excavate, to mine, to extract.

examples.english: He did the work of extracting minerals for many years.
If you gather more experience in practical activities of the outside world, it is beneficial when you need to reach inward for your own strength.
The customs office really searched through my bag. ({'gag sgo} is often pronounced {'gang sgo}.) They searched the inside of my house and left.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to take care of, to look after.

examples.english: Take good care of those books I gave you. If (you) don't look after your body, (you'll) get sick.
(I) have heard that there are likely many thieves around here, so (you) need to look after (your) money carefully.
The work will go much easier, if we can approach it with the same mindset.
It is impossible for all religious doctrines to be synthesised into one.
If the nation can unite as one, it will become very powerful. ({khong bu} means 'entity' or 'mass'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He always talks to himself. He appears to be crazy! He always talks to himself.

commentsEnglish: Note that one can never say {ngas gcig lab brgyab pa yin} but rather {ngas gcig lab brgyab shag} or {ngas gcig lab brgyab song}, if the speaker is aware that they have been talking to themselves.

examples.english: I'm going to urinate. The dog urinated on the carpet.
Our grandmother really takes great loving care of (her) flowers. I always take loving care of my children, but also give (them) firm discipline.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: No matter who the parent, of course they cherish their own children.
Australia greatly treasures wild animals and natural environments.

commentsTibetan: མཐོང་བྱེད། མཐོང་ཆེན་བྱེད། སྣང་བྱེད། སྣང་ཆེན་བྱེད། རྩ་ཆེན་བྱེད། དགའ་པོ་བྱེད།

examples.english: He is a child whose mother has probably spoiled him. That child is completely spoiled. (In this example the intransitive, non-volitional verbaliser {shor} has been used.)
Since Dawa was spoiled as a child, he doesn't obey anyone now.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to lower, to reduce, to deduct.

examples.english: Tashi threw a rock and broke that person's leg. (lit. 'Tashi broke his leg', but this is ambiguous in English.) Children always break windows by throwing stones.
In keeping with the King's command, Master Tumi went to India and created the Tibetan written language. (lit. 'Master Tumi didn't break the King's command'. {thu mi} is also spelled {thon mi}.)

If (your) parent's instructions are not obeyed, there will be consequences. (i.e., your karma will catch up with you.) One needs to disregard one's own pride and to learn much from knowledgeable people.
A. Is there a price reduction on this item? B. No, there isn't. A. If you don't reduce it, then I can't buy it.
Go outside or I'll break your leg! (This is often said to children when parents are angry with them.)

commentsEnglish: The above sentence in Related Words and Expressions can be translated as 'Because that person didn't come on time, my work was completely hindered.' {gcog} is pronounced {bcag} for all tenses.

examples.english: Yesterday, I chopped down many tree branches. To enjoy killing is an awful state of mind.
After my friend counselled me, I stopped (drinking) alcohol. What a pity it is for those children whose parents abandon them. ({'dra} here is pronounced {ra}.)

commentsEnglish: {gcod} is pronounced {bcad} for all tenses.

englishGloss: to be released from a duty or obligation.

examples.english: A. When will I ever get the time to go out with all these domestic duties I have? B. And today? A. My daughter has come home and released me from that.
If old ideas are not able to be liberated, society will not be able to be improved. (This is a common slogan.)
From today, I have been set free. (Note that the verbaliser is the benefactive, non-volitional verb {thob}.)
The combing of wool is very difficult work. Yesterday, I was helping my older sister comb wool.
The first thing to do when weaving a carpet is to comb the wool.

commentsEnglish: {bal shad rgyag} is interchangeable with {lcags shad rgyag}.

examples.english: That cow licked my head.
It appears that the small child finds the yoghurt to be very delicious. She's even licking the bowl!
Even though he says whatever he wants when he's with us, when he's in front of others he gets tongue-tied.
If you become tongue-tied when you arrive at the place you're making a speech, (you) will definitely lose out.
She is someone that everyone can place their trust in.
If (you) lie once or twice, people won't trust you.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to equalize, to even out, to average.

examples.english: A. On average, how much money does each person get? B. Probably a little more than 300 yuan.
A. On average, how much is your salary per month? B. I suppose around two thousand on average.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to get reduced (i.e., the price of something.)

examples.english: Oh no! I've broken their thermos. When playing soccer, there is a risk of breaking a leg.
This month, I completely missed out on my daily prayers. ({kha 'don} are prayers, chants or recitations.) I missed the lesson the other day.

She broke the cup just now. (Note that the subject is in the ergative even though {chag} is a non-volitional verb.) The beam broke from the strong gust of wind. ({gdung ma} are beams or girders that support a roof.)

commentsEnglish: Note that although this verb is intransitive and non-volitional, the ergative is used in certain situations. For example, {ngas ja dam chag song} 'I have broken the thermos.' The ergative is used by the speaker to emphasise the fact that 'I was the one who broke it', (but I broke it accidentally)'.

examples.english: Probably since I walked a lot yesterday, I'm really sore today.
Last night, I coughed a lot so today my lungs ache. My stomach aches from laughing so hard.
If you don't have a rest, you will get sore muscles.

englishGloss: to cause a disaster, harm or calamity.

examples.english: Oh no, he has caused a disaster. I've heard that (he) gambled away all the government's money.
A tragedy could occur unless the car is driven slowly. It is not OK if you cause harm (to us).
They caused a big calamity.

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense of {bslangs} is {slong}, but this is rarely used when combined with {chag sgo}. {chag sgo} is also spelled {chags sgo}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to become attached to someone or something.

examples.english: That child has really grown up. If (you) don't drink the tea, it will get cold.
What will become of the people in this poor place? My heart is completely attached to that girl.

commentsEnglish: {chags} also has the meaning 'to be situated or located'.

examples.english: A. Do you have a hangover today? B. I haven't.

Because I drank lots of barley beer last night, today I have a hangover. If (you) have a hangover, drinking chang will cure it. (This expression can be shortened to the proverbial saying {chang nad chang gis sangs}.)
A. Are you married? B. I'm not married. (lit. 'I am still to get married.')
Last year, my younger sibling got married.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The doctor examined (my) urine specimen. Even the examination of urine is important in Tibetan medicine.

commentsEnglish: Regarding example one, {am chi} is a relatively new word and is very commonly said in Lhasa dialect. {am chi} is also spelled {em chi} and {em je}. {sman pa} is the literary term.

examples.english: The sky has become cloudy and it is about to rain. If there is a lot of rain in summer, farmers greatly benefit.
The strong rainfall last night washed out the road.
Immediatley after lightning, there's no worry of rain. (This proverbial saying refers to someone who is all talk and no action.)

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: There was a rainstorm last night and water came in the windows. Even though I took an umbrella, the rain and wind were so strong that all (my) clothes got wet.
Because there are rainstorms every year, all the wooden window lattices have cracked.

commentsEnglish: This entry is a combination of the nouns {char pa} and {lhags pa} - rain and wind.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to make a treaty or agreement.
to bind, bundle, or bandage up.

examples.english: A business agreement was made between us and that seller. The custom of making mutual treaties between nations has existed from antiquity to the present day.
He is carrying many bundled up packages of incense to sell.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Who watered the flowers? B. She did.
A new tree really must be watered.

commentsEnglish: {chu rgyag} refers to watering plants or small areas of grass. {chu gtong} refers to irrigating large areas such as fields.

examples.english: I did a little bit of digging with a spade and got a blister on my hand. If (you) get a blister on (your) foot, what is the (best) way to deal with it?
Because I walked for the whole day yesterday, the soles of my feet have got many blisters.
Since many viaducts have been made for directing water, it has become much easier to irrigate the fields.
The places that previously needed to wait for rain, now have their fields irrigated by a sprinkler system.
It is time to irrigate the fields.

commentsEnglish: {chu gtong} refers to irrigating large areas such as fields, whereas {chu rgyag} refers to watering plants or small areas of grass.

englishGloss: to build a damn or dike.

examples.english: Before water bursts, a damn should be built. On either side of the Kyichu river some long dikes have been built.
The laundry needs to be rinsed clean after washing it. ({'khra 'khru} is pronounced {khrang 'khru}.) The colour of the clothes will fade if the soap isn't rinsed out well.
If plates are washed after the left over food has been rinsed off, they will get cleaner.
A. Will these things fit into the car? B. They probably will.
These things will not fit inside this bag. I think this dirt will fit in one vehicle.

commentsEnglish: {chud} is also spelled {chur}. The use of {chud} to mean 'to comprehend or understand' is more frequent in literary Tibetan. An example of this literary usage of {chud} appears in the Related Words and Expressions; {don 'di khong du chud} - 'He understood the meaning.'

examples.english: A. Is smoking permitted here? B. It's absolutely forbidden to smoke here.
A. Are you allowed to go to abroad? B. If I get a permit, I can certainly go.
Don't you know that you aren't allowed to yell in a hospital?

commentsEnglish: {chog} doesn't function as a verb by itself, rather it functions in combination with another verb. In Lhasa dialect, {chog} can indicate a promise to do something. For example, {ngas sprad chog} - 'I will give it'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be allowed to do something.

examples.english: A. Have you obtained permission to work in Tibet? B. Not yet. But I think it will come soon.
If I get the government's permission, I will go abroad straight away.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Did you receive permission to take a vacation rest? B. I haven't received permission as of now.
The higher authorities are possibly intending to give him permission to go abroad.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to ask for approval or permission.

examples.english: I went to the leader to ask for permission, but I didn't get it. I need to go and request permission from the leader.
No matter how many times I ask for approval for this work, up until now, I still haven't gotten it.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to participate in a philosophical debate.

examples.english: Many people came to seek an audience where the monks were participating in a philosophical debate.
Monks engage in philosophical debate by slapping their hands together. (Note:the verbaliser {btang} is used instead of {bkyon}.)
Some people are able to jump more than eight metres (long). He jumped from the second floor.
American basketball players jump very high and can dunk the ball right into the basket! (lit. 'into the net'.)
Tomorrow, a few of us soldiers will take parachutes and jump from an airplane. Perhaps you will see (us) on television!

commentsTibetan: རྒྱང་མཆོངས། མཐོ་མཆོངས། མདུན་མཆོང་རྒྱག མཆོང་རྒྱག་རྒྱག ཐག་མཆོང་རྒྱག འགྲོ་མཆོང་རྒྱག འགྲོས་རྒྱག

examples.english: When reading, don't skip over (anything), but rather read each word with proper pronunciation.
That crazy person is leaping (all over) the road.
That student missed grade two and skipped straight to grade three.

commentsTibetan: མཆོང་རྒྱག མཆོང་། མདུན་མཆོང་རྒྱག མདུན་མཆོང་རྒྱག ཐག་མཆོང་རྒྱག འགྲོ་མཆོང་རྒྱག འགྲོས་རྒྱག རྒྱང་མཆོངས། མཐོ་མཆོངས། ཁོས་གླ་བའི་མཆོང་ཀ་རྒྱག་གིས།

englishGloss: to add butter or fat to a butter lamp as an offering.

examples.english: Today, they went and added butter to butter lamps at Sera, Drepung and Ganden monastery.
The elderly women poured fat into a butter lamp in front of a sacred image.

commentsEnglish: {mchod thigs rgyag} is done by adding drips of melted butter into a butter lamp.

examples.english: He has the habit of touching everything when he goes to the market. Look, (he) is touching those things.
Please don't touch my cup. That dog barked all night. (Note that this use of {'chang} is unique to Lhasa dialect and is intransitive.)
The soldiers are holding the guns in (their) hands and are ready to depart. Please don't touch things recklessly.

If you put a beggar's dog on the roof, it will bark at the stars. (This proverb means, 'putting low people in high places won't work because such people will still whine and complain.' {sprang khyi} is pronounced {spang kyi} and also refers to stray dogs)

englishGloss: to be cut off, to be broken off.
to be short of, to run out off.

examples.english: Last night, the wind blew very hard and even broke the electricity lines. Perhaps my friend has run out of money for his expenses.
What happened? The phone was suddenly cut off. I was completely exhausted yesterday, when I was climbing the mountain.
I reckon the rain will stop quickly. A. Have you run out of cigarettes? B. Yes, I'm out.
There are many letters missing from this new book.
Some Tibetan customs are being lost.

commentsEnglish: This verb is commonly written {chad} for all tenses.

examples.english: A. I've got a cold. B. If you've got a cold, go to the hospital.
Our teacher probably has a cold today. (She) is sneezing a lot.
That previous situation keeps coming back to my mind. As the sun rises, the lotus flower opens.
Tonight, the moon is really bright and even the stars are glittering. (lit. 'the moon has risen well'.)
Since the new government policy came out, many good opportunities to study have emerged.
I don't get up until the sun rises. During the Tibetan bathing festival, we always go swimming.
As the moon of the 15th day arose, so did memories of my dear beloved. (This verse was written by the sixth Dalai Lama.)

commentsTibetan: ཉི་མ་སྐྱེལ། ཉི་མ་ནུབ། འཇའ་ཟུག འཇའ་ཡལ། ཉི་མ་ཤར། འཇའ་ཤར། ཟླ་དཀར་ཤར། སྐར་མ་ཤར། ཆུ་ལྒང་ཤར།

examples.english: The leader designed a very big project.
From now on, I will be designing the projects that need to be completed for next year.

After that person died, we have had no one saying troublesome things to us anymore. (This sentence means that the person was very troublesome when alive.) I'm dead tired. (lit. 'I'm so tired I died'.)
This winter some of my plants died. Because I was not able to get there on time, my plane ticket was wasted. (Note that {shi}, in this context, means to be wasted or expired.)
A. When did he pass away? B. He passed away last year.

commentsTibetan: སྲོག་ལ་བབས། སློག་ཤི། སྐུ་ཚེ་ལས་འདས། དགོངས་པ་རྫོགས། སྐུ་ཞིང་ལ་ཕེབས། སྐུ་མྱ་ངན་ལས་འདས། སྐུ་གྲོངས། སྐུ་ཞིང་ལ་གཤེགས། ཉལ་ཁར་ཆུ་མ་མང་། འཆི་ཁར་གཏམ་མ་མང་།

examples.english: That girl over there is wearing a bright apron. I tied my child's belt.
Most farmers wear leather belts. He tied (his) laces tightly. (Note that {lham sgrog} are the long ties on traditional Tibetan boots worn by farmers. {'jur sgrog} are shoe laces.)
He tied the donkey's front legs with rope. ({bong bu} is pronounced {bong gu}.)
A. Did you sprain (your) leg playing football? B. No. I lifted a big rock and so sprained (my) lower back.
A. Oh, your eyes are swollen. What happened? (hyper-corrective.) B. Today, I am not so well, so my eyes are probably swollen.

commentsEnglish: In example two, speaker A could also say {ga re gnang song} without the interrogative particle {ngas}. It has been marked 'hyper-corrective' because it has both the interrogative pronoun {ga re} and the question particle {ngas}. See 'hyper-corrective' in the glossary for further discussion.

examples.english: Each month, I deposit 100 yuan into the bank. I have money to deposit, so please give me a blank form. (i.e., a blank deposit form.)
This year, I will deposit this money and withdraw it next year.
A. Is it OK if I entrust my bike to you? (i.e., Is it OK if you look after my bike?) B. Sure. You can certainly put it here.
I am from Africa. I am seeking refuge in your country.
I have placed my hope in you. (lit. 'to you I have entrusted my hopes'. This is often said between boy/girl friend).

commentsEnglish: The difference between {nyar ba} and {bcol ba} is that {nyar ba} means 'to mind, look after or keep something,' whereas {bcol ba} means 'to entrust something with someone'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to correct, to repair, to renovate.

examples.english: The people's hospital treated his illness well.
The teacher corrected my essay. If that person is taking drugs, it is difficult to treat (him).

commentsEnglish: This verb is similar to the more colloquial verbalised compound {bzo bcos rgyag}.

examples.english: Some people mugged us and got away with all our things. It is said that there are many bandits in the northern grasslands.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to meedle in other people's business.
to intercede on behalf of someone else.

examples.english: Don't interfere in this matter. By the look of it, it's not any easy situation.
It is better to look in your own tsampa bag, then to only interfere in the affairs of others. (lit. ..'interfere in your own tsampa bag'.)
When a crane is going north, a pig has no cause to interfere. (This proverb means 'mind your own business.')

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: She is someone who is good at cutting carpet with scissors. It's unlikely this leather can be cut using scissors.
That robber cut and stole the otter skin sleeve of my chuba. ({sram} is pronounced {gram}.)

englishGloss: to give or grant an audience.

examples.english: Today, the Panchen Lama is granting an audience to the public.
A. When will the lama grant an audience? B. Beats me. Perhaps tomorrow.

englishGloss: to seek or request an audience with a religious figure.

examples.english: Many people are going for an audience with the lama today.
A. Were you able to have an audience with the rinpoche? B. I haven't been able to as of now.
We still haven't completed our work. As soon as I have concluded (my) studies, I will return to my homeland.

englishGloss: to measure weight, length, height, width or depth.

examples.english: A. Please measure the length of this material. B. I have measured it. It is one metre in length. ({kung khre} is a Chinese loan word.)
These days, I'm repaying a loan. Don't take barley beer and give water back in return. (This proverbial saying means 'return a favour in kind'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to demolish, to tear, to pull down.

examples.english: The many monasteries that were destroyed during the Cultural Revolution are now being rebuilt.
The tall buildings around the Lhasa's Jokhang temple are being dismantled.
I need to dismantle my old bike and clean it. Please untie the belt of my chuba.

commentsTibetan: སྐེ་རགས་བཤིག ཕྱུ་པ་བཤིག ལྷད་མ་བཤིག བསྟན་པ་བཤིག ཁྲིམས་བཤིག འཇུར་སྒྲོག་བཤིག ཐབ་ཆུ་བཤིག གྲ་པ་རྫུན་མ་དེ་ཚོ་ངས་བལྟས་ན་བསྟན་པ་བཤིག་མཁན་རེད། ལུག རླུག ཁ་བཤིག ལྷུ་བཤིག
commentsEnglish: There are two separate verbs which both have the present tense form {'jig}. One is transitive and the other is instransitive. They have been listed separately. An alternative spelling for the past tense of this verb is {bshigs}, and an alternative spelling of the imperative form is {shigs}.

englishGloss: to come to ruin, to fall to pieces.
to decay, to perish, to detoriate.

examples.english: The walls detoriated causing the house to fall down. Eventual destruction is the intrinsic nature of all living things.
Once, during the reign of king Lang Tarma, Buddhism was destroyed. ({zhig} is pronounced {'jig} in this sentence.)

commentsEnglish: There are two separate verbs which both have the present tense form {'jig}. One is transitive and the other is instransitive. They have been listed separately.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: After finishing eating, suck on the spoon. That child likes sucking his thumb.
This medicine needs to be sucked. (lit. 'sucked in the mouth'.)
My stomach must be sick. I can't digest (my) food. If too much food is eaten, it won't be digested.
If the fruits of another person's labour are eaten, those fruits won't be digested. (This phrase is a warning against taking credit for something you didn't do.)

englishGloss: to put in to, to insert.
to let, to allow, to permit.
to force someone to do something.

examples.english: I make my children go to bed early. Last year, three University graduates were placed into our work unit. I sent my daughter to school.

He usually gives me the chance to speak Tibetan. The teacher let me speak English. (Note that this sentence can also mean, 'The teacher made me speak English.' {du} is often said {ru} using this sentence pattern.)
That policeman caught a thief and put him in prison. ({zin} is often pronounced {zim}.) That child always puts her finger in her mouth. ({mthe bong} is pronounced {mthe po}).

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: You definitely must participate in this meeting. China has joined the World Trade Organisation in earnest.
A. Did you participate in the Tibetan Department's soccer match yesterday? B. No, what happened?
Before participating in the sports competition, (we) must train very hard.

commentsEnglish: For this verb {zhugs} is most commonly used for all tenses. Note that the present tense of this verb is the same as another verb meaning 'to insert', 'to put into'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Children need to be disciplined when they are young. I think it is important to be self-disciplined. (lit. 'to discipline oneself'.)
She does not discipline her children very much. Therefore they have become unruly. Discipline (your) children well.
Mongolians are experts at training horses.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Daughter? B. Yes. A. (You) haven't tied your shoe laces and they are undone. B. OK.
The elderly man kindly tied my shoe laces for me. Mister, you need to tie up your shoe laces.

commentsEnglish: The use of the honorific form {zhabs sgrog bskyon} is rare. {lham sgrog rgyag} refers to tying up laces on the traditional Tibetan boots worn by farmers.

englishGloss: to leave, to put, to place, to put down.
to put an end to, to cease, to halt, to stop.

examples.english: A. Where's the best place to put the flower? B. Isn't it better to put it next to the window?
A. Who put the phone down just now? (hyper-corrective. See comments below.) B. I did.
Please keep in mind what I asked (you). We will end today's lesson here.

commentsTibetan: མཚམས་བཞག ཁ་ཆེམས་བཞག དམ་བཅའ་བཞག སེམས་རྟེན་བཞག བྱས་རྗེས་འཇོག གན་རྒྱ་འཇོག གཏའ་མ་འཇོག
commentsEnglish: The present tense tense of this verb {'jog} is rarely said in Lhasa dialect, rather {bzhag} is used for all tenses. In example two, speaker A could also say {da gin kha par sus bzhag song} without the interrogative particle {ngas}. This sentence has been marked 'hyper-corrective', because it has both the interrogative pronoun {sus} and the question particle {ngas}. See 'hyper-corrective' in the glossary for further discussion.

examples.english: A. Do you have some change? B. Yes. How much do you want to change?
This coat did not suit me, so I exchanged it.
I may not be able to follow behind scholars, but I'm not going to be left behind with the fools.
No matter how powerful a bird's wings are, there's no way it can chase an airplane.

commentsEnglish: This entry is not common in the spoken register.

englishGloss: to chase, to pursue, to follow after.

examples.english: The brazen thief fled and the police chased (after him).
As soon as work was finished, Wangmo raced home as if someone was chasing her.

commentsEnglish: This entry is not common in the spoken register.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to follow, to adhere to, to believe in.

examples.english: He adhered closely to Buddhism. We must follow our ancestors and protect (our) culture. (This statement is a motivational directive.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is not common in the spoken register.

examples.english: Listen well students. I will read each word and you repeat after me.
When a lama teaches students, there is much they need to repeat. ({slob ma} can also mean 'disciple'.)

commentsEnglish: This verb is not very commonly said except in the two situations noted in the example sentences.

englishGloss: to follow a trail, to track, to trace.

examples.english: If you want to follow in the footsteps of your ancestors, you should strive to understand (their) culture.
By examining footprints, hunters are able to track wild animals.

commentsEnglish: This entry is not common in the spoken register.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Through study, I followed in the ways of my ancestors. That boy was able to inherit his parent's work.
Lobsang Trakba, the Victorious, has many followers.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to follow, adhere or believe in.
to lead or cause one to follow.

examples.english: Milarepa was a great saint who followed in the tradition of Marpa, the great translator.
Tsong Khaba led countless disciples.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Those two swopped cars. My coat is too small. I am going to exchange it.
Because this house was too small, (we) changed it (for another one).

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Since I'm getting up there in age, (I) tend to forget everything. I completely forgot what you said the other day.
This matter is very important (to me). Please dont forget it.
The students don't listen to the teacher's instructions.
When listening to the news, we heard that Australia had a suffered a bushfire. (lit. 'that fire damage had occurred'...)
Everyone, please listen carefully! (i.e., 'prick up your ears and listen', or 'listen with your ears up straight'.)

commentsEnglish: This verb is most commonly written {nyan} for all tenses.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: (We) should heed what (our) elders say.
No matter how much you gripe, if you don't listen, you're just like a jackass. (lit. 'no matter how much you say..'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to listen in secret, to bug.

examples.english: Though that person tried to obtain some secret information by eavesdropping, we didn't say anything and so he could do nothing (but) return (home).
Listening in secret by people's windows isn't good. Don't eavesdrop on people!

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to test the reaction of someone.

examples.english: I tested him to see what he might do. (i.e., to see whether he would make a mistake or not.) He is fishing to see her reaction. (i.e., to see if she will make a mistake or not.)
He really likes to test out (the reaction of) other people. It's not that he doesn't know; perhaps he is just testing me.

commentsEnglish: This verb has the meaning of testing out someone to see whether he or she will make a mistake or do something wrong.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to investigate, to examine, to test.
to find out about, to look out for.

examples.english: I need to buy a computer. When you go to the market, please find out about it.
That leader himself went to investigate the lives of the poor families.
I researched Tibetan culture for many years.

englishGloss: to find out about something before doing it.

examples.english: It is good if one is able to practice religion and not just hear it. (The use of {thos pa tsam du} reflects literary Tibetan.) There are many things to experience in life.
At this time, I need to write a research paper about doctors. So it is important to relate to their lives. (i.e., to find out about their lives.)
If you just utter empty words of Buddhism you will not become enlightened, but you will be an expert if you practice the real meaning of Buddhism. (This proverb means, 'practice what you preach.')

commentsEnglish: The word {am chi} in example two, is a relatively new word and is common in Lhasa dialect. {am chi} is also spelled {em chi} and {em je}. {sman pa} is the literary term.

englishGloss: to restore, to repair, to renovate.

examples.english: Various Tibetan monasteries are currently being restored. (Note that {dgon sde} is more commonly said as {dgon pa}.) That monastery has been restored well.
Unless this sacred image is restored, it will become completely ruined.

englishGloss: to take care of, to mind, to look after.

examples.english: Please look after my bicycle. After a short time I will come to pick it up.
I have kept this new book especially for you. Otherwise, it will sell out quickly because there are too many buyers. He looked after my book.
Could you please hold this dictionary (for me). Tomorrow, I will bring money to buy it.
Grandma, please take care of yourself. (lit. 'take care of your body'.)
Please look after this small child for a short time.
A. Are you going to lie down now? B. Yes. A. Has he got up? B. He is sleeping. (Note that {bzhengs} is pronounced {bzhangs}.)
Are you lying down at the moment? I'm not.
Sleep well. The teacher is sleeping.
Oh, it's time for the children to go to bed.

englishGloss: to put up an umbrella or sun shade.

examples.english: Unless we put up an umbrella, we won't be able to stand the heat. Please put up an umbrella for the children.

englishGloss: to ride double on a bike, motorbike or a horse.
to give someone a dinky (Aus. English.)

examples.english: In (Lhasa) city, it is forbidden to ride tandem on a bicycle.
It's sad when a horse has two people riding it.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The mother got very angry and smacked the small child. My father really beat me.
Today, in the religious debating area, the teacher hit a student. (Note that {slob ma} can also be translated 'disciple' and {slon dpon} as 'master.')

commentsEnglish: The verb {gzhu} is more common than {nyes} to mean 'hit, smack or beat'. The intransitive, non-volitional sense of {nyes} is 'to be faulty' or 'to be wrong'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: (You) will be fined immediately if (you) drive incorrectly in the city.
The tax department fined him about 100 yuan. ({sgor mo} here means RMB.) I have never been fined even once in (my) life.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: These days, it is forbidden to torture prisoners. Beating children is not a good method (of teaching them). (The sense here is of always beating them.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: If evil acts are committed, the court will meet out punishment.
The traffic controller fined that driver.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I have never be indicted by the law. If a car is driven that fast, one will get fined. (Note that the use of {gzed} as the verbaliser is common in this context.)
If (you) drive a car without a license, (you) will get punished. Monks will get punished if they drink chang. ({chang} is brewed beer usually made from barley.)

commentsEnglish: {nyes pa gzed} and {nyes pa phog} are used interchangeably with no change in meaning.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to commit a crime or offence.
to accumulate demerit or bad karma.

examples.english: According to Buddhism, the taking of life is considered a very non-virtuous deed. (i.e., killing accumulates much demerit which adversely affects one's movement within samsara.)
We will not release those who commit crimes.

commentsEnglish: This entry is used in both a legal and religious sense. It is a crime or offense against secular laws of the state and is also 'demerit' causing bad karma.

examples.english: A. Would you like to buy a coat? B. No. I was thinking I should purchase a bag.
I have bought a book for you.
You have caused your own suffering by bringing on this sham of a lawsuit. (lit. 'bought this bad thing'.)

commentsEnglish: The verb {blu} is typically used when buying a religious or sacred item. See {blu} for example sentences.

examples.english: If you are going shopping, please buy me a pen.
A. What did you shop for today? B. Today, I bought some vegetables and fish.
What's happened to that child? She's tired. If there is nothing to play with, I get very bored.
I am really frustrated with this current work. The sun is so hot that everyone is feeling lethargic.
I find that person very irritating. Why? (Note that {nyob} in this context means to find someone annoying, irritating or frustrating.)

commentsEnglish: {sgyid pa skyur} in the above Related Words and Expressions means 'to be fatigued or bored' and is used only in Shigatse dialect.

englishGloss: to get cramp in one's calf muscle.

examples.english: A. My body has become very weak. B. How do you know that? A. At night my calf muscles are always cramping.
I must have really worn myself out hiking up the mountain yesterday. I got severe cramp in my calves during the night.
People oppressing others is extraordinarily cruel.
The oppression of women still exists in some places. (lit. the situation of women being oppressed.)

commentsEnglish: This entry can also be verbalised with {byed}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Did you sleep well? B. I did. A. Did she sleep? B. She did not.
A. Is he asleep? B. He is not asleep.
A. Is he going to sleep (now)? B. Yes.
Yesterday, during the lesson he dozed off. Oh, I think I nodded off.
You are dozing off to sleep. I felt drowsy.
These days, my children are not sleeping well. I am going to go to sleep. Tomorrow, I have to get up early.
A. Did the children go to sleep? B. Yes. I really want to go to sleep.
A. Has grandfather gone to sleep? B. He has just gone to sleep now.

commentsEnglish: {mnal} can also be spelled {rnal}. There is a difference in meaning between {gnyid khug} and {gnyid shor}. Although both are non-volitional, {gnyid khug} means to fall asleep as the result of lying down in order to go to sleep, while {gnyid shor} is used when one falls asleep accidentally or over sleeps.

examples.english: Last night, you were laughing as you talked in your sleep. ({gad mo is pronounced {'gad mo}.)
A. Did I sleep talk last night? B. (You) did not.
A. Last night, I had a really nice dream. B. What did you dream? A. I dreamt that I was flying in the sky. ({'phur} is pronounced {'phir}.)
Sweet dreams! That's a total daydream! (i.e., what a ludicrous idea!)
We need to manage that business well.
The carpet factory, which was managed by (both) themselves and a foreign boss, became famous.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to crumple, wrinkle or scrunch up.

examples.english: The child completely crumpled up the money. If money is scrunched up, (they) won't sell things (in exchange for it.)
If (you) crease (your) clothes, the teacher will scold you.

commentsEnglish: This entry is often said about flowers.

englishGloss: to find, to discover, to get.

examples.english: That beggar found a nice ring on the road. I looked and looked and finally found the family.
It's really great if a new method of research is found.

englishGloss: to say troublesome or annoying things.

examples.english: He always says things that cause trouble. When he is drunk, he says very annoying things.
The boy is being annoying by saying he wants (us) to buy the toy. You have grown up and yet you are still saying annoying things to your parents?

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: That swine is preparing to take a lot of money from us on the false pretext of that small matter. ('swine' is an English colloquial expression for {mi ngan}.)
He really brought false accusations upon us.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to give a report or an account.

examples.english: We need to give a report to the leaders on our yearly teaching instruction.
I gave a report about this situation to the dean of our department.
We can't have this situation resolved without reporting it to the authorities.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: We were all envigorated by the recent event.
If people's resolve can be strengthened, then anything can be achieved.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to hate, to hold a grudge.

examples.english: That person drew on my car. Since he and I are not on friendly terms, perhaps he holds this against me.
Hating others is a bad state of mind.
You need to be persistent in the study of Tibetan. If (you) are not persistent how will (you) gain knowledge?
Persistent people can bore holes in rocks. Persevere in (your) studies.

englishGloss: to lean against, to rest against.

examples.english: A. If you are not comfortable please sit back against (the cushion). B. No problem, (I'm fine.)
If (you) always lean on your parents, how will (you) cope later on?

commentsEnglish: The first sentence of example one is a polite way of telling someone to relax or make themselves at ease.

englishGloss: to stretch out to reach for something.

examples.english: A. Were you are to reach the light bulb? B. No, I wasn't. A. Then climb on the chair and you will be able to reach it. ({'dzegs} is pronounced {'dzags}.)
A. Can you reach the light switch? B. I can't. (i.e., it is not something that is within my capability).

englishGloss: to put to sleep, to lay down.

examples.english: I'm going to put the baby down to sleep. If the child is sick, please put her to bed.
I put the drunk on the bed to sleep. Who brewed this delicious barley beer?
The hen seems to be hatching chicks. She is always lying on the eggs.
Hey, if you don't control yourself, they'll flatten you. (This is an idiomatic expression.)

commentsEnglish: The present tense and imperative forms of {snyol} are rarely used in Lhasa dialect.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: If a dog is teased a lot, it will bite. Those boys like teasing girls.
Don't tease me. I'm not really feeling happy today.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He verbally abuses his wife. ({zhe po cig} here indicates habitual action.) You older kids don't bully the younger children!.
He bullied me a great deal. If (you) mistreat the meek, you yourself will come to ruin.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Shall we play cards? B. I don't know how to play cards at all. You (go ahead and please play).
We played cards at the picnic yesterday.
A. Shall we swing together? (i.e., on a swing or swing set.) B. Yes, let's swing!
A. Swing for a little while and then come home. B. OK.

commentsEnglish: This verb is related to the sound a particular bird makes. The bird is a type of partridge that is smaller than a pigeon and larger than a sparrow. The sound of someone swinging resembles the call of this bird.

examples.english: I rang the bell on my bike many times, but that person didn't make any attempt to get out of the way. ({yin na'i} is pronounced {yin de'i} here.)
The bell to start class has rung.
Some people go along the main road banging small drums. The banging of small drums, is hard on the ears. (lit. 'hot ears.')
At school, children dance beating small drums.

englishGloss: to beep or honk a horn.

examples.english: I honked the horn over and over from the house gate, but no one came.
The car behind (us) is beeping it's horn a lot. Look, who is it?

commentsEnglish: Note that {la ba}, in Related Words and Expressions, is a Chinese loan word.

examples.english: Their travel to mainlaind China has been settled. Have you settled your travel arrangements?
It has been decided that this book will be translated into English.

commentsEnglish: {gtan 'khel} is also spelled {gtan khel}.

examples.english: If our company has reasonable results, it has been decided that the worker's wages will be increased.
It has been decided that the prisoner will be released after one year.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound usually refers to decisions which have been made by leaders. {gtan 'khel}, a commonly used compound, has essentially the same meaning.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to put down a deposit or make a pledge.

examples.english: If I don't put down the Japanese watch my mother gave me as a deposit, that person won't lend me any money. (Note that {ri pin} is a Chinese loan word.)
I put down my house permit as collateral and borrowed 50,000 RMB from the bank.

He gave up his own life and saved the life of that child. (This phrase would be said only in unusual circumstances - e.g., if a child was kidnapped and someone offered themselves in exchange for the release of the child.)

commentsEnglish: The present tense {'jog} is rarely used in Lhasa dialect, with the past root {bzhag} typically being used for all tenses.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Why do you hold a grudge against him? B. What are you saying? (i.e., what do you mean?) I don't hold a grudge.
If you have something to say, please be frank. It is pointless if we hold a grudge against each other.

englishGloss: to collapse or take something down.

examples.english: Today it will probably rain, (since) lots of mist is covering the tops of the mountains.
The way in which this kitchen was built is not good at all. When the wind blows in a particular direction, all the smoke stays inside.
If this old building is not taken down before it collapses, there is great danger to the safety of children who play in it.
Big businessmen run each other out of business at the most crucial moment. (lit. 'collapse each other' or 'make bankrupt.') The robber stole from that person. (i.e., the thief robbed him blind.)
Early this morning, those nomads took down their tents and left.

commentsEnglish: The first meaning of 'becoming overcast' refers to either clouds, fog, mist or smoke. The intransitive counterpart of this verb when meaning to become overcast is {'thibs} as in {nam 'thibs shag} - 'It's cloudy.' The second meaning of this verb, to intentionally take something down, is commonly used in both Lhasa and Shigatse dialects. The intransitive, non-volitional verb meaning 'to collapse', is {rdib}. See {rdib} for example sentences.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to cut in to small pieces.

examples.english: A. I've finished chopping the vegetables. Could you please chop the meat? B. OK, I'll chop it.
He is cutting (his) fingernails. I am cutting paper. ({shog bu} is pronounced {shu gu}.)
Nomads wrap butter with yak stomachs. If you wrap a child's head up, there is danger of (the child) being suffocated.

For the duration of winter, wrap those small apple trees in hay. That way they won't freeze. ({sog ma} is the husk or chaff remaining after grain has been threshed. The imperative {thums} is pronounced {gtums}.)
I sent some people to Shigatse. Since there is presently a severe epidemic in this area, they are not letting any people go there.
Please let me go in. (lit. 'from the gate..'. This phrase is said to a gatekeeper or someone in charge of a work unit or a building.) Will you sell this jacket for 5 yuan? (lit. 'allow this to go'.)
She sent many Tibetan things to her own hometown. ({pha yul} is literally 'fatherland'.) I sent a letter, but I haven't got a reply yet.

commentsEnglish: {gtong} is used primarily as a verbaliser. Note that the correct imperative form of is {thong}. However, we have written the imperative as {gtong} in keeping with the practice of Lhasa dialect. The imperative is also often said {btang}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: These days, most old houses of Lhasa are being demolished and new ones are being built.
Beating children without instructing them (first), is not good at all. Water should be scattered on the path to keep dust from rising.
Every morning, he sprinkles water on the flowers. The chicken scattered around a lot of grain.

commentsTibetan: ལྟ་བ་རྙིང་པ་གཏོར། རྒྱལ་ཁབ་གཏོར། དགྲ་བོ་གཏོར། འཕྲུག་འཁོར་གཏོར། ཁྲིམས་གཏོར་བ་ལ་སོགས། རྩི་གཏོར། ཕུད་གཏོར། གད་ཆུ་གཏོར། ཆུ་གཏོར། དྲི་མ་ཞིམ་པོ་གཏོར།
commentsEnglish: Note that the verbalised compound {chu gtor ba}, requires on object in the dative case. See examples two and three.

englishGloss: to hold a religious ceremony to ward off evil spirits.

examples.english: On the 29th day of the month, monasteries hold a religious ceremony to ward off evil spirits. Today, many people came to the place where they hold the ceremony for warding off evil spirits.
That child is destroying everything in the house.

These days, some people destroy cultural relics in the hope of being able to be rich. (This sentences means that some people sell precious things in order to to get rich. Thus, they are destroying the preciousness of the antique and it's rightful place in prosterity. Note that the use of {yod} reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.)

englishGloss: to be impartial, to treat equally.

examples.english: Mother treats her children, all of us, equally. A judge needs to be impartial to everyone when deciding a case.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Oh dear, he whipped this horse really hard.
A. Have you ever caned a person? B. I've never caned (anyone).

englishGloss: to manifest or display a sign or symbol.

examples.english: Doesn't his voluntary admission demonstrate his criminal offence?
If there is a rainbow and light rain on the day a child is born, it is regarded (by Tibetans) as an auspicious sign.

englishGloss: to have a sign manifest itself.

examples.english: The fact that more people are coming to our restaurant is a sign that our food has got better.
The fact that snow covered mountains have decreased in Tibet is a sign that the weather has really changed.
Today at Sera Monastery, monks are debating. Perhaps they're having a debate about the six perfections. (Note that {phar phyin} is an abbreviation of {phar rol du phyin pa}.)
A. Do you know how to debate? B. I know how to a little.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound means to debate in the traditional monastic way.

examples.english: Flatulating where there are guests is really rude.
If (you) fart too much where (you) think there are no people, (you) could be embarrassed when (you) actually find yourself amongst lots of people.

commentsEnglish: Both {dri ma gtong} and {rtug dri gtong} are commonly used.

examples.english: A. On whom do you depend for your livelihood? B. I depend on my husband for my livelihood.
We depend mainly on the support of the government for the successful completion of our projects.
The earth is dependent upon air.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I am wishing you a happy birthday. (Note that this is not traditionally said by Tibetans. Only in recent years have birthdays begun to be celebrated by some Tibetans in Lhasa.)
A. When will the two of you get married? I will come to celebrate it. B. As soon as the time has been decided, I will let you know.
We are planning to celebrate our third wedding anniversary. (This expression would typically be said by a foreigner and not a Tibetan. Note that {byed} is the verbaliser here.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: These days, many new teams of scientific researchers have arrived in Tibet.
It is not good to only search out the faults of others and not examine your own thoughts and behaviour.
When I investigated the village, their lives were not so poor. (i.e., not as poor as people had said. {de tsam} is pronounced here as {'di ka tsa}.)

A. Did (you) watch a movie last night? B. (I) watched a movie. A. What did (you) watch? B. I watched a movie called "By the Water Side Story." (This movie is based on a famous Chinese novel called "Outlaws of the Marsh".)
A. Do you want to go and watch a movie? ({ltad mo} can also be translated 'performance'.) B. (I) don't. (I'm) watching television.
A. Tomorrow, we will go on a religious visit. Please see if you can come or not. B. Yes. I'll look and see how things go.
I am reading a book. I read a book.
One of the important procedures in Tibetan medicine is the examing of urine.

commentsEnglish: Although {lta} primarily means 'to watch or look', it also is used to mean 'to read'. ({klog} also means 'to read' though this usually refers to reading aloud.) In Lhasa dialect, the first person ergative {ngas} is often simply said {nga}. {ngas} is more frequently used in past tense constructions (see example four) and when the speaker is seeking emphasis or clarification. See glossary for more details. In example three, {nga lta gin lta gin byed kyi yin} is commonly said when someone can't decide immediately or doesn't want to communicate a direct refusal.

englishGloss: to look after, to take care of.

examples.english: When I was sick, the work unit looked after me very well. Our organisation cares for the poor.

commentsEnglish: This entry is not common in the spoken register.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I'm going to see whether I know how to make this food or not. (lit. 'to try out'). I took a car for a test drive a car, but didn't buy it.
First, I 'm going to see whether that thing is good or not. To begin with, I will see what kind of child he is.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: When clothes become dry, (you) need to fold and pile them together. (You) shouldn't fold a carpet and then lay it (on the floor.)
My daughter folds paper everyday and makes really cool toys. ({shog bu} is pronounced {shug gu}).
If you can't control yourself, there is danger of dying. (lit. 'danger of getting folded up' - an idiom for dying.) Unless you refrain from drinking a lot of beer, you could die. (idiom.)
Please fold these clothes.

commentsTibetan: གཤོག་བུ། ཉལ་ཁྲི། རས། ལག་ཆ། ཡོ་ཆས། ཉལ་ཆས། ཀམ་པ་ལིང་ལ་སོགས་ལྟབ་རྩིག་རྒྱག ལྟེབ་བརྩེག་རྒྱག ལྟེབ་རྩེག་བཤིག
commentsEnglish: {ltab rtsig rgyag} is also spelled {ldeb brtseg rgyag}.

examples.english: Please unpack the tent. I will get the pegs ready.
If the chuba's sleeve is unfolded, it will make it a little bit longer.
It is common for many people to die of starvation during a large famine.
How terrible! That place has had a really bad famine and many children have starved to death.
My bird is starving. (Note that the bird is still alive.)

englishGloss: to get angry from being hungry.

examples.english: As that boy was coming home from school, he became angry through hunger. (lit. displayed his anger. {bstan} is the verbaliser here.) He easily gets angry from being hungry.
He bumped the cup and it rolled over. The car went too fast on the road to the airport and rolled over. (lit. 'airport road.')
It is slightly better if a ship rolls over than a plane. (This sentence means if a plane crashes there are likely to be few, if any, survivors, but if a ship sinks there could be less fatalities.)

commentsEnglish: {ltob kyog log} is also pronounced {ltab kyog log}.

examples.english: Those evil people took advantage of the opportunity and waged a surprise attack on us.
When he works, he always acts in harmony with his partner. (lit. 'in accordance with his partner'.)
I took advantage of a good opportunity and studied Tibetan.
A. Did you give him a book? B. I didn't. Drolma gave it to him.
A. Who gave him the money? B. His Uncle gave it to him.
A. Who gave you the snacks? (Note that {rngan pa} also means 'gifts' or ' tips'. Hyper-corrective, see glossary.) B. My grandfather.
The lama gave me a protective neck cord.
I gave some money to a beggar.

commentsTibetan: ཟ་ཁང་ནང་གི་སྐད་ཆ། ང་ལ་ཆུ་འཁོལ་ཅིག་སྟེར་རོགས། ཚྭ་ཅིག་སྟེར་དང་། གཤོག་གུ་ཅིག་སྟེར་དང་། ལྗགས་སྤོད་ཏོག་ཙམ་སྟེར་གནང་དང་། སྡུག་པོ་སྟེར།
commentsEnglish: The past tense of {ster} is also spelled {bster}, though the latter form does not appear to be very common. {ster} is used in the sense of giving something without expecting to receive anything in return. When in a restaurant, {ster} is used to ask for things that will be eaten or used and thrown away (e.g., a tissue). When asking for a utensil, (e.g., a spoon,) one would usually use either {bshug} or {g.yar}. See the verbs {bshug} and {g.yar} for example sentences.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to deplete, to waste, to squander.

examples.english: To talk about pointless things is really a waste of time. How could you possibly squander this single instance of your acquired human body? (i.e., 'since (you) only have one life, (you) shouldn't waste it.')
Please, don't dash my hopes.
Since life is only as short as a cat's yawn, don't waste it. (This expression is a proverb.)

commentsEnglish: In reference to sentence two of example one, Buddhism sees the attainment of human form, acquired through much positive merit, to be very rare.

examples.english: A. Is it OK if I show these photos to him? B. It's OK.
A. Did you show the certificate to her? B. I showed (it to her). A. Did you get shown the certificate? B. I didn't. She is in a good mood. (lit. 'she is manifesting a pleasant countenance.')
Please show me this book. That lama can prophesy well. Put on a good face. (lit. 'show a pleasant mood.')
Yesterday, the sun was very hot. This year, there was a bad drought.
He didn't even come to see me. (lit. 'he didn't come and show his face.' This phrase is usually said after having a disagreement).

commentsTibetan: གདོང་བསྟན་ཙམ་བྱས་ན་ཡག་པོ་ཡོད་རེད། མིག་བསྟན། སྤྱན་འབུལ་ཞུ། ཁྲོམ་སྟོན། རྟགས་མཚན་སྟོན། ཐན་པ་སྟོན། རྣམ་འགྱུར་སྟོན། ལྟོགས་རླུང་སྟོན། རྫུ་འཕྲུལ་སྟོན།
