commentsEnglish: {ston} is usually pronounced {bstan} for all tenses. {rnam rgyur yag tsam bstan A} in example three is often said to children and means 'look at me nicely' or 'please smile.' Note that in example two {lag 'khyer} can also mean 'passport', 'permit', 'license', or another official document.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Farmers are in the midst of gathering up the harvest.
Because there was a big drought this year, there will not be much harvest to collect.

englishGloss: to study, to research, to examine.

examples.english: I am going to the hospital for an examination. An investigation into who stole the object must be carried out.
Please investigate carefully who killed that person. I will examine this issue.
Since the teacher has been praising her highly, my daughter is likewise very happy.
I'm not just complimenting you, your actions are truly outstanding.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Our leaders will settle this situation. Work will proceed by observing the manner of decision making from the top.
Getting the resident permit will be the same as solving a lot of problems (at once).
It is really beneficial to (your) body, if you jump rope everyday. Some children are skipping rope in the courtyard.
The song that children sing when jumping rope is really nice. ({snyan po} is literally 'nice sounding'.)
He is skipping rope while eating a lolly. If (you) don't how to jump rope well, (you) will fall to the ground.

commentsEnglish: The meaning 'to skip or jump rope' reflects U.S. English.

examples.english: A. Did you get tired when we went mountain climbing yesterday? B. Since I usually don't walk very much, I got completely worn out.
One gets tired with excessive work. The deer was exhausted and laid down beside the great Milarepa. (Note that {mi la} is short for {mi la re pa}.)
Because there were years of successive droughts before, some areas have become very poor and still have not seen much improvement.
I don't imagine there will be a drought this year.

commentsEnglish: The correct present root is {than pa ston} but this verbalised compound is most commonly said {than pa bstan} and so has been written this way.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to be emancipated, released or freed.

examples.english: This road is presently being repaired and it is even difficult for people to cross, let alone cars.

This work unit won't let you in if you don't bring a letter of invitation. ({ngo sprod yi ge} also means 'letter of introduction'.) If you are freed from this existence, you are free indeed. (This phrase is a proverbial saying of Milarepa.)
If (I) don't get given some money, I don't think I can make it. (Or more naturally, 'If I don't receive some money...')

commentsEnglish: The use of {gnas} in the second sentence of example two refers to {'khor ba}, 'the cyclic existence'.

examples.english: When the guests arrived inside, everyone clapped and welcomed them.
Everyone clapped and agreed to my proposal. When monks debate, they clap hands to each other.

commentsEnglish: In Lhasa dialect, {dga' bsu shu} is more common than {thal mo rdeb} to mean 'to applaud'.

englishGloss: to hold hands together in a praying position.

examples.english: The elderly woman is listening to the Dharma with her hands clasped together. When prostrating, (you) should know how to clasp your hands (correctly).
He clasped his hands together and wished everyone well.

englishGloss: to absorb, to evaporate, to drain.

examples.english: All the water has been absorbed into the sand. All my money has been sunk into merchandise. (This phrase means that one's capital is tied up in commodities.)

The waves emerge from the ocean and in the end sink back. (lit. 'the waves sink back into the sea.' Note that the use of {yod} in this sentence reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.)

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: The house is leaking, because there has been torrential rain this year.
This is not a place to stay. There's (water) dripping from the tree.

englishGloss: to patch up a leaky roof.

examples.english: Tonight, it will probably rain. The ants are transporting dirt to the top of their houses. (Tibetans understand ant activity like this as a sign of impending rain.)
Some students patched up the roof of their classroom.

commentsEnglish: {thigs sa rgyag} is usually done with dirt or mud.

englishGloss: to meet, to come into contact.

examples.english: Yesterday, I met Tashi at the Lu Khang. Those two met at the school gateway. My leg touched the table.
Because there were too many people when I went to the market, we bumped each other a lot. The two of us had a fight.
A. Did he meet you? B. Yes, (he) met (me.) A. Did you meet him? B. No (I) didn't. Tomorrow, (I) will meet (him.)
Whether you go to University or not is dependent upon how well you do the exam. It depends on you whether we are able to go Shigatse tomorrow.
Because the house is too low, (people) bump (their) heads. I will go to meet (my) teacher.

commentsEnglish: The normative sense of this verb is non-volitional. i.e., I unintentionally met someone or I accidentally touched something. Therefore, the primary verbal argument is transitive, benefactive. The subject rarely takes the ergative, but rather it is often in the dative. However, {thug} can be used in a volitional sense when combined with another verb as in the sentence {nga khyed rang thug gar yong pa yin} - 'I came to meet you'. The transitive, volitional counterpart {gtugs} is not commonly used in Lhasa dialect.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: In 1990, I visited my relatives in America. I met our work unit's leader and talked with him.
On Saturday, family members are allowed to visit prisoners.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. I wonder if I will be able to do that work? B. Of course you will be able to do that work.
I am not able to come to the meeting today. So please allow me to be absent. (i.e., please excuse me.)
(She) probably won't be able to come today.

commentsEnglish: {thub} is not strictly a verb but rather a verb 'helper' - i.e., verb + {thub}. The example in Related words and Expressions is a special case of the use of {thub}. This particularl usage means 'to last.' - Speaker A. 'How long did those shoes last for?' B. 'Half a year'.

examples.english: If you are unsure, speak up and ask. If you remain indecisive, how can you achieve anything?

If you're in two minds about something, you can't achieve anything. Just like you can't sow with a two-pointed needle. (This expression is a proverb. 'To be in two minds' means to be hesitant in Aus. English.)

commentsEnglish: {the tshom} can be verbalised with either {skye} or {za} with little change in meaning or emphasis.

examples.english: Without the slightest hesitition, Wu Song grabbed a lion by the head. (Wu Song is a famous Chinese hero.)
Since he is totally indecisive when he works, he doesn't achieve a good result.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: His head seems to have been hit with a rock. There is a lot of blood gushing out from (his head). I threw a stone at a dog, but I didn't hit it.
If there is too much supertitious belief, society will remain backwards. (This is a slogan.)
The thief was caught by the police. (lit. 'at the hand of the police.')
That plant has budded less than it did last year. It is said that if you pull off some of the buds of a plant when there are many buds on it, the remaining buds will grow larger.
Irrespective of there being not enough fertiliser or too much water, many of the plant's buds dropped off.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: If his crime were exposed, it would be of benefit to him later on. I exposed your mistake.
He revealed my faults (to me).

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to register, to enroll, to make a list.

examples.english: All the commodities in the shop have been registered. It is good if some things that are said at meetings are recorded.
When (you) come to the work unit, (you) must register at the gate. (lit. 'near the gate'.) Whenever you come, please register.
He hit someone on the head with a hammer. Hammering is the most important part of a blacksmith's work.

englishGloss: to have lightning flash or strike.

examples.english: When there is loud thunder, there is danger of lightning. Last night, there was lots of lightning.

There is a proverb which says that if an old horse is struck by lightning, an old dog is happy. (This expression means that when bad things happen to a person, some people are happy about it. The German word, 'schadenfreude' adaptly describes this quirk of human nature.)

commentsEnglish: {gnam langs} means for the day to begin (lit. 'sky rise'), but in example two it means 'to be happy'.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to get, to obtain, to achieve, to gain.

examples.english: A. Who won the soccer? (U.S. English, 'Who won at soccer?') B. Tibet University won.
No matter how much people win gambling, (their) desires are never fulfilled.
She won the Nobel Prize for literature.

commentsEnglish: This verb is commonly spelled {thob} for all tenses.

examples.english: We mopped the classroom and made it clean. If this floor is mopped, it will become sparkling clean.

commentsEnglish: {tho' spa} is the Chinese word for mop.

examples.english: When I was young, my face would break out in pimples. When (you) get a pimple, don't touch it in a careless manner.

englishGloss: to carry something through to completion.

examples.english: Please see this work through to the end. Whatever work he does, he carries it through to completion.
He completed reading this book. I proof read this book all the way through.
I'm going to see this work through to completion. Please see this through to the end. Please complete (it).
These days, it is rare (to find) people who cast magic spells on each other. According to history, some monasteries have cast spells on each other.
Following his mother's command, Milarepa killed thirty people with sorcery.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to join or piece two things together.
to go in together to buy something.

examples.english: Dawa joined up the electric wires that had been cut. Shall the two of us go in together and buy a car? (i.e., combine our money together.)
This story is continued on section two. (i.e., of the newspaper or magazine.)
Your trousers are too short. They need to be lengthened. (This expression means that unless the trouser bottoms are joined together with another piece of material, they will still be too short.)
Please join together these two ropes.
A. Yesterday, two cars crashed. Did you see it? B. No, I didn't. Where did it happen?
A. Are you able to see the performance over there clearly? B. I can't see it very clearly.
A. Did he see the car yesterday that I bought? B. He didn't. If you drive it tomorrow, he will see it.
I don't consider that person to be very good. He doesn't appear to find that girl attractive.
My guess is that might rain tonight.

commentsEnglish: This verb is traditionally categorised as intransitive {tha mi dad pa}, but Kesang Gyurme considers this verb to be transitive and non-volitional. See glossary for more details on verbal arguments.

englishGloss: to look down on someone or something.
to view with disdain or contempt.

examples.english: It is commonly known by everyone that you look down on Dawa. If (you) don't have money, other people will definitely look down on you.
In contemporary society, even if you lack moral character, no one will look down on you if you have money.
Despite their differences, separate nationalities should not disparage one another. Those who belittle others show themselves to be lacking moral character.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: One should not look down on the Tibetan language, but rather esteem it. The leader regards him highly.
I have great respect for your position.

In order to cleanse accumulated non-virtue, I confessed before the Triple Refuge. (Note that {dkon mchog} is literally 'jewel'. {sdig pa} is often translated 'sin' but is more accurately rendered as 'non-virtue'.)
I admitted my mistake to the teacher and promised to be a good person. (Note that {slob dpon} means 'great teacher' or 'master'.)
He confessed in front of the Triple Refuge. I will confess my offences.
I am confessing the many non-virtues I have accumulated up to now. (Note that {mthol lo bshags} is used here.)

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound is only used in a religious sense. In Lhasa dialect, {mthol bshags phul} is also often said {mthol lo bshags}.

examples.english: They fought for many days over a disagreement in philosophy, but it is still not decided who won or lost.
If an axe fights with a rock, it will incur a loss. (This proverb is a a warning not to do something that is totally beyond your ability as you will surely suffer a loss.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be a comrade or brother-in-arms.

examples.english: Did you forget? We were previously brothers-in-arms.
We never had the slightest quarrel when we were military buddies.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: If you have a plan, it's easy to combat the enemy.
I think it is more important to protect the world than it is to fight against it.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Upon meeting (her) mother, the child immediately embraced her. That madman hugs every girl he sees.
Your eyes can not bear a whole day of being glued to a computer. (lit. 'If you hug a computer for a whole day,'.)
Overjoyed, the two of them embraced.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: She was shocked by that drunkard who tried to hug her.
For Tibetans, hugging in public is considered inappropriate.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Last night, I drank lots of sweet tea. Today, my stomach is a little sore.
A. Drolma, shall we go and drink some beer? B. I don't drink beer. I drink sweet tea.
A. Do you eat noodles, Madam? (i.e., would you like some noodles?) B. I do.

commentsEnglish: In contrast to English, Tibetans say 'to drink' noodle soup. They also say 'to lick' yoghurt. The past tense {btungs} is commonly used for all tenses.

englishGloss: to wrap up as a package, to encase, to pack.

examples.english: Tibetans have the custom of wrapping up money and giving it at wedding ceremonies. (i.e., giving it to the married couple.) Many people are required to package Tibetan medicine. (i.e., it takes many people to pack Tibetan medicine.)
These days in Lhasa, there are a variety of vegetables packaged and transported from mainland China.
I wasn't able to buy a present. I'm making it up (to you) by giving (you) money.
A. Will the grain I gave you the other day be sufficient as repayment for your loan? B. No, how can that suffice? (You) still need to supplement it with some money.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Because I was sick, the work was really delayed. If one always plays mahjong, then of course work will be held up.
If (you) go out often, (your) studies will be disturbed. Today, my work was really interrupted.
Son, this year is a crucial time for your studies, don't let anything get in the way.
If farming work is not hindered, then any other work on the side is possible. ({zhor las} means 'other work or activities'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Please take my hand, the stairs are very dangerous. At night, that dog pulls (at the leash) a lot.
I cough a lot if I smoke cigarettes. They plan to participate in the tug-of-war competition. (lit. 'rope pulling competition.')
Five taken from six is one. Six minus five is one. The parents pulled the child out of school.

englishGloss: to come out, to leave, to depart.

examples.english: A. When did the car leave Lhoka? (hyper-corrective. See comments below.) B. It left yesterday evening at 9 o'clock.
A. When did you graduate from University? B. I graduated in 1991.
Sorry, I have to go now. Some work has come up. ({tshom} is also sometimes spelled {'tshum}.) This mountain yields many minerals.
A. When will he graduate from school? B. Next year.

commentsTibetan: ང་ཁང་པ་ནས་ཐོན་གྱི་ཡིན། ཁོང་ཁང་པ་ནས་ཐོན་སོང་། ཁོང་ཁང་པ་ནས་ཐོན་གྱི་འདུག རྟགས་མཚན་ཐོན། སྨྱུ་གུ་ཐོན། ཁ་ལུད་ཐོན།
commentsEnglish: {'thon} is often spelled {thon} for all the tenses. The verb can be both volitional and non-volitional depending on the context, but more often the sense is non-volitional. Using the volitional sense, one can say {nga khang pa nas thon pa yin} - 'I left the building'. In this case, the verb is still intransitive but it takes on volitional auxiliaries (e.g., {pa yin}). Note that Speaker A in example sentence one could also say {ga dus thon song} without the interrogative particle {ngas}. See 'hyper-corrective' in the glossary for further discussion.

englishGloss: to be confused, dazed or puzzled.

examples.english: He mixed up the order of the documents and so I was totally confused.
It is confusing when you come back to a place that has undergone great changes while you weren't living there.
When coming home from the market today, I got really mixed up. (i.e., as to the right direction to come home.) Today, I was really confused. What happened?

commentsEnglish: The present and future tenses of this verb are often spelled {'thom}.

englishGloss: to collapse, to disintegrate, to crumble.

examples.english: I got splashed by the truck that scatters water on the road. (i.e., I got splashed with water.) The book has ink splattered on it.
That family has completely dispersed. Perhaps the family was not so close. Their plans have probably also broken down.
As I was taking the rice down from the truck, a sack ripped open and rice scattered everywhere.
If one gets hit by a boxer's fist, sometimes one will get knocked out. (lit. 'become unconscious'.)
The teacher corrected my essay. She is an expert at correcting people's honorific words.
My illness seems to have got a little better as I have regained my appetite.
Getting one's appetite back is a sign that a sick person has got better. ({nad pa} also means 'patient'.)

commentsEnglish: {dang kha 'byed} refers to the regaining of one's appetite after a period of not eating, such as following an illness. {dang kha 'byed} litearlly means 'appetite open'.

englishGloss: to make an oath, to pledge.

examples.english: I pledged before the Triple Refuge that I wouldn't drink alcohol.
He made a promise in front of his parents to stop smoking.
My brother pledged before the precious Jowo that he would no longer gamble by playing the Tibetan dice game, mahjong and other (games).

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense of the {bzhag} is { 'jog} but this is rarely used.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to make good use of one's time.
to hold or grasp something firmly.

examples.english: Make the best use of your time, and your studies won't be difficult.
(You) can achieve anything, if (you) seize the opportunity.
To stop the epidemic pneumonia disease (SARS), the whole world is taking serious action.
If the boss is not able to hold firmly to his authority, the company's discipline will collapse. ({kung si} is a Chinese loan word.)

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound is very similar to {dam bzung byed}.

examples.english: Many years have passed since solar (water) heaters became widespread in Tibet. In Lhasa, the use of computers is gradually spreading.
Places in the world where a religious system has never spread are very rare. (i.e., major religions have spread throughout the world.)
Through effort and diligence, we should expand the reach of science.

Some new systems appropriate for the development of the human race are spreading throughout the world. (i.e., technological systems. The use of {yod} in this sentence reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.)
Isn't it our responsibility to promote Tibetan culture? (lit. 'to disseminate or spread'.)

commentsEnglish: {dar spel gtong} and {dar khyab gtong} can be used interchangeably.

examples.english: The lives of the masses have improved tremendously. (This statement is a common slogan. {phun gsum tshogs} lit. 'means complete or perfect.' The use of {yod} in this sentence reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.) Everyday, our country is developing.
The lake in our area freezes over in December.
How easy for a frozen lake to melt, and yet how hard to be able to restore a frozen heart.

commentsEnglish: This is a compound verb of {dar}, which means 'silk' and {chags} which is the non-volitional verb 'to become'. The meaning is that the ice has become like silk. However, some people also say that {dar} here refers to {da ra} which is the substance remaining after butter has seperated from milk or cream.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: You'll definitely drown if you cross the water without knowing how to swim. My pen sunk into the water.
What a pity, my classmate is drowning in the ocean of suffering. (Note that the speaker here is expressing genuine concern.)
If you aren't careful, you will drown in that lake. A person drowned in that lake.

englishGloss: to make a deadline or time limit.

examples.english: A three year deadline for our project was set by (our) superiors. That person was sentenced to a nine year prison term by the court.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to take care of, to manage.

examples.english: He is managing the Tibetan department. If people below (you) are managed well, business will go well.
Our work unit manages work strictly.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to pay attention to, to be aware of.

examples.english: I listen attentively to your lesson. He usually pays attention to those matters.
It appears that you are not paying attention to what you eat. (lit. 'to your food.') Pay attention to this work!
A. Did you notice? B. I didn't. If you don't pay attention to your work, other people will look down on you.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: We will quickly put these things in sacks and leave tomorrow. Those merchants have packed their sacks and are ready to depart.
A. How many sacks have you finished packing? B. Two.

englishGloss: to get well, to get better.

examples.english: A. Teacher, is (your) leg better? B. It's completely healed.
I have completely recovered from my tuberculosis. A. When will she get better? B. Her sickness won't be cured straight away.
A. Do you remember the situation I told you about before? B. What did you say? I don't recall.
Oh what a pity, that child seems to be really missing his mother.

commentsEnglish: To say that you missed someone in Tibetan, as in the sentence {ngas khyed rang zhe drags dran byung} -'I really missed you', implies that you like or love that person very much.

examples.english: Unless (I) am reminded, (I) will forget. Teacher, I have come to you to remind you about something.
A. The other day, I went and reminded the teacher about what she will teach us. B. She may have forgotten. So she needs to be reminded again.
Please remind (me) often about this work. I am worried that I will forget about it.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. What happened to him? B. He was overwhelmed with fear and fainted.
It seems like the illness is a very serious one. I heard that (she) stayed unconscious for three days.

These days I am very forgetful, so please remind me. (The verbaliser {gtong} is use here which is more commonly used when asking someone to remind them about something.) We are commemorating the great achievements of those heroes.

englishGloss: to correct a student's hand writing.

examples.english: The tailor Drolma is cutting fabric. It is better not to cut this silk.
The teacher corrected my handwriting a lot. Teacher, please correct my handwriting.
The dog sniffed the meat a little.
Please smell this fresh meat. I think it is probably fine.

commentsEnglish: {snom} by itself also means to smell though in Lhasa dialect it is always said after the words {dri ma}.

englishGloss: to spray on a nice perfume or cologne.

examples.english: That girl is wearing a nice fragrance. (lit. 'a delicious smell sprayed on her body.') Since we are men, wouldn't it be peculiar to spray on a perfume like that?

englishGloss: to return or repay a kindness.

examples.english: Money alone cannot repay the kindness of (one's) parents. She has been very kind to me. I need to return the favour.
To return a favour, one also ought to have the ability to do so. (Note that {gsab} is the verbaliser in this sentence and not {'jal}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He was very ungrateful to me. That ungrateful person is worse than a dog.
You can't show gratitude when you can't recognise kindness. (This is a proverb.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to publicise, to have a publicity campaign.

examples.english: There will be public announcements about health care at the meeting today.
We held a publicity campaign many times about protecting animals.
A. What are (you) going to do after (you) have heated up the water? B. I am going to wash the kids.
This food is left over from yesterday. Please heat it up a little. Unless this room is warmed up, we'll really freeze.
When eating, he opens his eyes wider than his mouth. (This proverbial saying means that he is a greedy person looking for selfish gain in whatever he does.) That person died with (her) eyes open.
Unless the cloth bag is opened quite widely, it is difficult to put in. (i.e., difficult to put things in.) She's probably in. The door is open.

commentsEnglish: {gdang} is primarily used with things that have mouths or openings.

examples.english: Teacher, (I) am inviting you to a banquet tomorrow. Who are we inviting to our banquet this year?
One day we will invite you over to our home.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I am giving a high appraisal of that student. I have never received a high evaluation from a teacher.
It is difficult for anyone to evaluate that person. (i.e., it is difficult to make an assessment of this person because he or she does not reveal his or her true character.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. I met a wolf face to face on the mountain. B. Really? Oh, just as well you didn't meet a tiger.
Even if he meets me face to face, he still doesn't say anything.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to maintain, to take care of.

examples.english: (You) need to take care of public property. He is taking really good care of the car.

I am taking such good care of (these) scriptures as if they were my very own eyes! (In Tibetan, one's eyes are used as a common rhetorical device for something precious and dear.) He takes good care of flowers. (Note that {me tok} is also a generic term for 'plants'.)

englishGloss: to keep, to take care of.

examples.english: I have taken good care of the government housing. Those teachers are looking after the children very well.
If you don't watch (your) mouth, (you) will cause many problems.

commentsEnglish: {bdag po sprod} and {bdag po rgyag} appear to have the same meaning, though the latter is seldom used.

examples.english: Forget about my brother taking care of his own tools, he even lost some of my things!
There is a danger of this thing being ruined if it is not looked after well. ({'phro brlag} is also spelled {'phrog brlag}.)
The horse got frightened and snapped the rope. So could you please tie a knot in the rope.

If rope isn't knotted together firmly when joined, it will fall apart. (Note that the future tense of the intransitive verb {zhig} is {'jig}. {zhig} is the past tense but is commonly used for all tenses.)
The achievements of our sports team has leapt forward greatly.
A great leap forward in governance has occurred within Chinese history.

commentsTibetan: མཆོང་རྒྱག མཆོང་། མཆོང་རྒྱག ཐག་མཆོང་རྒྱག འགྲོ་མཆོང་རྒྱག འགྲོས་རྒྱག རྒྱང་མཆོངས། མཐོ་མཆོངས།

examples.english: If you use this soap powder, it cleans clothes really well. The jacket you washed today has become really clean.

In order to be cleansed from non-virtue, (one needs to) do prostrations and circumamulations. (The absence of an auxiliary verb in this sentence reflects literary Tibetan.) Please ask father for forgiveness.
He is a leader who has been elected by the people. This year, you are to be chosen as the (leading) example (to others).
I chose a bike from among those things. ({rkang sga ril} is often pronounced {btang sga ril}.)

commentsEnglish: Alternative spellings of the present and past tenses of this verb are {'dems} and {gdam} respectively.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: My hand is shaking, and I can't write the letter. Oh dear, this child is cold and shivering!
I trembled with extreme fear. A Tibetan proverb says, 'If goats are killed, sheep will tremble.' (This expression means that all of our actions have consequences.)

englishGloss: to quiver or tremmer when speaking.

examples.english: When she speaks among a large number of people, she gets nervous and tremmers in her speech.
That elderly woman's voice quivers as she begs.
Last night, the puppy must have been left out in the middle of the rain. It is really shivering. ({lus} is pronounced {las}. {khyi phrug} is another commonly used word for 'puppy'.)
Some sheep tremble at the sight of a butcher.

englishGloss: to lay a floor, foundation or tiles.

examples.english: They are in the process of putting carpet down in their house. We are putting down a floor.
A good plan needs to be formulated before doing work.

englishGloss: to have or hold an idea, concept or ideology.
to have an emotive connection to someone.

examples.english: In this world, there are many different ways of conceptualising a philosopy of mortal existence. (Note that {'jig rten} is often translated as 'universe', but literally it means 'the receptacle of the perishable', or 'the worldy constant of destruction and change.')
I am expressing the value of family by treating my sister well. (lit. 'a consciouness of kinfolk.') How do you feel about your parents?

commentsEnglish: This entry is more literary, though some people do use it in everyday life.

examples.english: If Tibetan paper gets soaked in water, it doesn't easily break apart.
The meat was boiled too much and completely fell apart.
King Gesar used many different methods to overcome his enemies.
Buddha preached the Dharma and overcame many evil traits of sentient beings.

commentsEnglish: This verbs is also used for training or breaking in a horse, though {bcun} is more commonly used for that sense.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to drive, to herd animals, to cause to move.
to chase, to go after, to pursue.

examples.english: He is herding cows. That child cow herder is driving all the livestock onto the grass.
I came following your footsteps. That stray dog really chased me.
You have to drive that student like a donkey because he doesn't have much initiative.

Wolves chase sheep as a result of previous karma. The whip of a powerful leader is the result of myself. (This proverb means some circumstances are the result of karma, while other situations are brought about by one's own immediate folly.)

commentsEnglish: An alternative past root spelling of this verb is {ded}.

examples.english: In Tibet, ploughing and sowing commences sometime around May. (lit. 'the fifth month of the western calendar'). One needs to know how to plant fields according to the season.
After the planting of fields has finished, farm work isn't done. There is still a ton of work to do.
The season of spring has arrived. It is time to plant the fields with seed. Has it been said who the seed planter is today?

commentsEnglish: {thobs} is an alternative spelling of the imperative form of this verb. {'debs} is usually pronounced {btab} for all tenses.

examples.english: As soon as spring begins, farmers do cultivation work. The time has come to do cultivation work.

englishGloss: to tie, to fasten, to attach, to lease.

examples.english: A. Who named your child? B. A lama from Sera monastery.

Tibetan women wear a lot of jewellery. Nomads leash their dogs beside their tents. ({gdogs} is usually pronounced {gdags}, but here, the pronunciation of the written form is retained because it sounds nicer when combined with {khyi}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to satisfy or fulfil one's desires or needs.

examples.english: The office has met all our work needs. (Note that {las khungs} is often translated as 'work unit' in the context of the P.R.C.) Sponsors take care of all our needs during our stay in Tibet.
I will do whatever I can to fulfil that wish of yours.
It would be utterly impossible if (we) had to fulfil the wishes of everyone.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to wish, to want, to desire.

examples.english: A. Does that girl desire to get married? B. I'm not sure. (lit. 'now I am not able to say.')
He wants to have the coat that we bought yesterday.
That girl really wants my money.
A. Are you satisfied with the way I teach class? B. I am.
No matter how much money he gets, he is never satisfied. This time, I'm going to rest until I'm satisfied.
A. Are you content with your life at the moment? B. No, I am not.
Do you find your work satisfying?
You should never be content in your pursuit of knowledge. (This is a motivational directive.)

commentsEnglish: Both {tshim} and {khengs} are used as verbalisers with {'dod pa}, and both appear in the example sentences. Regardless of which verbaliser is used there is no change of meaning or emphasis.

englishGloss: to cause to come out, to put forth.
to take or bring out, to produce.
to publish, to import, to mine.
to print, to have film developed.

examples.english: She took something out of (her) bag. Those people are extracting minerals from the mountains.
I have written a book, but it is still to be published. A. Have our photos been developed? B. They are on their way out now.
That new dictionary has been published by the Tibetan People's Publishing House.
All those things have been imported from mainland China.

commentsEnglish: One could also use the verb {bshus} for the second sentence in example two to express the meaning 'develop photos'. See {bshu} for example sentences.

englishGloss: to cut out material for sowing.

examples.english: The tailor cut material with scissors for making a jacket. I know how to cut out material for a chuba, but (I) have never cut out material for a jacket.
The thief was interrogated by the authorities.
When he was interrogated by the court, he didn't say a single word.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be acquainted or familiar with.
to get accustomed or used to.

examples.english: A. Is that dog used to you? B. Yes.
If you get accustomed to that person, (you will discover that) he will get worse and worse.
A. What are you digging? (hyper-corrective. See comments below.) B. We are digging a hole for a tree.
We dug a new well.
Previously, the farmers dug a hole in the ground and buried potates and radishes in it for food in winter and spring.

commentsEnglish: In example one, speaker A could also say {ga re 'dru gi yod} without the interrogative particle {pas}. The example is marked 'hyper-corrective' because it has both the interrogative pronoun {ga re} and the question particle {pas}. See 'hyper-corrective' in the glossary for further discussion.

englishGloss: to drag, to pull, to haul.

examples.english: He is pulling a cart. ({ther ge} is pronounced {ther ka}.) He dragged that drunkard and put him outside.
That person was dragged by a horse and sustained very bad injuries to his arms and legs. My child is coming with his toy car dragging behind.
Don't drag your feet.
If chang is mixed with tea, it's got a strange taste. Don't mix sand with the dirt for making the roof.

These days when Tibetans speak, (they) mix Tibetan and Chinese together. (Note that while Lhasa Tibetans often claim this to be the case, this generalisation can not be applied universally to Tibetans in all areas.)

commentsEnglish: Note that {'dre} is most commonly written and pronounced {'dres} for all tenses.

examples.english: A. You didn't slip? B. I nearly slipped.
Yesterday, he slipped over on the ice. If you are not careful you will slip. Yesterday, he slipped and fell over.
Teacher, (please be careful) or you will slip over.

commentsEnglish: Note that the pronunciation of {'gyel 'dar} is not always subsituted for the written form. {'dred 'dar} is also common in Lhasa dialect.

examples.english: In history, Kuru Churwang saved his mother from (the body of an) insect and pulled her to (heaven). (Note that Kuru Churwang is a famous {gter ston}, or treasure revealer, of the Nyingma sect who lived during the 13th and 14th centuries.)
Buddha has the hook of salvation, but sentient beings need to have the ring of faith.

Parents should lead their children in the right direction. The farmers built a viaduct and brought water to (their) fields. ({zhing chu} means 'irrigation water'. Note that {drangs} is pronounced {'dren}.)

commentsEnglish: The expression in Related Words and Expression, 'He wet my head with water', is more common in Shigatse, though some Lhasa speakers do use the verb {drangs} in this way.

englishGloss: to be startled, to be frightened.

examples.english: I was frightened because of the way you spoke to me. The horse was startled and threw off that person.
The car's horn beeped causing all the yaks to be startled. The horse was frightened by his presence. I was startled by the sound of the car.
If you speak loudly, wild animals will be quickly startled. Last night, the wind blew very strongly against the window causing me to be very frightened.
You don't need to be alarmed. I was just joking.

commentsEnglish: The term {ri dwags} in example three properly refers to 'herbivores' and is often used as a reference to deer.

examples.english: I sharpened the knife and cut up the meat. When I was sharpening the knife, I cut my hand.
A. Miss, please go down and grate the radishes. B. I have just grated them.
The builders didn't work and spent the whole day in idle chatter. (lit. 'ground their mouths.' This is an idiomatic expression to mean to talk about all kinds of small, meaningless things.)

commentsEnglish: The verb {rdar} is also used for sharpening metal objects other than knives. The word {bu mo} in the first sentence of example two, has been translated as 'Miss' in this context to correspond with American English. {bu mo} means 'young girl', 'daughter' or 'woman.'

examples.english: Because it rained a lot this summer, even the buildings collapsed. Last night, because the wind was strong, all those tents collapsed.
That kettle fell from the table and got dented. ({hu'u} is a Chinese loan word.) Children! If you run on the roof, there is danger of the building collapsing.
I have heard that a friend of mine, who is a businessman, has gone completely bankrupt these days.

commentsEnglish: An alternative spelling for the past tense of this verb is {brdibs} and an alternative spelling of the future tense is {brdib}.

examples.english: His car hit my bicycle. Yesterday, an ox bashed into her.
I knocked on his door, but there was no one there to open it. Isn't it easier if you hit the iron with a hammer? (Note that {tho ba} is also pronounced {tho bo}.)
I beat a drum. Last night, the hail almost struck the crops.

commentsTibetan: སྙེ་མ་རྡུང་། ཞིང་པས་གཡུལ་ཐང་སྒང་ལ་སྙེ་མ་རྡུང་གི་འདུག ཏུམ་ཏུམ་རྡུང་། ཉེས་རྡུང་གཏོང་། རྡུང་རྡེག་གཏོང་། རྡུང་ཁ་རྒྱག
commentsEnglish: {rdung} can also be used in the context of threshing the ear of a stalk of grain.

examples.english: Yesterday, two cars collided.
Today, I saw two yaks ram each other on the grassland. (i.e., bang into each other repeatedly. Note that here the sense is intentional.)
According to the law, it is forbidden to recklessly beat prisoners.
Everyone should strike out against those who spread evil in society. (This expression is a motivational directive and hence reflects literary Tibetan.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to strike, beat or bang against something.

examples.english: He got angry and smashed the bowl on the ground. I hit the pen on the desk but it didn't break.
What were you saying as you pounded your hand on the desk? The back of your jacket is full of dust, so it needs to be dusted off.

commentsTibetan: ཐལ་མོ་རྡེབ། ལག་པ་རྡེབ། བརྡབ། རྐང་རྡབ་ལག་རྡབ་བྱེད། བརྡབ་བརྡབ་གཏོང་། ཁོས་དཀར་ཡོལ་བརྡབས་བྱས་བཅག་སོང་།

examples.english: If you get too close to a horse, it will kick (you.) I don't know how to kick a ball.
I kicked that dog in the bottom.

englishGloss: to mop the floor with one's feet and a rag.

examples.english: Mopping the floor, is the work of the chapel caretaker. If the floor is mopped often, it will become shiny. ({snum tshil tshil} literally means 'greasy' or 'oily'.)
We need to unite as one! (This expression is a slogan.)
All the people from the same fatherland need to unite together and help build a new homeland.
If your side can unite as one, the enemy won't be able to attack. (lit. 'wage an attack in your direction.' This is a slogan.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to step, tread, stomp or trample on.

examples.english: When Tibetans do a big wash of carpets and so forth, they must wash them by stomping on them.
You're stepping on my feet! Haven't you got eyes? (The context here is two people dancing.)
Today, my lower back is very sore. Please step on it a little. (i.e., as a way of massaging it.)
Don't trample on someone who has fallen down. (This proverbial saying means 'don't beat someone who is already down.')
Yesterday, my bike got a puncture and (I) went and got it patched. The cloth bag for putting the tsampa in has burst.
A. How many holes are there in the tyre? B. Only one.
(My) head was split and lots of blood came out.

commentsTibetan: སྟོད་ཕད་རྡོལ། སྣོད་ཆས་རྡོལ། དོ་པོ་རྡོལ། རྫིང་རྡོལ། གྱིག་གཤོག་རྡོལ། ལྷམ་གོག་རྡོལ། རྫུན་རྐུབ་རྡོལ། ལྒང་བུ་རྡོལ།
commentsEnglish: An alternative spelling of the past tense of this verb is {brdol}.

examples.english: Don't just sit there chewing away. Isn't the food delicious?
Why do cows and yaks ruminate?
Those who bring harm to world peace are loathed by all people, male and female.

I don't hate you, (I'm) fond of you. (i.e., I'm telling you off because I like you, not because I hate you.) Followers of the Dharma, do not hate their enemies, neither do they remain attached to their friends and relatives.

commentsEnglish: {sdang} is not commonly used in Lhasa dialect, but {sdang po byed} is somewhat more frequent. See the record for {sdang po byed}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to act in a spiteful, vindictive way.

examples.english: It is really sad when you consider how Milarepa's uncle and aunt victimised him.
According to Buddhism, it is not right to hate anyone, whether friend of foe. ({la'ang} is pronounced {la'i}.) Why is he being so spiteful to me?

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: (You) should not hate any kind of sentient beings.
Hating others is the same as buying suffering for yourself.
Harbouring hate is the basis upon which you yourself will become lost. (This proverb means 'hatred will be your downfall.' Here, {sdang 'zin} is verbalised with {'chang}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: There is great benefit if you confess your previously committed non-virtue. He confessed his sins before a lama.
In Buddhism, repenting of non-virtue by the five special strengths is extremely important. (Note that these special strengths are; faith, energy, recollection, contemplation and wisdom.)
Don't pound on the roof as there are people living below.
Put the tsampa in the cloth bag and pound it.

englishGloss: to cry or howl in agony.

examples.english: If you always cry out in agony, will the other patients be able to get any rest?
The dog barked through the dead of the night and wouldn't let us sleep.
He really whines all the time.
He caused us much suffering.
The employer really mistreated his staff by not paying (them) their rightful salary.
(You) need to make yourself happy as other people won't do it for you. (lit. 'people will cause you harm'. This proverbial saying means 'you can't rely on others for your own happiness.')

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: That boss puts his workers through a lot of hardship. I will die, unless you stop putting me through so much misery! ({nga shi ba 'dug} doesn't literally mean 'to die' but is a common expression used for emphasis.)
That child causes undue grief to his parents by always loafing around.

commentsEnglish: {sdug po gtong} is also commonly used in Lhasa dialect.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Son, just bare it for a little while. When we arrive home, you will be able to eat right away.
No matter how much pain he is in, he is able to endure it. I wasn't able to stand it any longer and told them off.
A. When having the injection, how did he hold up? B. He held up for a bit, but cried in the end.
At the airport customs they collected a hundred American dollars from each person.
The laity collected money and built this temple. I will collect the student's homework.
In short, your work has turned out great.
His name is abbreviated as 'Drey Nor'.
King Song Tsen Gampo brought Shang Shung under the control of Tibet. (Shang Shung is the ancient name of Guge, a province in western Tibet.)
They made their plan after comparing ideas. In comparison with before, our lives have really improved, you know.
A. If (you) compare those two, who is better at (their) studies? B. How can you compare those two? That girl is twice as good.
There's no comparison with that.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Please take what you want from the shop. It will be fine if we calculate it all together later.
When I calculated everything together, I arrived at exactly 15,000 RMB.
If (you) always go wandering about, one day (you) will be held accountable for it.

englishGloss: to wind up, to roll up.
to pull up or lift up trousers, chubas or curtains.

examples.english: I already packed all the necessities for my trip to Lhoka. Oh, I still have to pack some tea and butter.
Dont leave that long electric wire stretched out. Roll it up. I wound up the rope.
Our job of writing a textbook is difficult to finish. (lit. 'making a textbook.') (We) will finish this project quickly.
Please fast forward the video tape. Please re-wind.

englishGloss: to pack for a trip or outing.

examples.english: We need to pack up today, as we should leave early tomorrow. I finished packing the things needed for the trip to mainland China.

englishGloss: to reside, to stay, to live.

examples.english: A. How many years are you going to stay in Tibet? (lit. 'how many years are you a stayer in Tibet?') B. If (I) get permission, (I) plan to stay for three years.
A. Where are you living these days? B. I'm living in the Barkhor.
A. What is your daughter doing? B. My daughter is at home. I came from Nepal by airplane.

A. Teacher, have you been staying in Lhasa? (i.e., you haven't gone anywhere recently? This question could also be expressed {nang la bzhugs bzhugs pa yin pas} 'Have you been staying at home?') B. I have been staying (here in Lhasa).
Last year, I stayed in America for a few months.

commentsEnglish: The present tense {sdod} is pronounced {bsdad}. The imperative {sdod} is pronounced as it is spelled. In Shigatse and many areas near Lhasa, {sdod} is pronounced as it is written for the present tense. In Lhasa dialect, {sdad} is used in combination with many verbs. It is often used in a similar way to 'ing' in English. For example, {khyed rang sgugs sdad yod pas} - 'Are you waiting (for someone)?'.

englishGloss: to bind, to fasten, to tie.

examples.english: The traders have tied the sacks and are planning to leave. The belt is undone and needs to be tied up.
If there is not a tightening of the law, it is difficult for people to initiate good deeds.
Please tie up the girl's hair. (Note that {sdoms} here refers to tying hair into a pony tail. {bu mo chung chung} literally means 'small girl'.)

commentsEnglish: {sdom} is typically pronounced {sdams} for all tenses. This verb has the same present tense and imperative root as a different verb meaning, 'to add, to total, to sum up.' They are often confused as the same verb. They have been listed separately in this book - see {sdom}.

englishGloss: to add, to total, to sum up.

examples.english: A. How much is five plus five? B. Five plus five is ten.
All in all, they also get the benefit. Altogether, how many songs did you sing today?

commentsEnglish: This verb has the same present tense and imperative root as a different verb meaning, 'to bind, to fasten, to tie.' They are often confused as the same verb. They have been listed separately - see {sdom}.

englishGloss: to take a vow or oath.

examples.english: Beyond being barely able to take a vow, he can't actually keep it. He said that he is taking monastic vows and is going to practice the holy Dharma.
He has taken the highest vow of a monk.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to put up a notice or sign.

examples.english: Our work unit is planning to advertise for bringing in new people.
However extensive the advertising is, to that degree the sale of the item will benefit.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Our soliders knew that the enemy had sent a signal. I will notify (people) that a meeting will convene tomorrow.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Basang, go and put a notice up that (we) are having a meeting this afternoon. ({dgong dag} is often translated 'evening' but most commonly it refers to the work time from 3.30p.m. to 6p.m.)
We put up notices, but those guys are always saying they didn't know. (One might typically say this about a meeting.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to fall down, to collide, to crash.

examples.english: I fell down with my bike yesterday. My motorbike has fallen on the ground.
When learning to ride a bike, (you) fall off often. If (you) are not careful, (you) will fall.
You didn't hit your hand, did you? I bumped my hand many times on the desk.
Just now, Chodrun fell and her forehead has swollen. ({dpral khog} is pronounced {pe khog}.)
When I ride my bike, I always fall off a few times. (lit. 'one or two times.')

commentsEnglish: Though {sku brdabs gsal} is honorific for {brdab}, {gsal} does not appear to have a standard spelling when used with {sku brtabs}.

englishGloss: to shake out or dust off.

examples.english: After washing clothes, they need to be shaken out. I will shake out that dirty carpet outside. Lots of dust is caught in it.
I dusted off your hat. Before entering a temple, (you) should dust off (your) shoes.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound is also spelled {rdab rdab gtong} and sometimes verbalised with {byed}.

englishGloss: to put away, to pack up, to collect.

examples.english: The nomads packed up (their) tent and left. They packed up all of (their) things quickly.

Today I am packing, and I will leave for Beijing tomorrow. It seems that the person who murdered someone the other day was packed off to jail by the court. (Here {bsdu gsog rgyag} is an idiomatic expression meaning 'thrown in jail.')
A. You don't appear to be very well. (lit. 'your face is not very good'.) Are you sick? B. I am a little sick.
If you are sick, please go to the hospital straight away. That dog must be sick. It isn't eating any food at all.
He has infected sinuses.

englishGloss: to have pain, to ache, to be sick.

examples.english: I'm in a lot of pain because my head was struck by a rock.
If I bump my old wound even a tiny bit, it's excruciatingly painful.
He often fakes illness so people don't believe him (anymore). Don't avoid work by pretending to be sick.
To be able to import foreign goods, would bring a good profit. They imported some excellent cars from Japan.

Since he said such bad words to me, I just couldn't stomach it. What, can't you handle a scolding from your parents? (This sentence means that one should be easily able to endure a telling off from one's parents.)
If abuse like that is metered out, how can it be tolerated?
When teaching a lesson, the important points certainly should be emphasised often.

If our baby sister is not often told emphatically, she forgets to do the important things. (Note that {pA mo} is a Chinese loan word meaning 'housekeeper' as well as 'babysitter'. In Tibetan, one can say {bu rdzi} or {phrug gu lta mkhan} for 'baby-sitter.')
I have stressed emphatically that they have to pay attention to the children's safety.
Look, my sweater is really stretched. (Note that in British and Australian English 'jumper' means 'sweater'.) This plastic is very stretchy.
Work becomes boring when it is prolonged. (Note that {mjug gu} is pronounced {zhu gu} and means the conclusion, the last part, the end or the finish.)
Look, there is a long, stretched out cloud.
Our plane was delayed for one hour.
I'm going to write the report for the government without delay.
I had to postpone for a little while the work you gave me to do. Please don't be angry. ({zhal bkod} means, 'to instruct, to order.')

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to provide something free of charge.

examples.english: During the religious teaching, the lama covered all the expenses. Today, our work unit will provide our food. (i.e., as a free service.)
The P.R.C paid for all the expenses of our visit.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Would you dare eat this food? B. I wouldn't dare eat insects like that.
There's no way I would ever dare to swim in the river.
I could do anything, but couldn't kill anyone. ({gsod} is pronounced {gsad} in this example.)

englishGloss: to bring forth one's power or strength.
to use one's capacity, power or strength.

examples.english: I will support this work in whatever way I can. We need to need to muster all our strength to successfully complete this project. (This expression is a motivational directive and reflects aspects of written Tibetan.)
The farmers showed enormous strength in building this year's dam.

englishGloss: to err or make a mistake.

examples.english: I made a writing mistake. It seems that the tourist took the wrong road.
Oh, I completely said the wrong thing. (lit. 'my speech was in error'.)

If an expert errs, it is a big mistake. If a fool errs, it is a small mistake. (This proverb means that well-informed people should know better not to make mistakes, whereas a fool has less accountability.)

commentsEnglish: While the verb {nor} is intransitive, the subject is often in the ergative. {'dom gan}, used in the proverb of example three, means the length of one's out stretched arms, and {mtho gan} means the distance from the tip of the thumb to the tip of the middle finger.

englishGloss: to act in a mean, cruel or wicked way.

examples.english: That person acted wickedly and smashed my car window.

If (you) act cruelly to others, unfortunate events will come back to you. (This sentence means that karmic retribution will cycle back to you. This expression is based on the proverb {sems pa ngan pa mi la byas na/ bya ba ngan pa so sor 'khor/.)

commentsEnglish: This entry literally means 'to do something with a black heart'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Since I didn't do anything bad, there is no need to feel guilty. As soon as I mentioned that situation, she suddenly grew remorseful. ({shad ma thag} is more commonly said as {shad pa da ga}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: When the teacher collected the homework, some students probably had not done it and put (their) heads down in shame.
There is no need for remorse if you didn't do it. (Note that {las ka} here means 'deed' or 'action' rather than 'work.')
He showed remorse. (i.e., perhaps he put his head in his hands.)

commentsEnglish: This compound means to display or show guilt through one's actions. The sense of this verb doesn't necessarily mean that one is regretful.

examples.english: Don't harm my work. This work is very important.
Rats caused a lot of damage in the house. Even though you have all that, you shouldn't inflict harm on others.
He harmed me.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: It seems that those thoughtless people are still harming wild animals.
How can it be acceptable to damage the environment when there aren't even any measures to protect it?
If the natural world is excessively ravaged, the end result of this will catch up with us. (i.e., karmic retribution will cycle back to us.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He stomped on my leg. Last night, the snow flattened all the flowers.
If those children aren't suppressed a little, they will become more selfish. (i.e., disciplined a little...) Unless the washing is held by a rock, it will get taken away by the water.

englishGloss: to take an oath, to swear, to vow.

examples.english: I took an oath, before the Jowo, that I would not marry for my entire life.
Even though you have taken an oath, we will never trust you. Swear (on it). (The imperative is also said as {mna' skyal}.)
I had to swear (that I was telling the truth), because my older brother didn't believe me. She took an oath that from now on she would stop drinking. (i.e., stop drinking alcohol.)
I can swear that she will not do poor work.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The bandits not only stole our possesions, but also greatly tortured (us).
According to the Geneva Convention, prisoners of war are not allowed to be tortured.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to show an external expression of one's attitude or feelings.

examples.english: Please show a good demeanour. That child is showing a very good demeanour.
On top of being beautiful, she is also good at showing a pleasant demeanour to the guests.
When we went to a foreign country, he didn't pay us much attention.
That person has a bad work attitude. (In this sentence, {rnam 'gyur} is not verbalised with {bstan}.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is typically pronounced {rnam 'gyur bstan} for all tenses. In Lhasa dialect, the expression {rnam 'gyur yag po bstan dang} is often said to little children and means 'look happy', 'smile' or 'show a nice mood'.

englishGloss: for one's countenance, mood or manner to change.
to become noticably disturbed or irritated.

examples.english: He got angry and his mood changed. I don't understand. He's become irritated with me.
Those friends of mine never have mood swings.
Please wipe the child's nose. That person has probably got a cold. (Her) nose has become all red from wiping it. (i.e., from wiping the mucus.)

You don't listen to what I say and now you have learned your lesson. According to a proverb, it is said that it is better to learn once from your own mistake than to be told one hundred pieces of advice.
He doesn't play with firecrackers these days. This is because some time ago a firecracker exploded in (his) hand and (he) learned his lesson.

It is said that it is good if you have a blood nose in spring. (Note that in U.S. English 'blood nose' is 'bloody nose.') Just now, the elderly lady sat out under the sun for too long and this probably caused her nose to bleed.
If (you) get a blood nose, (you) should put cold water on (your) head. (Note that this reflects the Tibetan practice of dealing with a blood nose.)

commentsEnglish: The first sentence in example one reflects the Tibetan belief that it is beneficial to the body to have a nose bleed in the summer.

englishGloss: to hold in low regard or esteem.

examples.english: You shouldn't disregard small illnesses. Don't hold the Tibetan language in low regard.
He doesn't hold anything in low regard and does everything thoroughly.
Mother showed little concern for her shoes and left them out in the middle of the rain for the whole day.
Don't take this matter lightly. Don't underestimate this thing. It has tremendous force.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to notice, to take an interest in.

examples.english: Dekyi does not pay attention to what her mother says. He doesn't pay any attention to the way other people do things.
A. Is Mr. Lobsang there? B. I haven't noticed. (i.e., if he was or wasn't there.)
Pay attention to what she is wearing today. (i.e. pay attention to her clothes. Note that the imperative is {byed} and not {gtong}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He doesn't pay the slighest attention to what I say. No matter what I say to him, he doesn't listen.
Some children don't listen to the advice of their parents. Concentrate and write the letter well.

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense of {bzhag} is {'jog}, but this is rarely used when paired with {snang ba}.

englishGloss: to be unconcerned, neglectful, or indifferent.

examples.english: If (you) overlook those circumstances, it will be like a small fire destroying a forest and a small stream eroding a whole area. (The second part of this sentence is a proverb and means 'if you do not take care of little things, they will become big problems.')
A terrible end result with cycle back if, through indifference, trees are excessively chopped down.
When a plane is about to land, the wheels extend out. The girl stretched out all the rope.
Don't let the chuba hang down so low. Wear it properly.
Isn't it better to quickly finish the remaining work and not put it off?
I will give you some extra. Please give me some extra.
Unless my sister pitches in some money, I will not be able to buy this computer alone.
If you buy stuff from that shop over there, they always give some extra.

englishGloss: to act in a wild, unrestrained manner.
to behave like a reckless bum.
to be reckless with drinking, smoking and fooling around.

examples.english: In society, some people do not go to work but rather act in a reckless manner.

Don't act like a bum! (i.e., don't indulge yourself with reckless living. The imperative {'khrobs} is pronounced {'khrab}.) That child has recently become a real rascal. (Note that {chags} is the verb in this sentence.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is similar to {phyogs sprang}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to hold or nurse a child.

examples.english: Our child needs to be held as soon as he wakes up. (The) father is holding the child on his lap.
I don't remember my mother nursing me. (Note that 'nursing' in this context does not mean breast feeding, but holding in one's lap.) Cradling children is not only the work of mothers.

commentsEnglish: Both {pang khar btab} and {pang phar btab} are used in Lhasa dialect, with the latter being more common. The correct present tense of {btab} is {'debs} but this is rare in Lhasa dialect. {pang khar nyar} is also common in Lhasa. In Gyantse dialect {pang khog btab} is used.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Is it OK if I take a photo of you? B. It's OK.
Let's take a photo together. I need to make a photocopy of those old scriptures.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I kneeled before the noble. He is kneeling before the representation of the diety and praying.
Even though he has pleaded on bended knee, his wife has no intention of ever getting back with him. (The couple here have separated).

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be a witness, to get evidence, testimony.

examples.english: I can bear witness that you didn't commit the crime. (lit. accumulate the offence.) One needs to look for a guarantor, if borrowing money from a bank.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The teacher dictated about ten new words to us.
The teacher always dictates (to us) when teaching a lesson.

englishGloss: to have a picnic on Saturday.

examples.english: Going on Saturday picnics is popular in Shigatse. That woman sang very well at the weekend outing.
The campaign for stopping the epidemic is spreading everywhere.
The behaviour of evil people is increasing and they are causing harm to society.

englishGloss: to move from one place to another.

examples.english: The ants are in the midst of moving (their) nest. I will move from Lhasa to mainland China.
If this reasoning doesn't make sense, (it) will be easier to understand by moving onto another example.

commentsEnglish: {spo} is most often pronounced {spos} for all tenses.

englishGloss: to play ball. (i.e., soccer or basketball.)

examples.english: A. Do you want to go and play ball now? B. Sure. Where shall we go and play?
He is really good at soccer and basketball.
They are playing ball with me. (This idiomatic expression means one is being sent from place to place by one's superior.)

commentsEnglish: {spo lo rgyag} refers not only to soccer but also to basketball.

englishGloss: to give up, to renounce, to abandon.
to abolish, to discard, to revoke.

examples.english: After receiving good advice, I gave up both alcohol and cigarettes.
A. Have you quit (going to) Tibetan-style nightclubs? B. Not completely.
If you can abandon the taking of life, there is much merit.

commentsEnglish: This verb is also used in the religious sense of renouncing worldly desires or bad habits.

examples.english: He lit a fire and it caught alight. I tried hard to start the motorbike, but it wouldn't start.
My friend was promoted by (her) superiors. The price of oil has been raised due to the war.
These days, the nomads are moving their camps. ({mtsher sa} means nomad encampment.) Please get up and turn on the light. (Note the imperative {spor} is pronounced {spar}.)

commentsEnglish: The first sentence in example one illustrates the causative/resultative pair of {spar} and {'bar}.

englishGloss: to look away in the other direction.
to turn away (often out of anger.)

examples.english: He works in a different manner to other people. (This sentence means that he looks in a different direction to other people in all the work he does.)
As soon as that child is told off a little, he looks in the other direction. (This example means that he doesn't obey his parents.)

commentsEnglish: {spor phyogs slog} is often done out of anger or annoyance.

examples.english: Please stir the soup well. ({gtong A} is often pronounced {btang aA}.) If (you) shake an apricot tree, apricots will fall down. ({kham sdong} can also be translated 'peach tree'.)
I agitated him, but he didn't get angry. Those kids shook the cat violently. (lit. 'the cat's body'.)

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound is also spelled {dkrug dkrug gtong}. In the first sentence of example one note that {rung} means 'you', but if translated directly into English can sometimes sound unnatural.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to flatter, to say what another person wants to hear.

examples.english: She really likes to say flattering things in front of the leader.
He's an expert at brown-nosing. I have never crawled up to anyone. (In U.S. English, one might say, 'I have never kissed up to anyone.')
Don't flatter me. (This is being said in a somewhat lighthearted, joking manner.)

commentsEnglish: The original meaning of this entry is connected to imitating a monkey. In Australian English, 'crawling up' to someone means to tell them something they want to hear in hope of gaining personal advantage.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I gave a book to her. We gave each other presents.
The hospital gave me a seven day medical certificate. (lit. 'rest certificate.') Since she routinely does her work well, the work unit gave (her) a promotion.
A. Have you finished paying off the bank loan? B. I still have a little left to pay.

commentsEnglish: The past, present tense, and future tenses of {sprod} are typically pronounced {sprad}, though the imperative {sprod} is usually pronounced as it is written.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: When washing shoes, (you) must scrub them. The dirt is so thick that unless you scrub it, (the object) won't become clean. (The implication here is that the object being washed is clothing.)
When washing a horse, (you) must scrub it.

commentsEnglish: {phag mdo} is a special brush used for brushing clothes and shoes. {phag mdo} can also refer to 'paint brush'. This verbalised compound is sometimes spelled {phang to rgyag}.

examples.english: We translated some of the most important news from English into Tibetan.
He is a translator of storybooks.
If we unite together, the enemy will not be able to defeat us.
Their hope of defeating us has come to ruin. ({stong zad du} is a fixed collocation that is commonly said in Lhasa dialect.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to swim across a body of water.

examples.english: A. Are you able to swim across this river? B. I don't know about this river. However, I have swum across the Lhasa river.
He swam across the river.

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense is {phar gcod gtong} though this is rarely said.

examples.english: I blew up a balloon. My eye is sore. Please blow on it.
I am going to pump up my bike. (i.e., my bike's trye.) The trye doesn't have any air at all. Please pump it up.
Since he always drinks beer, he blew away his job. (This idiomatic expression means 'he threw away his job.')
His wife seems to have changed. Her way of speaking is not at all like it is normally. (Note that {phu rgyag} in this context is used to mean that a person's behaviour has changed.)

englishGloss: to make a first offering to a deity or god.

examples.english: The guests gave the first offering of the chang three times each, and then drank.
Before drinking chang, please make the offering to the gods. Tibetans make an offering to the deities before drinking chang.

commentsEnglish: {phud gtor byed} is usually done by flicking chang into the air three times with one's fourth finger.

examples.english: Everyday, my husband massages my back. When (you) have sore eyes, don't rub (them) with (your) hands.
I spent many days tinkering with the car, but it is unfixable. (lit. 'massaging the car'. This is an idiomatic expression.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to get hit or inflicted with.

examples.english: I've got a strange sickness. My arrow didn't hit the target.
A. What happened to you? (You) are sitting there like a bird that's been struck by a stone. B. I've got a cold.
I was really hurt by what you said.

commentsTibetan: ཉི་འོད་ཕོག དམོད་པ་ཕོག ལ་དུག་ཕོག ཟས་དུག་ཕོག གངས་སྐྱོན་ཕོག ཇུས་ཉེས་ཕོག སྒོ་བརྡུངས་ཕོག

examples.english: He always offends other people. Dont say things that offend other people.
She really offended that meek person by wrongfully accusing him.
She can withstand any amount of personal insult.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Tibetans are very concerned with local dieties being offended.
It won't be any good unless the leader doesn't get offended.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to make religious symbols with one's hands.
to clasp hands together in a respectful greeting.
to pretend to do something with one's hands.

examples.english: The lama performed many mudras from his throne. There are many ways of performing mudras that have varying degrees of tantric significance.
That mad person always pretends to be firing a gun with his hands.
A. You speak English very well. B. Nahh... I can only give the appearance that (I speak), but really I don't know English very well. (The speaker is being modest.)
A. Who founded this monastery? B. The venerable Tsong Khapa founded it.
The first Panchen Lama founded Tashi Lunpo (monastery).
The Jokhang was founded by Song Tsen Gampo in the middle of the seventh century.

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense of {btab} is {'debs}, but this is rarely used when joined with {phyag}.

examples.english: Some Tibetans, who have great faith in the Dharma, come to visit Lhasa's Jowo by prostrating all the way from very distant areas. (This sentence reflects aspects of literary Tibetan.)
A. Are you offering prostrations these days? B. I am, but each day I'm only able to do a hundred.
Elderly Tibetans continually prostrate and circumambulate on a daily basis. (Note that {phyag 'tshal} is part of a larger nominal phrase verbalised with {byed}.)

englishGloss: to put things back to front.

examples.english: He is wearing his jacket inside out.
If that material is turned inside out and then clothes are made from it, they will be beautiful.

englishGloss: to withdraw, to retreat, to recall, to pullback.

examples.english: The mountaineers retreated from the glacier.
There was no choice but to temporarily delay this plan.

Starting from next month, tourists going abroad will be delayed for a period of time. (Note that the use of {yin} in this sentence reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.)

englishGloss: to expel, to drive out, to drive away.

examples.english: Because that student fought with the teacher, he was expelled from school.
The work unit expelled him because he always gets drunk and causes problems.

commentsEnglish: This entry is sometimes said {phyir 'bud gtong} and is similar to {rkyang 'bur gtong}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: These days, China is exporting many kinds of commodities.
Our country made those things specifically to be exported overseas.
Are those cars for overseas export?
He returned to his country. Those people just now returned to their work unit.
Because the terrain and weather of that place were not suitable, she had to return to (her) homeland. ({pha yul} literally means 'fatherland'.)
These days, Chinese living abroad are returning to the motherland.

commentsEnglish: This entry can also be verbalised with {rgyag}.

examples.english: I wiped the desk with a cloth. Before (we go), one student must stand up and erase the blackboard. (lit. 'wipe clean the blackboard'.)
A. Is this vacuum cleaner able to clean this carpet? ({sa gdan} is pronounced {sab gdan}.) B. Yeah, this machine is able to clean it very well.

commentsEnglish: This verb is sometimes spelled {'phyi} with the corresponding past tense {'phyis} and future tense {'phyi}.

examples.english: Young girl, please wipe the table right after you have finished sweeping.
The temple caretaker wiped the altar clean.
People have spread rumours about them and consequently put them at odds. (i.e., they now don't get along with each other, lit. no longer friendly.)
Uncle Tru Tung is an expert at spreading malicious rumours. (Tru Tung is one of King Gesar's uncles)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: She sang well and so people were envious.
Being jealous of people who are higher than you and looking down on people who are lower, is a situation that is everywhere.
Tibetans call a jealous person a peacock.

englishGloss: to jump around, to move around.

examples.english: When a colt is first riden, it bucks a lot. During winter, (your) body will warm up if you move around a bit.
Don't jump around! (This expression is often said to children.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is also spelled {'phag 'tshag rgyag}.

examples.english: They lost the lawsuit because they didn't invite an expert lawyer.
They lost the war and immediately fled to another country. Defeat is the root of victory. (This proverb means that if you learn from your defeats, you will ultimately be victorious.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. How did he come to ruin? B. He came to ruin because he liked alcohol too much.
If you hang out with a bad person, you also will come to ruin.
(I) heard that a few weavers were expelled from the carpet factory. Hey you, unless you work hard (you) will be expelled from the work unit!
(We) can't get across this river without taking our shoes off. If you are feeling hot, please take off (your) coat.

commentsTibetan: མིག་ཤེལ་འཕུད། དུག་སློག་འཕུད། ཞྭ་མོ་འཕུད། སྟོད་ཐུང་འཕུད། ཕྱིར་འབུད་བྱེད། འབུད་རྒྱག་རྒྱག ཕུད་གཏོར།
commentsEnglish: An alternative spelling of the present and future tense of this verb is {'phud}. Some people also pronounce this verb {'phud}, though {pid} seems to be more common. This verb is similar to the transitive form {'bud} which is rarely said by Lhasa speakers. {'bud} means, 'to push, to shove, to expel'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Look, there is a vulture flying in the sky. Kites can fly well when the wind is blowing. ({bya 'phir} is also spelled {bya 'phur}.)
A foreigner flew with wings from the mountain of Ganden Wangbo to Samye. (Note that 'flew with wings' refers to a hang glider.)
Flowers have really flourished in that garden. If rice is boiled, it expands.
The number of sheep has really increased in that household. It is said that if (you) go around the Lingkhor often, (you) will accumulate a lot of merit.
The technology of our factory is advancing.
If (we) want to develop agriculture, (we) must import new technology from abroad.
We will develop the economy and bring benefit to the public.
Computing skills have really advanced in Lhasa.

commentsEnglish: This verb is not very commonly said but it regularly appears in the newspaper.

englishGloss: to be moved from one place to another.
