examples.english: When (one) transmigrates from this life, it is difficult to say where (one) will arrive.
It is not easy to transmigrate from the human realm to the blissful realm.
A. I wonder who the lama is for transferring the consciousness of that deceased person? B. I don't know who the lama is.
A. Is it possible to transfer one's own consciousness? (i.e., before death.) B. Those who have obtained realisation transfer consciousness themselves.

commentsEnglish: {'pho ba rgyag} occurs at death or in unusual circumstances prior to death. {'pho ba rgyag} is usually evidenced by a hole in the top of one's skull.

englishGloss: to ridicule, to put someone down.

examples.english: Since I don't have good English pronunciation, they are mocking me. Don't put her down or she will be embarrassed.
Don't mock me.

commentsEnglish: {'phya lad rgyag} is similiar in usage to the more common {dma' 'bebs gtong}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Miss, please sweep the courtyard well. B. OK. First (I) will scatter water, and then I will sweep.
Those girls sweep the market street early in the morning.
He has swept up all of the leaves of the willow tree. (Note that {lcang ma} can also be translated generically as 'tree.') Please sweep all that garbage away.

commentsEnglish: Note that {bu mo} is translated 'Miss' in the first sentence of example one to reflect U.S. English.

englishGloss: to make a mistake, to err.

examples.english: A. Yesterday, I made a mistake with this work. (i.e., I really botched it.) B. What mistake did you make? (hyper-corrective. See comments below.) A. I made a complete blunder about the place to buy a new computer.
When you go to Lhasa, please don't mess up the purchase of my thangkha.

commentsEnglish: This verb is also spelled {'chug}, the tenses of which are {'chug}, {chugs} and {chug}. {'phyug} is very similar to the verb {nor}. In example one, speaker B could also say {ga re 'phyugs gnang song} without the interrogative particle {ngas}. It has been marked 'hyper-corrective' because it has both the interrogative pronoun {ga re} and the question particle {ngas}. See 'hyper-corrective' in the glossary for further discussion.

englishGloss: to rise, roll or swell upwards.

examples.english: Because the wind is blowing strongly, the ocean waves are surging up to the sky.

During the Tibetan festival commemorating the death of Tsong Khapa, the incense smoke swells up in Lhasa's Barkhor where there as many people as the eye can see. (This festival is always held on the 25th of the tenth month in the Tibetan calendar.)

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to waste, ruin, wreck or spoil.

examples.english: Whatever he gets, he ruins. (lit. 'whatever is given into his hand...') He wrecked my computer.
If much time is wasted now, (we) will regret it later on.
He snatched the pocket knife from the child's hand. Yesterday, the Nepal border customs seized many fake cigarettes.
Killing others is the most serious of the ten non-virtuous deeds. (Note that when {'phrog} is preceded by {srog}, {'phrog} is pronounced as it is written.)
Honestly, when I met you I was powerlessly swept away by you. (This expression is said between boyfriend and girlfriend. In this contect {phrog} is pronounced as it is written.)
Don't plan to steal my wife! (This phrase is usually said as a joke).

englishGloss: to rob, to plunder, to loot.

examples.english: Not only did those criminals participate in an uprising, but they also plundered much of the wealth of the masses.
Last night, all of his money was stolen by a bandit.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: If you arrive in a place with very high humidity, (your) body will get soaked (with sweat). The rain soaked my clothes.
If a fly's wings get dipped in water, it can't fly. ({sbrang 'bu} is pronounced {sbang gu} and {'phur} is pronounced {'phir}.)

commentsEnglish: The volitional counterpart {sbong} is pronounced {sbang}.

englishGloss: to form a line or row.

examples.english: The army is marching in lines. When buying a plane ticket, (you) need to queue up.
Unless those books are put in rows in the book shelf, they won't be easy to take out.
Those cars for sale are lined up in rows.
I acted as mediator when those two fought. To mediate in a marriage dispute is the most difficult thing to do.
When mediating in a dispute, one needs to be good at acting in accordance with both parties.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to mediate, to act as a go-between.

examples.english: Acting as a mediator in the middle of a squabble is a big mess! When married couples fight, it's beneficial if someone mediates. ({rgyag 'dre} is pronounced {rgyam 'dre}.)
Two people were fighting yesterday, but not a single person (was willing) to interfere.
Being a business negotiator is a heavy responsibility.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to use, to make use of, to utilise.

examples.english: We dont know how to use this kind of machine. These days, people only use others for their own ends.
Nowadays, most people use a computer to do (their) work. What is the difference between not using something you have and not having it at all?
I got ink spilt on my new clothes. Oh no! My cup fell on the ground and all the tea has been spilt.
When (you) fill up a thermos with hot water, please don't spill it. If coagulated butter gets spilt on clothes, it is difficult to get clean. ({ja zhag} is the layer on the top part of butter tea.)

englishGloss: to take on a lease or a rental payment.

examples.english: He took on the lease of the school canteen and then gradually become rich.
If you want to get into civil disputes, then interfere in the affairs of others. (This is an idiomatic expresssion used if you want to incite or provoke others.)
These days, most farmers are leasing their fields and are going out to do business themselves. ({rgyag par} is more commonly said as {rgyag gar}.)
The dishes have improved since the work unit leased out the restaurant. (i.e., the food has improved.)

commentsEnglish: This is usually said of renting out land or a shop. For a private house, {khang gla gtong} is more commonly said.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: When I was a child, I liked to fly kites. It is dangerous to fly kites on the roof and in the street.
The Tibetan method of flying kites is especially unique.

englishGloss: to leave or make a contribution.

examples.english: Tumi Sambhota founded written Tibetan and accomplished something great for Tibet.
In Tibetan history, many people have emerged who have left behind significant achievements. (This sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)
Lhasa is a place which has been blessed by Avalokiteshvara. (i.e., Chenrisi, who is considered to be the embodiment of the love and compassion of the Buddha.)
Lama, please bless my body, speech and mind. (This expression reflects literary Tibetan.)

commentsEnglish: The present tense is {byin gyis rlob}, but is rarely used.

examples.english: Son, if you pat that dog down there, it will bite.
He is stroking his beard and contemplating.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound can be used to mean rubbing or stroking one's face or beard.

englishGloss: to do, to make, to act.

examples.english: I have to work every other day. (Note that {byad} functions as a verbaliser here.) I studied at Tibet University. ({byas} functions as a verbaliser here.)
I said to that person many times,'don't do that'. But he doesn't listen.
A. Oh bother. B. What happened? A. I left my keys inside the house.
The more work you do, the more problems arise. (lit. the amount of work one does is proportionate to the amount of problems that arise.)

commentsEnglish: The primary function of {byed} is as a verbaliser. Along with {gtong} and {rgyag}, it is one of the most common verbalisers. However, it also acts as a verb in its own right, as illustrated in some of the example sentences. The use of {byed} meaning 'to say', is best considered an extension of the meaning 'to act in a certain way'. For example, {ngas khong la 'di 'dras byas pa yin} could be translated, 'I said such and such to her'. Though some Tibetans will disagree with this English gloss, such usage frequently exists in both oral and written registers.

examples.english: We ran away from Shigatse and came to Lhasa. If children run away, they cause difficulties for the parents.
I got excrement on my shoes on the road. (I) scraped (it off).
Please scratch my back. That child probably has an itch. He is scratching his head.
Don't scratch the wound. If it is scratched, it will get infected.

commentsEnglish: {brad brad} is also spelled {'brad 'brad}.

examples.english: A. How well is this item selling? B. It is selling really well.
A. I wonder if jackets like these will be marketable in Lhasa? B. I've heard that trousers will probably sell well.
All my aprons were sold.

englishGloss: to have a feeling of wanting to do something.

examples.english: If you look at my history, there are many things to make one feel like laughing and crying. There is a saying that children who tend to cry when young, turn out to be good when they grow older.
I need to urinate. When you need to urinate, only then do (you) remember the toilet. (This proverbial saying means you can recall things from memory when it is necessary.)
I really want to eat Tibetan food today. ({bro} is pronounced as it is written when used with {snying}.) Last night, I really wanted to go to a Tibetan night club.

commentsEnglish: In example three, {bro} is used in a similar way to {'dod}.

englishGloss: to separate, to distinguish, to differentiate.
to distinguish between what should be accepted and rejected.

examples.english: He is an expert at discerning good from bad in proportion to his great depth of learning. She is able to distinguish clearly between what is good and what is bad in society.
My instructor teaches many methods for distinguishing between what should be accepted and what should be rejected.

commentsEnglish: This entry is commonly pronounced {blang dor byed}.

examples.english: My mother redeemed a swan and set it free. If (I) were to buy this scripture, how much would it cost?
I redeemed the life of this yak. He redeemed my life. (This is a very rare usage. e.g., the speaker was sentenced to death and his life was somehow saved.)

commentsEnglish: In the first sentence of example one, the sense of this expression is to purchase the animal and then set it free. {blu} is sometimes pronounced {blos}.

examples.english: I will pour chang from the kettle into the cup. A. When should the hot water be poured into the thermos? B. Isn't it best to pour it in straight away?
A. Please put this letter in the fastest envelope. Don't let it slip from your mind. (lit. 'Please pour this matter into your brain well.' 'fastest envelope' means 'express post.') B. OK. No problem.
A. Were you able to score any goals? B. Yes, (I) was. A. How many goals did you score? B. I scored two goals.
A. Do they fill gas (bottles) well? B. No, (they) don't fill them well.

commentsEnglish: In example one, note that {hu'u} is a Chinese loan word. The Tibetan equivalent is {khog ltir}, a large clay or metal pot for holding tea or beer.

englishGloss: to win over to one's side.

examples.english: Using persuasion, our strategy should be to keep him from over indulgence.
It is our responsibility as teachers to patiently win over and (change) the bad behaviour of those students.

commentsEnglish: This entry is not common in the spoken register.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to give or entrust yourself to someone.
to open your heart up to someone.
to trust or believe in someone.
to depend or rely on someone.

examples.english: The couple whose marriage was arranged by their parents, have not opened up their hearts to one another. (i.e., haven't entrusted their deepest feelings to each other.)

I contemplated opening my heart to you, but you show no interest in me. (i.e., I want to show you how much you mean to me, but you don't want anything to do with me. The use of {khyed} and {na'ng} in this sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)

commentsEnglish: The present tense of {gtad} is {gtod}, but this is rarely used. This entry is not common in the spoken register.

englishGloss: to rely on, to depend on.

examples.english: I always entrust my heart to you. (This is more commonly said between boyfriend and girlfriend.)
If they have invested their trust in us, we need to help them as much as we can.

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense is {blo dtad 'chol} though this is rarely used.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to stay or remain in one's mind.

examples.english: It is good if (you) can remember the advice of (your) teachers and parents. Since I've become old, there are many things that I can't remember.
When we were young, we had to remember many new words everyday. If you can't remember, forget about it.

englishGloss: to be appealing, attractive or agreeable.

examples.english: A. Which thing appeals to you? B. This thing appeals to (me).
If you like that jacket, I will buy it. The things that he said really appealed to me.
Those people were really impressed by the things she said. (Note that {'bab po} acts as an adjective.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to trust in, to have confidence.

examples.english: Please trust (me). I will say that there is no problem about this matter.
I am going to trust you in this matter. (The speaker is talking to a higly respected person, e.g., a lama.) Please have confidence in me.
A. Is it OK to trust that person? B. Yes. It's fine to trust her.
There is an old proverb which says, if you trust a bag made of stomach lining, that bag will leak water. (This expression means even a person you think is trustworthy can let you down.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He gave up his life and saved that child from the water. (One) needs to sacrifice as much as (one) can for the sake of the people. (This phrase is a motivational directive and reflects written Tibetan.)
I could sacrifice my wealth and position, but I could not abandon my parents.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be willing to run a risk.
to be able to bare the sacrifice involved with something.

examples.english: I can't bare that burden of you going outside on your own! (The implication here is that the speaker is feeling uneasy and is urging the person to stay and not go out alone.)
You seem so willing to run risks. Sending (your) child to school alone!

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to give authority, to give power, to pass on power.

examples.english: The king passed on power to his son and from then on the common people were happy.

The Panchen Lama has empowered many tens of thousands of people. (This is to empower people spiritually. This is a ritual that one goes through in order to enter the secret mantra vehicle of Buddhism. {dbang bskur} is sometimes translated 'intitiation'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: England took control of India for many years. When King Lang Tarma ruled Tibet, Buddhism underwent a great collapse.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to hand over power or authority.

examples.english: We're through if power is handed over to an evil individual! ({bsags pa red} is a colloquial expression meaning that nothing but bad will happen, or 'we're finished!'.)
That father never gives (his) children the power to make decisions.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: If an evil person obtains power, he will even ration bad water. (This is a proverb.) Tashi, when you obtain power, don't forget us.
You should guard your sarced commitment as your own life after receiving a lama's initiation.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Hey, don't bully children smaller (than you). They are always intimidating us. (Or more precisely, 'they are always speaking as if they have authority over us.')
He bullied me and made (me) buy (him) a ticket.

commentsEnglish: This entry literally means to speak as if having power or authority.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The king continuously keeps before him many male and female entertainers.
Unless I leave, I will completely waste the day entertaining you with frivolous amusements. (This expression is a way of saying, 'It's time I left'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be founded, to be established.
to come into being or existence.

examples.english: Our nation has been established for fifty years. (This is a slogan.) How many years have passed since the Children's Foundation was established?

It is clear from historical (records), that Buddhism was first introduced in Tibet during the time of (king) Lha Totori Nyentsen. (According to tradition, It is said that a Buddhist scripture fell from heaven into King Lha Totori Nyentsen's hand. This sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)

commentsEnglish: {dbu brnyes} is not commonly said but can be heard often on local news broadcasts.

examples.english: Listen, everyone. Take a single (big) breath before singing. (This is a music teacher talking to his/her students.)
Young girl, don't be afraid and slowly breathe in and out. (This is a doctor speaking to a patient.)
When singing, the manner of inhaling and exhaling is important. ({gnyis cha} is the same as {gnyis ka}, {gnyis ca} and {gnyis car}.)
He has difficulty breathing when he smokes.

commentsEnglish: {dbugs rngub gtong/byed} means to breathe in and out.

examples.english: He sighed and pondered.
He seems to be very disappointed. He is sitting (there) sighing a lot.

englishGloss: to be deflated, to loose strength.

examples.english: When a dog meets a wolf, the dog loses heart. When that married couple fights, the husband (always) loses heart.
That evil person killed his wife by choking her. It would be very terrifying to be choked.

commentsEnglish: There appears to be two different spellings for this compound - {dbugs sub} and {dbugs sum}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be suffocated, to be choked.

examples.english: If you don't open the doors and windows of the house, it will become stuffy. If you don't often check up on babies when they are sleeping, there is danger of (them) suffocating.
The inside of this house is getting stuffy.

commentsEnglish: {dbugs sub} is also spelled {dbugs sum}.

examples.english: A. When you arrived in Tibet, how short of breath were you? B. Not so much. I was a bit at first, but later (I) had no problems. ({mcug gur} is pronounced {zhu gur}.)
If you are short of breath, have a rest. That patient is really wheezing.
When the iron gets hot, (I) will iron (my) trousers. ({gos thun} is often pronounced {gu thung}.) If clothes are ironed, they keep their shape better.

commentsEnglish: {dbur ti rgyag} is also spelled {bdur te rgyag}.

englishGloss: to move something from one location to another.

examples.english: A. If you move house, where do you plan to transport your old furniture? (hyper-corrective. See comments below.) B. We will transport all our furniture to a new house.
A. Oh. Tonight, it will definitely rain. B. Why? A. Look! Those ants are transporting soil and patching up the roof of their ant nest.
They transported some good quality cars from Europe to Lhasa.

commentsEnglish: The first sentence in example one has been marked 'hyper-corrective', as this question could also be asked without the interrogative particle {pas} because it contains the interrogative pronoun {ga par}. See glossary for further discussion.

examples.english: A. Did he throw out the waste paper? B. (He) did not. How can it be alright if parents abandon their children?

It is forbidden to spit or blow out mucus. (i.e., to fling around saliva and mucus.) Don't do this work. Just leave it. (Note the alternative spelling of {g.yugs} in this example. See comments below.)

commentsTibetan: ལག་པ་གཡུགས། ལྕགས་རིལ་གཡུགས། ལྕགས་བག་ལེབ་གཡུགས། འབར་རྫས་གཡུགས། འབོམ་གཡུགས། ལག་འབོམ་གཡུགས།
commentsEnglish: An alternative spelling of {dbyugs} is {g.yugs}. The difference in meaning between the two is that {g.yugs} can also mean 'to wave' as in {lag pa g.yugs}. Otherwise, the two verbs are similar.

englishGloss: to tear up or rip up.

examples.english: I tore all the paper. Before going to war, that country tore up the peace treaty.
From the look of the weather, it's about to rain. When the time comes to die, there is nothing one can do.

commentsEnglish: An alternative past tense spelling of this entry is {babs}.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: Please stop the car, sir. I'm getting off here. These stairs are probably not easy to descend.
This morning we came down from the mountain. He was demoted from a leader's position. (Note that the commonly used alternative past root spelling {babs} is used in this example.)

commentsEnglish: A commonly used alternative past root spelling of this verb is {babs}.

examples.english: He rolled a stone down the mountain. If a big rock is rolled down, there is great danger of hitting people who are coming and going!
Hey, my friend, don't get so drunk or your life will be taken away (from you). (In this context {'bab ril gtong} is an idiom for getting drunk.)

commentsTibetan: རྦབ་རིལ་གཏོང་། རྦབ་སྒྲིལ་གཏོང་། འབབ་རིལ་གློད། འབབ་རིལ་ཐེབས། མི་དེ་རྦད་དེ་འབབ་རིལ་འབབ་རིལ་རེད། ཁོང་རྦད་དེ་འབབ་རིལ་འབབ་རིལ་བསྡད་ཤག གདུམ་མ་རིའི་སྒང་ནས་འབབ་རིལ་གློད་བྱས་དབོར་གྱི་རེད། འབབ་རིལ་གློད་གར་འགྲོ་གས།
commentsEnglish: {'bab ril glod} is a common idiom meaning to 'to get drunk'. It literally means 'to roll over and over'. {'bab ril glod} also means to roll something along, for example, {gdung ma ri'i sgang nas 'bab ril glod byas dbor gyi red} - 'The beams are transported by being rolled down the mountain'.

englishGloss: to burn, to catch on fire, to explode.
to be turned on, to be started.

examples.english: If you aren't careful with electricity, (you) could start a fire. (lit. 'fire will start'.) A firecracker exploded in my hand.

Like the proverb of adding fuel to a fire, after the leader told me off you also gave me your opinion. (The first part of this sentence can be literally translated as 'on top of burning fire, split wood.')
(You) shouldn't squander aimlessly the period of youth when your vigour and energy is in the midst of burning. (This sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: He is boring a hole in a stone. (This phrase is an idiomatic expression meaning that he is a hard worker.) The rats gnawed a hole in my bag again.
The robbers drilled a hole in the roof and entered the house. People who are persistent can bore a hole in a rock. (This is a proverb.)

commentsEnglish: In Lhasa dialect {'bigs} is often written for all the tense forms and the imperative, but the verb is always pronounced {pid}.

examples.english: Children always push when lining up. When playing basketball, (you) will get pushed strongly. (Note that the non-volitional verbaliser {thebs} has been used in this sentence.)
I pushed him. (i.e., accidentally. See comments below.) He pushed me.

commentsEnglish: The first sentence in example two illustrates the non-volitional sense communicated by the verbaliser {thebs}. In this situation, the person has pushed someone accidentally. Notice, however, that the subject 'I' is in the ergative. This structure is common with many non-volitional verbs when the speaker wishes to give clarification or emphasis that it was he or she, and not someone else, who accidentally did the action.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: This drawing is well carved. (lit.'protruding out well'.) Those images would be more magnificent if they protruded out.
The hero's courage is made to stand out in this story.

englishGloss: to plane, to smooth with a planer.

examples.english: A. This desk has been made very sturdy, but it hasn't been planed well. (Note that {de'i} is the spoken form of {de yang}.) B. Oh, I am just going to plane it.
I am planing a plank of wood.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound is similar to the less common verb {'jog} which means 'to plane' or 'to carve'. However, the past tense of the verb {'jog} ({bzhogs}) is somewhat frequent.

englishGloss: to make or cause to descend, to bring down.
to demote, to lower the price.

examples.english: He was given a heavy responsibilty from the top. (i.e., from the leaders.) I took down the picture from the wall.
It will be difficult to translate this poem from Tibetan into English. (i.e., if the poem needs to be translated.)

englishGloss: to call out, to shout out.

examples.english: Even though at the point of death, that person is calling out the names of her children. What are (you) calling him for?
If a deceased person summons you by calling your own name in a dream, it is considered very bad luck.

commentsEnglish: {rnam rtog} in example two refers to the perception that certain behaviour or occurrences may lead to either harmful or beneficial consequences. In the spoken register, {rnam rtog} usually refers to a jinx.

examples.english: He normally exaggerates excessively. I'm not boasting, I don't lack the skills to do this job.
Don't blow your own trumpet. (In U.S. English, one might say 'Don't blow your own horn.')

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound is derived from {'bor chen}, which means a large quantity or amount. {kha pho shod} is common in Shigatse, though not in Lhasa dialect.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be stuck or glued on.

examples.english: There's a fly on your face. (lit. 'stuck on your face.') The small child is clinging to her mother as they go along. (lit. 'stuck'. i.e., the child is shy or feeling scared and is walking right beside his mother.)
Two pages of my book are stuck together.

englishGloss: to apply, to spread, to put on, to rub on.
to apply cream, medicine or hair colour.

examples.english: That girl has applied a lot of makeup on her face. (lit. 'applied much red and white.') A. Have you put cream on your face? B. Yes, I have.
The doctor applied medicine to (my) wound. I applied Tibetan medicine to the child's wound.
If you put varnish on a new cabinet, it will be good (for it).

englishGloss: to open, to unlock, to uncover.

examples.english: A. Please open the gate. I am coming in. B. OK, I will open it straight away.

The car's door is open. If (you) have some things, please open the boot and put (them) in. (Note that 'boot' in this context means 'trunk' in U.S. English. Tibetans also say {mo Ta'i rkub nas blugs rogs gnang} for 'please put things in the boot.')
Separate the stones from the soil. (Note that {dbye ba phyes} is a verbalised compound.) That person is not able to clearly distinguish between good and bad.
Tsong Khapa founded the Gelukpa tradition.
The house's door can not be opened unless it is unlocked first.

commentsTibetan: འགྱིག་ཤོག་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ལྕགས་ཀྲིན་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ཇ་དམ་གྱི་ཁ་གཅོད་ཕྱེ། བརྙན་འཕྲིན་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ཡི་གེ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། སྒྲོག་རྩེའི་ཤུར་སྒམ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། འགྱིག་དམ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ཡིག་སྐོགས་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ལྟོ་ཕད་ཁ་ཕྱེ། སྒམ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། དེབ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། ཞལ་ཁ་ཕྱེ། སྒོ་ལྕགས་ཕྱེ།

examples.english: A. Did you receive your letter? B. No, not yet. A. If you get the lettter, please tell me. Perhaps there is a message for me in that letter.
A. When did the Abbot arrive in America? B. He arrived two weeks ago.
A. How many days have passed since they arrived in Lhasa? B. I don't know when they arrived.
As soon as you arrive in England, please call home. A. Did you receive the thing I sent you? B. I did. Thank you.

englishGloss: to follow after, to adhere to.

examples.english: Many people follow religion. I came following after you.
Regardless, the most important thing is that we adhere to a correct and rational viewpoint. (This sentence reflects aspects of literary Tibetan.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Who wrote this book? B. Lobsang wrote it. It is said that this picture was painted in the 12th century.
Long ago, his father was number one in all Tibet for his Tibetan hand writing. (i.e., the neatest and most accurate.)
I wrote you a letter, but I don't know whether you received it or not.
He is an expert at writing books.
A. Who is the writer of this letter? B. I am.

commentsEnglish: Note that {ri mo 'bri} means both to paint or draw a picture. It also can mean to accidentally stratch the surface of something.

examples.english: There was a lot of thunder today. It is frightening when it thunders like this.
There is no fear of rain immediately after thunder. (This proverbial saying means some people make a lot of noise about something but never do anything.)

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: A. When did you have your hair cut? B. A few days ago. You didn't notice?
Parents cut (their) children's fingernails. I cut the paper with scissors.

englishGloss: to escape, to run away, to flee.

examples.english: Some life prisoners killed some guards and escaped.
Yesterday, while being followed by a dog, he didn't look back and fled. He fled to another country.
I heard gun fire in front of me, and I ran away at once. If you kill a goat, sheep tremble. If you hit a dog, pigs flee. (This is a proverb.)
That businessman played mahjong and lost all his capital. We will play mahjong during the new year festival.
There are many mahjong players in the gambling room.

commentsEnglish: In contemporary Lhasa, {sbag} is the same as the Chinese game {mA cang}.

englishGloss: to split or break in two.

examples.english: This rock needs to be split in two. I split up those wooden beams and made planks out of them.

commentsEnglish: {sbag bshags} is also spelled {sbag zhag}, but there seems to be good reason to spell it {sbag bshags} because of an etymological connection. {bshags} is the past form of {gshog} which means 'to split' or 'to break in two'.

englishGloss: to be broken or split into two.

examples.english: I wasn't being careful when returning (home) and all the eggs broke open.
I've eaten too much and my stomach is about to burst. Today, my bike tyre split in two.
The plastic bag has split. Just as I put on my jacket, it split.
I need to urinate (and if I don't), (my) stomach will burst in two! ({grod khog} refers to the whole abdomen or belly.)

commentsEnglish: {sbag bshags} is also spelled {sbag zhag}, but there is good reason to spell this entry {sbag bshags} because of an etymological connection. {bshags} is the past tense of {gshog} which means 'to split' or 'to break in two'.

examples.english: When girls fight, they scratch each other on the face. Cats scratch strongly.
The cat scratched the child on the face. Hey! You're sratching me. Please dont. (Note that {khong} in this context refers to the second person 'you'. Lhasa speakers often use {khong} in this way.)
He covered the pen with (his) hand. He concealed the pen in his hand.

That child hid someone else's wallet in his pocket. (i.e., pocket of a chuba. {am phrag} is pronounced {am phag}.) There are many places which have the custom of burying the dead. (i.e., under the ground.)
The potatoes have been buried underground. (Note that burying potatoes underground is a common way to store them.)
A. (Have you) finished soaking the vegetables? B. I have. The yak leather should be tanned after many days of soaking it. (Note that the verb {mnye} is the future tense of {mnyed}, meaning 'to tan.')
These noodles are edible after being soaked in hot water. Before washing the clothes, please soak them for a little while.

englishGloss: to dig using a shovel or spade.

examples.english: I dug out the dead tree in our courtyard and pulled it out by the roots. (lit. 'dried up tree.') He is shovelling and digging up the ground.
There will be no end to their slothfulness unless I go and dig to root it out. (This idiomatic expression is said about people who do not work hard but like resting all the time.)

englishGloss: to attach, to stick, to affix.
to paste on, to put up.

examples.english: I stuck stamps on the envelope. She caused those two people to have a big fight. (lit. 'stirred them up into a fight.')
All the expenditure for building that monastery was covered by him.
Adorned with bones, the crazy Tsang ba Heruga compiled the religious songs of Milarepa.
He stuck a nice picture on the wall. (Note that {ri mo} in this context means poster or large photograph. Pictures are usually hung -{skon} rather than stuck {sbyar}.)

englishGloss: to spell a word out loud.

examples.english: When first studying Tibetan, one needs to read (each word) by spelling it out loud. The manner of spelling words out loud is a unique feature of the Tibetan language.

englishGloss: to have a body part fall asleep.

examples.english: Because I have been sitting for a long time, my leg has fallen asleep and I can't get going.
Mother, please only put a small amount of Sichuan peppercorn into the dish. Otherwise, (my) tongue will become numb, and the food will be flavourless.
Because he had a stroke, half his body is paralyzed and he can't move about. ({grib phog pa} also means to be defiled or have some kind of contamination.)
He did this work voluntarily. Dekyi is voluntarily doing all the small household chores.
It's very important to be self-motivated when studying. I voluntarily sang a song. (Note that {rang 'gul} is the verbal compound used in this sentence.)
We should voluntarily serve our parents.

commentsEnglish: An alternative spelling for this entry is {ma bskul dang len byed}.

englishGloss: to wrongfully or unjustly accuse or blame.

examples.english: I was wrongfully accused by that scoundrel. He did not kill anyone. The charge is completely unjust. (i.e., he is completely innocent of the charge.)
If you have wrongfully accused someone, it will become clear in the end.
Don't wrongfully accuse me.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He lied to you. Yesterday, I didn't go out all day.
You'd better not lie; it's not good. If you lie, people won't trust you.

commentsEnglish: {ma 'bin shod} is semantically related to {brin}, which means 'to sell.' It literally means 'to say something that you can't sell off,'. A common expression in Lhasa is {mi 'di rbad de ma 'bin red} - 'That person is a complete liar.'
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to joke in a sarcastic way.

examples.english: He says things to me in a really sarcastic way. Don't mock him. He will get angry.

commentsEnglish: This entry literally means 'to beautify that which is not.'
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to look upon or use as an example.

examples.english: I just simply had to look at those beautiful flowers. (lit. 'I was helplessly compelled'.) Son, you should look upon the better children as (an example). (Note that {mig lta byed} is a verbalised compound.)
When crossing a road, unless you look both ways, there is a risk of being hit by a car. ({yar mar} is lit. 'up and down'.)
Would it be alright if you show me that watch for sale?
He only talks, but never shows anything. (i.e., as proof.) I am going to show my plan to the leader.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to get first hand experience or knowledge.

examples.english: I witnessed Tibetan expertise first hand, when I saw the majesty of the Potala Palace.
A. Did he acquire first hand knowledge of that situation? B. He did.
I am completely astonished with the transfomations in the world, which I have seen with my own eyes.
By winking, she strongly indicated to me not to say anything. (i.e., not to let on or spill the beans.)
That man is really winking at me. I wonder why?

commentsEnglish: Blinking is often done in conjunction with a slight head movement, usually to indicate to someone else to not say something or not to move forward in the speaker's direction. Or it can also be used positively to indicate to someone to say something or to proceed in your direction. There does also appear to be a secondary usage which is similar to how a man or women in the West might wink to someone of the opposite sex.

examples.english: Some spouses get enormously jealous. Being very jealous, is really not a good habit.
That girl gets very jealous. Jealousy always exists between couples.

commentsEnglish: {mig gzer rgyag} is usually related to romantic jealousy. This entry is also spelled {mig ser rgyag}.

englishGloss: to put on glasses or sunglasses.

examples.english: The person over there wearing glasses is our teacher. If I don't wear glasses when reading, I can't see clearly. (lit. 'when looking at letters...')
He's wearing clay glasses and so didn't see it. (This idiomatic expression is said about someone who is not very discerning.)
That child didn't chew the food, but swallowed it whole. Swallow that medicine straight away.
Don't swallow this medicine. Suck on it.
There are a few places that have had a famine after a damaging snowstorm. Even if I were afflicted by famine, I wouldn't come begging at your doorstep. (i.e., I don't want anything from you at all.)
He related to me that he had come from a place ravaged by famine.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to suck on something by putting between your gum and cheek.

examples.english: Even though our grandmother does not have any pearl teeth, she still likes gnawing on dried cheese very much.
Don't bite lollies. (You) should suck on them. Gnaw on this powdered cheese. It's delicious.
(I) think that if rubbish is burned within cities, it could be very harmful to people's health.
He is burning leaves.
(Someone) said that a gun was shot last night and somebody was killed.
I fired a gun into the air to scare off a thief.

englishGloss: to divine, to do a divination.

examples.english: I went to the monk for a divination to see whether or not I would have good fortune.
He performed a divination for me, but it was not so accurate. The divination that the monk performed for me came true.

englishGloss: to drive a car or motor vehicle.

examples.english: A. Do you like driving? B. I do, but I don't have a license.
He's an experienced driver, so let your mind be at ease. (lit. 'he's an old driver.') If a vehicle is driven too fast, there will be an accident.

commentsEnglish: The expression {dpe bsags}, in the second sentence of example two, is a colloquial expression meaning that there is no hope for a good outcome or that 'we're done for'.

englishGloss: to like, to be interested in.
to agree, to be in accord with.

examples.english: A. Do you agree with her viewpoint? B. I don't know what to say (about that).
The heart pursues it's desires like a donkey outracing a horse. (This proverb means 'our passion is tireless when roused into action.')
A. Do you like that gift she bought? B. I do.
(My) superiors agreed that I could go to mainland China to study. (lit. 'it was agreed from above.') I don't think that the parents of those two would consent to (their) love.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Those people have a very strong liking for playing mahjong these days. Last night, we played mahjong all night.
These days, wedding reception places and places for celebrations are full of mahjong players.
It's a waste of time to always play mahjong.

commentsEnglish: {mA cang} is a Chinese loan word. In contemporary Lhasa, {sbag} is the same as the Chinese game {mA cang}.

examples.english: If there is war, it will cause immeasurable hardship for the common people.
Last night, that couple fought all night.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: How can peace emerge from nothing but a back-and-forth battle?
In the end, from the battles they waged against others, their own homeland was destroyed.

commentsEnglish: This entry is very similar to {dmag rgyag}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Insulting others is a very bad habit. Some students are degrading the teacher. (Note that {byed} is the verbaliser here.)
If you insult others too much, it indicates that you have faults of your own. (Note that {byed} is the verbaliser here.) You'll hurt yourself if you insult a leader.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: It's good for a person to be humble, no matter who they are. On the peak of a high mountain, water cannot stay gathered together, but on a low place lotus flowers grow. (This is a proverb.)
You are beautiful in the eyes of others, if you can be modest and not vain.
He is normally a modest person, so everyone respects and likes him.

commentsEnglish: This entry can also be verbalised with the {bzung} - the past tense of {'dzin}. The proverb in example one means, 'It is better to be lowly and have company than be lofty and alone.'

englishGloss: to curse, cuss or swear at someone.
to put a curse on someone.

examples.english: That women swore at us a lot. It is not good to swear at other people.
If a sage puts a curse on someone, it will happen.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to get a wound, sore or cut.

examples.english: I wasn't taking care when chopping up the vegetables and so I cut my hand. This tree has a split in it.
Physical wounds heal well, but wounds of the heart do not heal so easily.
They fought (each other) and inflicted many wounds.
When sheep transport salt, (they) get many sores from the packs. {Note that {khal rma} means 'sack sores.')

englishGloss: to use as a basis for.

examples.english: This building's foundation has been laid very well. Children need a firm foundation for their studies.
When you are young, a good foundation of knowledge needs to be established.
Not only were many of our soldiers wounded in the war, but there was also death.
Two soccer players injured their legs.
They injured innocent civilians during the war. A few days ago, we seriously injured the enemy soldiers.
Unless a horse is shoed, it can not go far. He finished shoeing all the horses and mules.
If people aren't careful, that dog will bite (them.) A dog bit my leg.

commentsEnglish: In Lhasa dialect, {so rgyag} is more commonly used than {rmug}. {rmug} is used in Shigatse dialect. {rmug} also means, 'to bark', though in Lhasa dialect {'chang} is much more commonly used for 'to bark'.

examples.english: A. Do you know how to plough? B. Far from knowing how to plough, I haven't even seen it (being done).
In Tibet, during March and April, farmers plough the fields.
If a car hits someone, then the driver needs to pay for that person's medical expenses.
The government paid for grandma's medical bill. We have to pay for our own medical expenses.
A. That drunkard has bruises on his face. B. Oh dear, he probably fell down and bruised (himself).
That boxer was badly bruised. (Note that {sbog sun} is an English loan word.)

commentsEnglish: {smug thig} is also spelled {rmug thig}.

examples.english: In summer, a lot of fog surrounds the mountains. If there is fog, it is not easy for planes to land.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to pray or to say prayers.

examples.english: That old lady said many prayers in front of the Buddha.
Everyday, mother prays in front of the shrine.
Every morning, I pray for there to be no war and no famine. ({'debs} is pronounced {btab}.)

commentsEnglish: {smon lam 'debs} is invariably pronounced {smon lam btab}.

examples.english: A. During a Muslim fast, are (they) allowed to drink water? B. I only know about the fasts during which (they are) forbidden to eat food.

The most frightening thing for me is fasting. The reason being that usually my stomach is a bottom-less pit. ({kha sla po} means 'weak mouth' and is an idiom for eating a lot or giving into food easily.)
It seems that the rinpoche is fasting.

commentsEnglish: The practise of {smyung gnas} can allow for a small intake of food, usually at lunch time. Meat is never eaten during {smyung gnas} and it is common to combine fasting with a period of not speaking to anyone - {ngag gcod byed}.

examples.english: Where are you going acting like such a fool? Oh, that child is acting like a fool and is even stepping over food containers.
Don't act like a fool!

englishGloss: to squat, to sit on one's haunches.

examples.english: Our child is able to sit up by herself now. That person is squatting down and eating food.
Sit up straight.
A. Are they cleaning? B. No, they finished cleaning just now.
Our grandmother cleans the house everyday.

englishGloss: to have a phobia of something.

examples.english: He has developed a real phobia of ice because he has fallen down on it many times.
The activity of climbing a mountain really frightened me this time.
My body is cramped and (I) feel sick.
Please don't make that noise. It grates on my teeth. (Note here that in U.S. English one might say that noise makes my skin crawl.)
The children are arguing with each other about the amount of snacks (they should get). ({rnang pa} can also mean 'gifts, treats, money or a tip.')
What is the point of you two arguing over something so small?

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The girl was abducted by bandits.
The situation of some evil people kidnapping children for monetary gain is increasing. (This sentences has some literary features.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: They are now appearing before the court because they took those fields by force.
I am resolute that I will not obey those who (try to) force me to do something without reason.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Germany invaded many countries during the Second World War.
The evil practice of invasion, waged back and forth by nations, has been going on continuously from antiquity to the present.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: To rape a woman is to commit a serious crime. He raped a small girl and so now he has been thrown in prison. ( lit. 'he was packed up from above.' This is an idiomatic epxression for putting someone in jail.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to force on, to impose on.

examples.english: He didn't do anything wrong, but he was accused of a crime. Even if chubas are forced onto children these days, they still won't wear them. ({gyon} is pronounced {gon}.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is not common in the spoken register.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to force, to coerce, to intimidate.

examples.english: If children are encouraged to study by being coerced, there will not be a good outcome.
There are still a few places where people are forced to get married. (i.e., against their will.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: My bike is completely rusted. It is easy for iron to rust in summer.
The car rusted because it was left out in the rain for a long time.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: The extinction of precious animals is one of the world's worst tragedies.
If weeds can be completely destroyed, a good harvest will result.
Investigating thieves is police work.
One of the best habits is examining one's own heart and investigating one's own behaviour.

Through investigating, experts from both inside and outside the country have found many ancient remnants in Tibet. (Note that the use of {yod} reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.)

commentsEnglish: This entry is usually associated with a police or legal investigation.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: It's difficult to get information about someone when looking for them in a big city. He found out about that situation.
There are still some lost Tibetan cultural relics which haven't been found. (i.e., haven't been found out about.)

englishGloss: to hold, to consider, to count as.
to include, to adhere to, to respect.

examples.english: A. Please count this money again. B. I counted it a few times. Usually (I) don't make mistakes.
Tibetans consider giving charity to the poor a good habit.
We always esteem English teachers. Because you are an old person, I regard you highly.
If you disregard the law, in the end, nothing good will come of it. (i.e., good consequences will not be forthcoming.)

commentsEnglish: {ljags rtsis} is the honorific of this verb only when the meaning is 'to count'.

examples.english: A. What work are you doing? B. I am painting the cabinet.
Painting cabinets is good work. There are more shoe shiners on Lhasa's streets now.

englishGloss: to spray paint, varnish or lacquer.

examples.english: The house has been painted white. I varnished those old desks.
A. Are (they) still building up this wall? B. (They) still have about one full metre to build up.
I've heard he bribed the leader in order to get a good job.
Those who obtain their position through bribery are the absolute worst.

commentsEnglish: {rtsibs ma bcag} literally means 'to prod or break someone's rib'. It refers to the behaviour of trying to get something out of someone by giving money or extending favours. The correct present tense is {rtsibs ma gcog} but this is rarely used.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I am counting money. I have finished counting out all her earned salary.

The custom of making astrological calculations at birth and death is very widespread in Tibet. If you continue to do bad deeds, I will make you accountable for it. ({ldebs rtsis rgyag} is a fixed verbalised compound. See the record for {ldebs rtsis rgyag}.)
A. Please calculate the bill. (lit. 'the price of the food'.) B. OK, here is the change.
He disregarded the laws of the country and used power for (his own) private purposes. It's probably inappropriate to disrespect the customs of this place.
Some bad children disregard (their) parent's advice.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. What are you doing? B. I'm just playing.
I exercise from six to seven o'clock every morning.
A. Shall we play hide and seek? B. Sure.
I got played by them. (This idiomatic expression means 'they played me as the fool.')
There is nowhere to put books. They will have to be placed one on top of the other.

The weather is very cold today. Please put some more clothes on the children. (lit. 'the weather is very poor'. Note that the imperative form is properly written as {rtsegs}, but in this particular case it is pronounced {rtsog}.)
It is the responsibilty of students to do better and better. (lit. 'to stack good on top of good.')

englishGloss: to stack, to pile on top.

examples.english: Please stack up those empty flower plots.
If cups are stacked up too high, they will break. (lit. 'if cups are stacked up in too many layers...')

commentsEnglish: {rtseg thog rgyag} is also spelled {rtse thog rgyag}.

examples.english: A. Who wrote this story book? B. Do Kharwa wrote it. He has written many books. (Do Kharwa was a famous Tibetan writer who lived during the time of the fifth Dalai Lama.)
The new song has been composed with a nice melody, but the words are not very well composed.
A. When will (you) begin that work? B. After a few days (I) will start.

commentsTibetan: རྩོམ་པ་པོ། རྩོམ་མཁན། རྩོམ་ཡིག ཆེད་རྩོམ། རྩོམ་རིག རྩོམ་རིག་སྐད་ཆ།
commentsEnglish: In Lhasa dialect, the present tense {rtsom} is commonly used for all tenses. {'go rtsom} in example three is a compound verb.

examples.english: There are many people who show respect to him. All the students show respect to the teacher.
I respect you.

commentsEnglish: The term {sku zhabs} in the first sentence of example one, is referring to a monk. Few people use this as a form of address in Lhasa dialect unless addressing a monk. However, {sku zhabs} is frequently used in Tibetan dubbed television programs to mean 'Sir' or 'Mister'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to get a pimple or heat rash.

examples.english: That girl has got pimples on her face. My body has all of a sudden got a really extensive rash. I wonder why?
A. Can this window be welded? B. No. Your window is aluminium.
A. My bike is broken. Is there a welding place around here? B. I don't know for sure whether there is one around here. (lit. 'I don't know clearly.')
Please weld this.

englishGloss: to filter, to strain, to sift or sieve.

examples.english: Farmers sift grain and make it clean. Sift this sand and separate out all the small stones.
I will sift rapeseed. He is sifting rice. (Note that {tshags rgyag} is used here instead of {tshag ma rgyag}.)
He sifted sand.

commentsTibetan: ཚགས་རྒྱག ཚགས་ཟེ་རྒྱག ཚགས་མ། ཁྲོལ་མ ཁྲོལ་མ་རྒྱག ཁྲོལ་བུ། ཁྲོལ་ཚགས། ཁྲོལ་ཚགས་རྒྱག ཁོང་གིས་ཇ་ལ་ཚགས་རྒྱག་གིས། ཆུ་ཚགས་རྒྱག ཇ་ཚགས་རྒྱག
commentsEnglish: Both {tshags ma rgyag} and {tshags rgyag} are commonly used in Lhasa dialect.

examples.english: A. Have you finished making the food? B. (I've) finished.
A. Have you finished writing the letter? B. I still have a little to write, but I'll finish quickly.
A. Has she arrived yet? B. (She) is still to arrive.

englishGloss: to perform a song of call-and-response.

examples.english: We spent the entire night playing a Tibetan call-and-response singing game. There's a lot of black humour during a Tibetan song of call-and-response.
How can one find time to sing a Tibetan call-and-reponse song these days?

commentsEnglish: {tshig rgyag rgyag} commonly occurs between men and women working in a field. Sometimes people try to outwit each other through the meaning of the verses. This is typically practiced in farming areas.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to have entered or gone into.
to be put inside or inserted.

examples.english: I heard that his oldest daughter has gained entry to university. ({zer gyis} literally means, 'it is said'.) Food expenses are not included in the daily wage.
(His) hand went in between the machine and caused a serious wound. The book has been put under the box and (I) wasn't able to take it out.

commentsEnglish: The volitional, transitive counterpart {'dzud} is rarely said in Lhasa dialect.

englishGloss: to release or free a life.
to let someone off from being punished.

examples.english: Purchasing animals and setting them free is very beneficial to both you and others. (Note that this sentence refers to the accumulation of merit. {srog} literally means 'life'.)
In the fourth month of the Tibetan calendar, people do virtuous deeds by setting many lives free. (Note that the 'fourth month' here refers to Saga Dawa.)
I've let you off this time!
I'm sewing children's clothes. That person is very good at stitching shoes.
Before buying that motorbike, I am going to test it out. Shouldn't we experiment first to see whether or not we can finish this job?
My friend is an experimental chemist. (i.e., a chemical scientist.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I guess that he has wasted all his money on mahjong.
Please guess. How old do you think I am? My guess is that she will arrive in Lhasa tomorrow.
According to the estimations of science, the world's temperatures are increasing each year.

englishGloss: to appear to be confused, uncertain.

examples.english: You shouldn't merely guess, but think well before responding to questions. (lit. 'think twelvefold' ( 3x4 = 12). This construction appears often in literary texts as well as in the spoken register.)
Those sellers are not weighing the sweets, but are cheating the small children with their estimates.
You should investigate the problem well and not (simply) guess. Don't guess, say it well. (i.e., think about what you are saying.)
I came without really knowing how to come. (Note that {tshod tshod} is verbalised with {tshod}.)

commentsEnglish: {sgro 'dogs bcad} in the example three literally means 'to cut away the feathers which have been attached to something'.

examples.english: A. Friend, aren't you able to control how much beer you drink? B. It's difficult to control. (Note that {tshod byed} is commonly used in this context.)
These days, I'm regulating the amount of chang I drink. The Nepalese are regulating the transportation of foreign goods.
Control your cigarette smoking a bit! Alright? (Note that {ong kog} is used to urge a child or a close friend to do something.)

englishGloss: to sense, to feel, to perceive.
to be aware of, to notice.

examples.english: A. Are my glasses at your house? ({lus} is pronounced {las}.) B. I didn't notice them.
A. Last night, a dog barked a lot. Were you aware of it? B. I wasn't. I fell completely asleep.
The meat has been cooked. Please eat. Unboiled potates shouldn't eat be eaten. (You'll) get sick.
A. Was the meat that was cooked yesterday cooked well? (Note that a pair of causative/resultative verbs is used.) B. It wasn't cooked so well.
This year there was a great rain storm, and so the ground is saturated with water. My coat is saturated with beer. (lit. 'by beer'.)
That person is always saturated with chang. (This idiomatic expression means that someone is an alcoholic.)
If you have high blood pressure, it is better if you put less salt on (your) food.
A. How much salt needs to be put in noodle soup? B. Put in as much as you think.
In accordance with the proverb that tea should have a little salt in it - while noodle soup should have more, (you) should not put much salt in tea.

englishGloss: to stop, to end, to terminate.

examples.english: After my father stopped smoking cigarettes, he took snuff.

We'll stop the lesson here for today. Construction work stops in Tibet during October. (In Tibet, construction stops at this time because it is too cold for cement to dry. Note that {mtshams 'jog} is verbalised with {byed}.)
We'll bring the lesson to a close here.

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense for this verb is {mtshams 'jog}, but {'jog} is rarely used in Lhasa dialect.

examples.english: What you said earlier and what you said later are not the same. (i.e., you are telling a lie.) The two personalities of that married couple are exactly the same.

englishGloss: to express, to show, to symbolize.

examples.english: A. What does this picture symbolise? B. It symbolises method and wisdom.
That boy expressed his love to his girlfriend by giving her a red flower.
You shouldn't crowd into a place where there are many old people. Those people are not queuing up at all. They are really squeezing in as they buy tickets.
A. Don't shove! B. What? You can't get a ticket without shoving.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to ask about the health of someone.

examples.english: I paid a visit to a sick patient. We are coming to visit you at your house.
Please give my regards to Drolma. (lit. 'in place of me.')
His father is visiting Europe now.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Where did you grow up? B. I grew up in Shigatse.

As for children, they grow up in the twinkling of a eye. (lit. 'those called children' - {phru gu zer yas de} is a common subject marker. {mig yug tsam cig} is a common idiomatic expression for a very short period. lit. 'a mere glance of the eye.' )
If you go near the stove, (your) clothes will get singed. I heard that today there was a fire and many houses were burned.
If you don't quickly turn off the stove, the meat will be completely burned.
A. Are you hot? B. No I'm not.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: A. Because you haven't kept your word, of course I got angry. B. What is the point of getting angry over such a small matter?
If you don't give money to those monk imposters, they get angry and fight.
Because he always lies to me, I got angry. Don't get angry. I will move the things straight away.
I wrung out the washing. ({'khru 'khru} is pronounced {khrang khru}.) The shoes are squashing (my) feet.
Son, if you squeeze a bird with (your) hand, won't it die? Because there were many people at the market today, I got really squashed.
According to a proverb, 'oil won't ooze from a squeezed flat rock, and butter won't emerge from a stirred river.' (This expression refers to work that won't produce any tangible result.)
Because the teacher really pressed them (with questions), they had to tell the truth.
We are holding an important meeting. A. Has the class already assembled? B. It has yet to assemble.
A. When will the class assemble? B. It will assemble at 9 o'clock.
Many people have assembled and are listening to the lama's teaching.

englishGloss: to tell on someone or betray them.
to let someone down, to lie, or to deceive.

examples.english: A. My new computer is for sale. B. Then, please sell it to me.
A. Is this type of hat for sale? B. If you want to buy it, I will sell it.
The three spies told on each other and in the end they all were arrested by the security office.
A. Yesterday, you let us all down. B. Sorry. Something very important turned up and so I was unable to come.
I betrayed him. (lit. 'sold him out.')

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Are you boiling rice? B. No. I'm frying vegetables.
Our neighbour's wife makes barley beer well. The other day I cooked noodles. It was delicious.

englishGloss: to search, to look for, to seek.

examples.english: A. Who are you looking for? B. I am looking for Drolma.
In order to get this work accomplished, (you) really must find someone you know. They are going to look for their lost friend.
Son, you probably have good eyes, please look for the needle.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He found out my secret. Don't copy (from someone else) on the exam. If you do that, you will be found out.
If someone discovers our situation, we will be punished. The robbery he committed was exposed.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to do something that exposes a secret or otherwise hidden situation.
to let the cat out of the bag, to spill the beans.

examples.english: At the meeting place, some people spilled the beans. ({'ga' shas} is more typically pronounced {kha shas}) From now on, don't give yourself away like that!

commentsEnglish: {dzor rtags gshom} usually means to expose someone else's situation to a third party, while {dzor rtags glod} means to expose yourself. Depending on context, {dzor rtags glod / bston} can be volitional or non-volitional. The verb {dzor} by itself, however, is always non-volitional (see ref#275). Note that {ngas dzor rtags stan sha} and {ngas dzor rtags shor song} both mean "I gave myself away" in a non-volitional sense, but the first expression indicates that I learned of my blunder some period after the fact, while the second expression means that I realized my blunder almost immediately.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The court makes criminals sign their names and also provide their fingerprints.
There's no way out of a financial debt when each party has stamped their fingerprint on the receipt.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A good friend points out (your) faults. He showed me the place by pointing.

commentsEnglish: {mdzub mo} means the forefinger or index finger.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Many warts appeared on my hand. If you get a wart, I wonder what you can do (to get rid of it)?

commentsEnglish: {mdzer pa} also means a knot in wood.

examples.english: A. When are you going to decorate your house? B. I don't have any plans at the moment. Renovating a house is really troublesome.
That girl's face has probably had cosmetic surgery. (Note that this sentence is not referring to make-up.)

The ceramic pot must have a crack in it. Lots of chang has leaked out. ({rdza ma} is a large ceramic pot used for brewing chang. {zag} is pronounced {'dzag}.) If a water jug bursts, then water will leak everywhere.
There is a lot of oil dripping from this car. ({snum} can also refer to petrol or gasoline in this context.)

commentsEnglish: {'dzag} is pronounced {'dzag} for all tenses. In sentence two of example one note that {chu ban} is also spelled {chu ben}.

examples.english: The police caught five thieves and took them to jail. Unless you hold on well with (your) hands, there is danger of falling.
If you don't hold the ball in (your) hand tightly, someone else will immediately steal it. ({'phrog} is typically pronounced {'phog}.)
I always strive to hold the right view.
If you are steadfast to your doctrine as you communicate your opinions, your meaning will be easier to understand.

commentsEnglish: {zungs} is an alternative spelling of the imperative form of this verb.

englishGloss: to arrest, to capture, to seize.

examples.english: The police arrested that bad person. I don't have the authority to arrest (people).
That country captured many bandits and banished them. (i.e., sent them to a place far away. {'bud} is pronounced {bid}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: In general, on the third day of the new year, prayer flags are customarily erected. There is a plan to establish a new hospital in that area.
A. Were you offered a cup? (i.e., 'Did you get a cup?' This question is often asked to guests.) B. Yes, I was.
If wanting a close friendship, (be willing) to point out the faults (of one another). (This expression is a proverbial saying.)

commentsTibetan: རྒྱན་འཛུགས། དངུལ་འཛུགས། འགོ་འཛུགས། མཛུབ་མོ་འཛུགས། ལྕང་མ་འཛུགས། པུས་མོ་འཛུགས།
commentsEnglish: An alternative past tense spelling of this entry is {gdzugs}. In example two, offering a cup indicates that the host wishes to pour some tea for the guest.

examples.english: There is much construction in Lhasa. In Beijing, modern constructions have been built extensively.
The main element involved in building the teaching force well is in supporting the teaching personnel. (This expression is a motivational directive and reflects written Tibetan.)
These days, the main business of Tibet is to build up the economy.
Rabbits sleep with their eyes open. (lit. 'without shutting their eyes'.) Shut your mouth. Don't say annoying things. (The imperative {tshums} is pronounced {btsum}.)
He has his eyes closed. Close your eyes. Open your mouth and I will give you a snack. (Note that {rngan pa} also means 'gifts' or 'tips'.)
Many flies have landed in my sweet tea. I really want to join this drama group.
A. Did you score any goals? B. I shot some, but none went in.
As I was entering the house, the robber fled through the window. ({bros} is pronounced {bos}.) In the past, I joined the army, but now I am in business.
Is it OK if I join in your game?
Please put out (your) bowl. I will give you a little tsampa. Son, hold out your hand. I will give you some snacks. (Note that {rngan pa} also means 'gifts' or 'tips'.)
I suffered a massive beating.

commentsEnglish: The verbal argument for the non-volitional sense is benefactive, transitive.

examples.english: A. Do you refrain from (eating) meat? B. Whenever there is an auspicious day, I do.
Because my stomach is not well, (I am) avoiding chilli. These days, he is abstaining from (drinking) beer.
A. Where shall we meet tomorrow? B. Aren't we meeting at the Guru bridge?

We came from all over the place and gathered in Tibet. Therefore, we have many kinds of customs and languages present. ({phyogs bzhi mtshams brgyad} means four directions and eight compass points. This is an idiomatic expression for 'everywhere'.)
A wide variety of spices are in this dish. (Note that the use of {cha tshang} here doesn't mean 'all' but rather 'a bunch'.)
Many fish would die, if dynamite were exploded in the water. We blew up our enemy's fortress.
He is catching fish by letting off explosives in the water. ({'dzin} is pronounced {zin}.)
A. Please knead the flour. Aren't we making dumplings? B. I (also) had the same thought. I kneaded it (the flour) just now.
There is great danger of someone getting run over by a car on that road over there. Horses trampled the crops. (Note that {zhing kha} here is referring to a field of crops.)
In the countryside, people use their feet to stamp down mud and make bricks. (i.e., mud bricks.)

englishGloss: to lose one's sense of smell.

examples.english: Whoever reaches such an old age will certainly lose some of their faculties. It is said that when dogs reach the age of nine, they lose their sense of smell.
It seems as though I have become completely senile. I'm forgetting everything.
He is really threathening her. You are threathening me, but I am not afraid.
They look threathening on the outside, but (I) don't think they really mean it.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to pose as, to impersonate, to pretend.

examples.english: Everywhere, one can see bad people posing as good.
Pretending to be on our side, he stole secret documents on numerous occasions over many years.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to display magical or miraculous powers.

examples.english: Milarepa performed many miracles and attracted disciples.
The practice of being able to do magic is a very difficult one.

englishGloss: to act in a deceptive way.

examples.english: He himself often pretends to be a scholar. However cunning you are, later on this will be exposed. (i.e., it all comes out in the wash.)

englishGloss: to be exposed as a fake or charlatan.

examples.english: That corrupt person was exposed and so immediately fled abroad.
The spy thought he would be exposed and so he killed himself.

commentsEnglish: {rdzun rkub} can be verbalised with both {rdol} and {lug}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: In Lhasa, how many people are there who disguise themselves as beggars! (This is a reference to people who dress up as monks and beg for donations. {ga tshod} is pronounced {ga tshad}.)
Those who disguise themselves as lamas really are wolves wearing sheep skins. (i.e., wolves in sheep's clothing.)

I heard that those people not only make fake things, they also make fake medicine. (Often the construction {ma zad} requires {yang} -which means 'also'- in literary Tibetan, but in spoken it is often omitted.)
There is nothing worse than making up false things. ({skad cha} means, 'talk, speech, words.')

englishGloss: to pull up, to roll up.

examples.english: If you don't pull up your sleeves, they'll get soaked with water. Please roll up the curtain. It is blocking the sun.
Keep your eyes peeled and look. (lit. 'roll back your eyes and look.')

commentsEnglish: This use of this verb is similar to {sdog}.

englishGloss: to pound, to pulverise, to crush.

examples.english: A. Have you already finished crushing the chilli? B. (I) have. Young girl, please crush the brown sugar.
If you don't control yourselves, they will pulverise (you). He always tramples on those who are meek. (lit. 'crushes those who are meek.')

englishGloss: to run out, to come to the end, to be finished.

examples.english: A. Is the Great Tibetan to Chinese Dictionary out of stock? B. It is. In a few weeks, new ones should arrive.
My money has not run out. (We've) completed the meaning of that section. (i.e., the explanation of that particular section of text has been completed.)

About one hundred individuals, including Master Tumi, were sent to India to learn (a system of) writing. (This sentence reflects literary Tibetan. More colloquially it would be said {...yi ge bslab gar btang pa red}.)
Princess Wencheng was sent from Tra An to Tibet, to be a bride. (The use of {brdangs} here reflects literary Tibetan. {btang} is commonly used in this context.)
Please stuff this book down the edge of that sack.

commentsEnglish: The first two example sentences are not commonly said.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The clothes have been stuffed into the bag. If those things won't fit, then stuff them in a bit and they will fit. ({chud} is pronounced {chur}.)
A. Which bag did you put that thing in? B. I put it in the yellow bag over there.

englishGloss: to finish or drink a whole glass at once.

examples.english: He drank all the chang in his glass. Let's all drink down in one!

commentsEnglish: In colloquial Australian English, to drink everything in your glass at once is called 'to scull'.

examples.english: After studying Tibetan, I will serve the Tibetan people with all my heart.
Serving the elderly is the responsibility of society. (This expression is a motivational directive.) It would be good if we could put such service to the people into real practice.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He was completely disgraced as his many acts of corruption became widely publicised.
I'm not ashamed if I am unable to leave behind a legacy. ({byas rjes} is lit. 'great achievements.')

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Those flowers have bloomed nicely. I think those flowers are about to bloom.
The monks have started to read scriptures. (Note the volitional usage here.) I will light the butter lamp.

commentsEnglish: The second meaning of this verb 'to start' is used for specific actions such as beginning to read scriptures or lighting butter lamps. When the verb takes on a volitional sense, the verbal argument is direct ergative.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: This wall still needs to be plastered. Plastering needs to be done evenly.

englishGloss: to do maintenance work, to repair.

examples.english: These days, many people are doing maintenance work on Ganden monastery. This palace is currently being repaired.
I doubt whether you can get rich quick just from farming. If machinery is used for agricultural work, the output will be greater.
Farming is the kind of work that each year has no end to it.

englishGloss: to investigate, to survey, to explore.

examples.english: This situation needs to be thoroughly investigated. Since you haven't researched well, don't say un-informed things.
He's a researcher of philosophy. (Note that {tshad ma} translates the Sanskrit word 'pramana' and is often translated in English as 'logic'.) I'm researching Buddhism.

commentsEnglish: In the first sentence of example one {'jug mthar} means 'to the end.'

examples.english: Today, our administrators are checking residence permits very closely.
The teacher strictly checked the students' assignments.
My Uncle is from the work unit which investigates regulations.
The first requirement of having a healthy body is to check the food one eats.
These days, police are checking driver's licenses.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to tell, to say, to ask.

examples.english: A. I am going to request a name for my child. B. Should I offer my help? (i.e., would you like my help?). A. Thank you.
A. Please have some tea. B. No thank you. I won't have any. (lit. 'I don't wish to request it from you.') I told you many times, but you don't listen.
I need to go and ask that leader something. If you have a book of this kind, I would kindly ask you for it.
The majority of Lhasa's elderly people always go on religious visits. ({chos mjal} is literally 'to meet the Dharma.')
A. Can I pour you a cup of hot water? B. Thank you.

commentsTibetan: ཀྲུང་གོའི་དབུ་ཁྲིད་ཚོས་ཕྱི་རྒྱལ་གྱི་སྐུ་མགྲོན་ལ་ཕེབས་སྐྱེལ་ཞུས་གནང་སོང་། ཕེབས་སྐྱེལ་ཞུ། ཕེབས་བསུ་ཞུ། དགོངས་པ་ཞུ། དགོངས་དག་ཞུ། མགོ་བཏགས་ཞུ། སྙན་སེང་ཞུ། ཞབས་འདྲེན་ཞུ། ཆོག་མཆན་ཞུ། སྐྱབས་བཅོལ་ཞུ། རྒྱང་མཇལ་ཞུ། མཇལ་ཁ་ཞུ། རྟེན་འབྲེལ་ཞུ། དབུ་སྐོར་ཞུ། q䞄ਜrcº��������������������
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to check a manuscript for mistakes.

examples.english: A book must be thoroughly proof read before publication. Unless this book is proof read well, mistakes will be perpetuated.
If you check my English, I will check your Tibetan.

englishGloss: to submit a written petition or request.

examples.english: I am going to submit a written request to the work unit concerning a foreign joint venture.
A. When did you submit your request for retirement? B. One year has past since I submitted it, and I still haven't received permission.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be afraid, to be scared.

examples.english: A. If demons are talked about, are you scared? B. Oh, please dont talk (about them). I get scared and can't sleep at night.
A. Last night when it thundered loudly, I was very scared. B. There's no need to be frightened. (You) can get used to it.
That crazy person is always scared of me.

commentsTibetan: ཞེད་སྣང་ལང་། སྐྱེ། བྱེད། ཞེད་སྣང་ཚ་པོ། སྐྲག དངངས་སྐྲག འཇིགས། འཇིགས་མེད།

examples.english: He (tried) very hard to scare me, but I didn't get frightened. It is not good to frighten children.
What you said doesn't intimidate me.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be attached to, to be fond of.

examples.english: I feel attached to my homeland. People become extremely attached to their homeland as they grow older.
She is near the point of death, yet is still attached to possessions and wealth.

englishGloss: to be sick of, to be fed up with.

examples.english: I always eat this food, and I'm so sick of it. I am really fed up with her bad behaviour.
He was disenchanted with life in the human realm and left for a mountain hermitage.
Long ago, most Tibetan people travelled long distances by horse. These days, most Tibetans know how to ride a bicycle.
A. Do you know how to ride a bicycle? (i.e., I have some doubt that you know how to.) B. Huh-uh, I don't know how to ride a bike at all.
Yesterday, I rode a horse to Pembo.
The ox and the cow mate. The yak (male) mates with the dri (female). (Or more literally, 'the ox mounts the cow...')

What you did is like the proverb of descending from a horse and riding a donkey. (i.e., what you did was very unwise. This proverb is used when someone gives up something that is good for something that it is worse. For example, if someone gives up a good job for a lesser one.)

commentsTibetan: ཉིས་བཞོན་རྒྱག བཞོན་དྲེལ། གྲུ་བཞོན། མོ་ཊ་བཞོན། བཞོན་ཕྱུགས། བཞོན་མ། ངས་རྟ་བཞོན་བྱས་ཕྱིན་པ་ཡིན། ང་རྟ་བཞོན་ནས་ཕྱིན་པ་ཡིན། ངས་རྟ་ལ་བཞོན་བྱས་ཕྱིན་པ་ཡིན།
