commentsEnglish: When this verb is used in Lhasa dialect the ergative and the {la don} particle are often omitted. See glossary for further discussion. In example one, the object, {rta} (horse), is in the dative to emphasise that horses were ridden as opposed to another form of transport. In Shigatse dialect, {gru bzhon} means both to travel by boat or to row a boat. Similarly, in Shigatse dialect, {mo Ta bzhon} can mean to travel by car or to drive a car. The honorific form of this verb {chibs} is actually the imperative form of the present tense {'chib}, but most people write {chibs} for all tenses.

examples.english: I am going to the barber to get (my) hair cut. My child doesn't like to get his hair cut at all.
Yesterday, she cut my hair. But I shaved (my) beard myself. Nomads don't cut their hair, but prefer to let it grow. (lit. 'to let hair accumulate'.)
She sang me a nice song. I don't know how to sing very well.

englishGloss: to hold or take as the basis or foundation.
to do in accordance with, to base on.

examples.english: I am working in accordance with the protocol (set in place by) my superiors. They worked in accordance with national law.
An explanation of any culture is credible if grounded in systematic thought.
Aren't we doing research on the basis of this book? We are going to implement (the work) in accordance with the contract.

commentsEnglish: This compound is also spelled {gzhi bzung}.

examples.english: A. I threw a stone at a dog. B. When a dog is resting, don't throw stones (at it).
I threw a stone at the vulture, but I didn't hit it. He hit me with a stick.
He hit his wife with (his) fist. If you hit a monastery's dog, the lama will be offended. (This is a proverb.)
That child assists enormously with her parents' work.
If a leader doesn't have people who lend support, it will be hard to do any work.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Have the flowers in your courtyard blossomed nicely? B. Yes. Since the weather has been warm, the flowers bloomed earlier this year.

commentsEnglish: {shar}, 'to arise/emerge', is also commonly used in the same way as {bshad}
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to melt, to smelt, to dissolve.

examples.english: If butter is put out into the sun, it will quickly melt. The sun melted the frost.
This object was molded from smelt iron. The snow will melt right away because of the hot sun.
It is so hot that my body fat will melt. (Note that this is said as a joke on a really hot day.) If ice cream isn't eaten quickly, it will melt.

commentsEnglish: An alternative past tense spelling of this verb is {bzhur}.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: Lhasa's Jokhang and Ramoche were both built in the 7th century.
A. Have you finished painting the thangkha? B. (I've) finished. A. Is father up? B. (He) isn't up yet.

commentsEnglish: The present and future tense of this verb are also spelled {bzheng}.

examples.english: A. Do you want to go and eat? B. Oh, yeah sure.
A. Have you finished eating? B. We have.
This rabbit eats a lot of grass, doesn't it? This car uses a lot of oil. (Note that {snum} could also refer to petrol or gasoline in this context.)
If this flour is used to deep-fry pastries, it will use up lots of oil. ({kha zas} is pronounced {khab zas}.)

commentsEnglish: An alternative past tense spelling of this verb is {zos}.

examples.english: My head is very itchy. This is probably because I haven't washed my hair for a long time. When a wound is healing, it becomes itchy.
Perhaps something good will come to me, (since) my palm is itchy. (Take note that this expression underscores the notion that an itchy palm symbolises the potential for good fortune.)
My hand is itching to smack that scoundrel! (This expression is idiomatic.)
My head is very itchy. I better wash it. (Note that {za} is sometimes used by itself.)
My pen fell out of my bag. (I) don't know where it fell. I fell from the horse.
The old lady fell when descending the stairs. A ball bearing fell off my bike. ({sran ma} is pronounced {kran ma}.)
At the end of autumn, leaves fall from trees.

commentsEnglish: Although the verbs {'gyel} or {ril} can be used in a similar sense, these verbs are usually used for people falling over on level ground. {ril} is more common in Lhasa dialect than {'gyel}.

englishGloss: to wear out, to run out.

examples.english: The heel of my shoe is completely worn down. ({lham gog} is pronounced {han gog}.) That chair is completely worn out. ({rgya'u} is a very typical Lhasa way of saying 'very, totally or completely'. It doesn't have an established written form.)
If the nib of a pen is worn, it is not good for writing. A. Is the bike tire worn out? B. No, it is punctured.
The doorstep to the house is completely worn down. I have completely run out of options for (my) business. (lit. 'all (my) business methods have been exhausted.')

englishGloss: to cause a riot, uprising or disturbance.

examples.english: While there is peace now, what need is there to cause a disturbance? That child is causing endless trouble in that family. ({phru gu} is typically pronounced {spu gu}.)
Some people deliberately cause uprisings in society.
Some of the naughtiest students in the class cause havoc when the teacher is not there, making it impossible for any study to occur. ({phru gu} is typically pronounced {spu gu}.)

englishGloss: to be pricked, to be pierced.

examples.english: Yesterday, when I was touching a rose, (I) got pricked by a thorn. Since this peg is stuck deeply in the ground, it is diffcult to take out.
I was struck by what you said. Everyone is really attracted to that girl.
When giving birth to (her) child, that mother seems to have experienced intense pain. I have a stomach ache, so I am going to take some medicine.
I have sharp head pains.
One of our principle aims is to improve production by combining both theory and practice.
He brought together concepts of the past and the present and wrote a new poetry book.

commentsEnglish: {zung sbrel byed} is also spelled {zung 'brel byed}.

examples.english: All the writing in pencil has been erased.
The teacher's writing on the blackboard still hasn't been erased.
Some flowers close up at nighttime. That child is closing her eyes and nodding off.
My sore has closed up.

englishGloss: to insult in a roundabout way.
to be sarcastic in a negative way.

examples.english: If you have something to say, say it directly. You don't have any cause to be sarcastic with me. ({kha thug} is also spelled {khar thug}.)
He still makes implications about others while his behaviour remains an eye sore.
Even if (someone) is sarcastic with him, he doesn't get it. I have never insulted someone indirectly.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: That person will make a mess of things, unless you are cautious with him. Unless you are careful when arriving at an intersection, you will be squashed by those crazy taxi drivers. (Note that there does not appear to be a standard spelling of {Ti sil} - taxi.)
Unless you take precautions when you eat out, there is a real risk of catching an infectious disease.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: (They) say that in the end those two became close and got married. (lit. 'they got joined together'. {mjug ma} is pronounced {gzu gu}.)
A. Shouldn't these extra things be combined together? B. If they are combined together, they will get all mixed up.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Please put this needle in the door curtain. (This means to sew it partially in so it won't fall or get lost.) Who is that guy going around with a knife clamped to his waist? (lit. 'knife put on his waist'.)

commentsEnglish: {gzer} as a noun means 'nail' or 'spike'.

examples.english: Since I hammered some nails into that old desk, now it has turned out well.
The gates of those old monasteries have iron nails hammered in a straight line. If (you) get iron nails hammered into (your) shoes, there will be quite a loud noise (when you walk).

commentsEnglish: The second sentence in example two refers to how shoes were once repaired in Tibet. Nails were hammered into the sole. This practice meant that after the shoes were repaired, a loud noise could be heard as nails on the bottom struck the ground when walking. Some leather shoes are still repaired this way, though this method is not common anymore.

examples.english: A. Excuse me, what are you planning to make for lunch? (hyper-corrective.) B. I have already made two vegetable dishes and a soup. Shall (I) send somebody out to buy bread? A. Yeah, that's right.
A variety of things are made from factories. Japan makes excellent cars and electrical goods. (Note that {ri pin} is a Chinese loan word.)
The teacher corrected my homework very thoroughly. That bad person had two children with that young woman and then left her.
A. Are you able to fix my computer? B. Probably (I) can.

commentsTibetan: ཆེད་མངགས་བཟོ། རྫུས་མ་བཟོ། ཁ་ལག་བཟོ། ཐང་བཟོ། བག་ལེབ་བཟོ། ཅ་ལག་བཟོ། དུས་བཀག་བཟོ། རྙིད་ཏོ་བཟོ།
commentsEnglish: This verb is also used in a similar way to {bzo bcos rgyag}, i.e., to fix, repair or correct. The second sentence of example two could be said {ga re bzo gnang rtsis yod} without the interrogative particle {pas}. See 'hyper-corrective' in the glossary for further discussion.

englishGloss: to correct, to repair, to alter.

examples.english: A. Teacher, have you corrected our homework? B. I am correcting it now.
That jerk, he altered what I said and reported it to the leader.
I will repair my house again this year. I repaired my old car and sold it.
Because I have been putting up with it, he continues to abuse me. If they behave in such an evil way, we will not be able to tolerate it.

englishGloss: to be left with no choice.

examples.english: That person was destitute and stole. We were left on the mountain for many days and so had no choice but to kill and eat a rabbit. ({ri kong} is correctly spelled {ri bong}.)
If people are desperate, they will even prostrate to a dog. (This proverb means people will do anything when they are desperate.)

commentsEnglish: {'u thug} is similar in meaning to {thabs zad}.

examples.english: You don't need to boast. It's common knowledge to all of us what kind of person you are.
He always brags in the presence of other people. Oh how you like to brag! ({dga' ba la A} is often said {dga' la A}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be unable to handle because of differing amounts.

examples.english: A. Are you able to cope with this work? B. I am not able to. (i.e., I don't have the necessary ability.)
I can't cope with doing the work of so many people.
The outside of this jacket is too small to handle the excessive inner lining.

commentsEnglish: The primary meaning of this verb is for something not to be able to cover over something else. For example, when the outside cover is too small to fully wrap around a book, one would say {'ub so 'du ba mi 'dug}. This verb can describe clothes that are too small and don't fully cover one's arms. The verb can also be applied to people who have buck teeth, and hence the expression {khong gi kha 'ub so 'du ba mi 'dug}.

englishGloss: to use or hurl a sling.

examples.english: All shepherds are skilled at hurling a sling.
A. Do you know how to use a sling? B. I don't know how to.
If you don't know how to use a sling, you'll hit yourself in the head.

englishGloss: to emit light, to shine, to glow.

examples.english: Shoes will shine if rubbed well. I wonder what she has applied to her (face)? Her face is shinning.
That diamond is really sparkling. That solar oven is really glowing.

commentsTibetan: དཔྲད་ཀོག་ནས་འོད་རྒྱག་གིས། གངས་རི་ནས་འོད་རྒྱག་གིས། མིག་ལ་འོད་རྒྱག་གིས། མིག་ནས་འོད་རྒྱག་གིས། སྐར་མ་ནས་འོད་རྒྱག་གིས། འོད་ཆིམ་ཆིམ།
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to be worthy, to be right.

examples.english: We are giving you the respect you deserve. It is right that I obey (my) mother.
I have never found the right job for me. ({'os} is used as an adjective here.)

commentsEnglish: {'os pa} by itself is an adjective. It functions as a verbal compound with a verb plus {'os pa}, for example {byed 'os pa.} or {nyan 'os pa}.

examples.english: She is our relative, but she doesn't take any notice of us. (i.e., she doesn't care about us.) These days, you are not taking any notice of me. What's up?
No one is taking any notice of that dog, but still it is playing by itself.
I didn't break the window, but they are blaming me.
He accused someone else even while his own wrong doing was evident. Don't blame me, I didn't do anything. ({gang yang} is pronounced {ga'i}.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to do or say something for someone's good.

examples.english: I introduced you to that person for your own good, but instead you got extremely angry.
I scratched that horse for it's own benefit, but it kicked me. ({brad brad} is pronounced {bad bad}.)

commentsEnglish: {yag yag byed} means to do or say something for someone else's benefit. It sometimes involves doing things that the recipient may not appreciate.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The teacher often encourages (the students) that they need to improve (their) studies.
The conditions of the school have been greatly improved recently.
He is not getting better at his studies at all. Her studies have really improved.
All the offering smoke from this morning has now completely faded away.
All the pimples on my face have disappeared.

englishGloss: to use or wash with soap.

examples.english: When washing (your) hands, you must use soap. This chuba won't get clean without using lots of soap.
I am impressed by the way he studies and works. I am impressed by the teacher's instructions. (i.e., the teacher's advice.)
I spoke to him, but he is not pleased with me.

commentsEnglish: This entry is also spelled {yid rang byed}.

englishGloss: to do or take an exam.

examples.english: (You) need to prepare well before taking an exam. We are presently doing mid-semester exams.
A. Is it possible to go to university after taking the exam? B. It's not for certain. Even if you think you should go, if you don't pass the exam, you can't go.
Because that student has so much homework, she is very discouraged. Since I don't know English, I am completely discouraged.
The parents are dismayed because the child doesn't obey. If (you) get discouraged, you won't retain (your) studies. (lit. 'know studies.')
I really appreciate that you have such kind parents. I admire experts of the English language.
I feel a deep respect for his knowledge. I have always been inclined towards the simple life.

commentsEnglish: {yid smon byed} is more common in the literary regsiter. {smon} is more commonly used as a verb by itself as in {khyed rang la pha ma yag po de 'dras yod pa nga zhe drags smon byung} -'I really appreciate that you have such nice parents'.

englishGloss: to make a big deal about something you have done.
to go on about what you have done.

examples.english: He is going on and on to me (about something he did). He is making such a big deal over the little work he did.
No one is happy when someone makes a big deal over a tiny bit of work.

commentsEnglish: {yus shod} is similar in meaning to {ngo so gtong}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I made a complete mess of this work. From now on, I will ask for correction. If I make a mistake with what I say, please correct me.
To not correct a mistake, is worse than to make a mistake. Please advise me and correct my inappropriate behaviours.
I spun some thread and made a rope. The girl is spinning yarn quickly.
A. When you get some free time, please come to our home. B. Sure. I'll come.
A. When will (your) daughter come back from mainland China? B. (She) will come back in March after doing (her) exams.
A. Am I allowed to stay here? B. You are not allowed to, if you don't have a permit.
A. Is it alright if I ask you a question now? B. Sorry, I have an important meeting right now.
A large plane is coming from the east. Big black clouds are coming from (the direction) of Trip. ({sgrib} is a village south of Lhasa.)
A. Has this can passed the expiry date? B. No, it hasn't. There is still more than one year left.
It is five minutes past three. This milk powder has expired.
If we continued on from here, we would pass by the Indian border. We have gone over time. (i.e., now, the time has passed.)
The mother beckoned and called her child from the roof. That person is waving someone over. I wonder who they are calling?
If water is boiled inside a tarnished container, it will make (people) sick. This copper cauldron has tarnished. It might be alright if it is cleaned.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: I borrowed a book from him.
I lent money to him. I haven't been repaid yet. That person always makes excuses and doesn't do any work.
Please lend me the key for a little while. I'll give it back straight away. ({phul} means 'to offer'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Are they threshing? B. No, they have finished threshing.
After harvesting, the threshing needs to be done straight away.

englishGloss: for the mind to wander, to be inattentive.

examples.english: She always gets caught up in the market place. I got caught up in playing mahjong and forgot to go to work.
When listening to a lesson, (you) should never let (your) mind wander. My son is easily absorbed in games.

commentsEnglish: {g.yeng} is similar to the verb {yeng}.

englishGloss: to be moved, shaken, agitated or manipulated.
to be touched or moved emotionally.

examples.english: Prayer flags blowing in the wind is quite a sight. ({ltad mo chen po} is lit. 'a grand spectacle.' The past tense {g.yos} is pronounced {g.yo}.)
My faith in the lama grew to such an extent that tears rolled from my eyes and the hairs on my body quivered.
Even though we don't notice it, the world moves and rotates around the sun.

commentsEnglish: The volitional, transitive counterpart of this entry also has the present tense {g.yo}.

examples.english: (The fact that) the elderly man, Tashi, offered his kidney to assist another patient is a deed that is able to move a person's heart.
Son, it is astounding that when you see others studying diligently, you are not affected at all!
If your heart is not moved a little, then there is no difference between you and earth and stones.

commentsEnglish: {g.yo 'gul thebs} primarily means to be touched or moved emotionally. {sems 'gul thebs} is more common way to express this.

englishGloss: to act in a cunning, deceitful way.

examples.english: The girl acted cunningly and completely snared his heart. (lit. 'she used deceitful means to attract his heart.' Note that {bkug} also means to hook something.) There is much deceitful pretension in the work of business.
Why are you acting in a deceitful way to me? Whatever business you have, say it directly.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He dressed his children in beautiful clothes. If the plastic sheet is not put over the truck, the merchandise will get wet.
The students had ceremonial scarves put on them and were farwelled. I hung a khata on a religious statue.

commentsEnglish: {g.yog} can not be said in relation to dressing oneself. One must use {gyon} in this case, for example, {ngas dug slog gyon pa yin}. See {gyon} for more examples. Note that the use of 'farewelled' in example two is specific to Australian English.

examples.english: A. That person is always avoiding me. B. Why? A. Perhaps (he) is avoiding me because I have some money to collect from him.
A. Son, when it is time to study, don't avoid it. B. Alright. From now on, I won't.
A. Ah! If he hadn't quickly avoided the car, it would have nearly crushed him. B. Yes, just like you said. My heart nearly came out of my mouth. (i.e., I was very frightened.)
The old lady thought that the dog would bite and slowly avoided it.

commentsEnglish: In example four the use of {'chang} - 'to bite' is less commonly used than {so rgyag}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to evade, avoid or dodge something.

examples.english: If the enemy's ship pursues us, we should try to evade it right away.
He does nothing but avoid work when there is something difficult to do.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to provide evidence for or against.

examples.english: I came to confront him for evidence on this matter. The court proved overwhemingly that this criminal committed the crime.
If you speak recklessly, people will confront you. (i.e., about the truth of your claims.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: (You) can prove it, if (you) get clear evidence.
He showed proof of the fact that he is normally diligent in his studies so that he could attend university.
At first I very much doubted that situation, (but) then I got verification and became convinced.
That event which I had heard about recently, was verified as I watched televsion last night.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Are you drunk? B. Yes, I'm drunk. A. Is he drunk? B. He is probably also drunk.
A. Did you get drunk last night? B. I didn't. A. Does he usually get drunk? B. Sometimes.
He always says annoying things when he gets drunk. Last night I got completely drunk, so today (I) have a hangover.
Last night, I got drunk and threw all (my) money away. (i.e., completely wasted all my money.)
A. Did you get a ticket? B. I didn't. Perhaps I will tomorrow.
A. What's happened to you today? B. Last night, I didn't get a good sleep so I'm very lethargic.
Yesterday, I didn't get a single drop of water. (This idiomatic expression means nothing was achieved.) If I get the opportunity, I will come to Tibet again.

englishGloss: to depend on, to rely on.

examples.english: The relative success of (your) projects depends on your own perseverance.
Children, be they good or bad, rely on (their) parents. (Note that this is an unusual use of {pa red}.)

commentsEnglish: {rag las} is not normally considered a verb by traditional Tibetan grammarians.

englishGloss: to be able to take care of yourself.
to be able to do something on your own.

examples.english: After graduating from school, my oldest child is (now) taking care of herself. I still can't drive a car on my own.
There wasn't a single person who could solve the problem by themselves. (lit. answer for this issue.)

commentsEnglish: An alternate spelling of this compound is {rang rkya}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to stand on one's own two feet.

examples.english: Even if (my) economic circumstances are no more than this, I can still scrape by on my own.
Rely on your own toil and stand on your own two feet!

englishGloss: to be able to stand on one's own two feet.

examples.english: My daughter is young, but she can be self-reliant.
Unless that son of mine is taken to school, he will not become self-reliant. (i.e., when he grows older he?.)
She is physically disabled, but is still able to be self-sufficient. Building up your homeland through your own initiative is extremely good. (This expression is a motivational directive.)
You need to rely on yourself!
A. Why did he commit suicide? B. I don't know.
That deranged person jumped off the roof and killed himself.
He helped enormously with our work. Students should help each other with their studies.

commentsEnglish: {ram 'degs byed} is more compound in the literary register. In Lhasa dialect, {rogs pa byed} is more common, even more so than {rogs ram byed}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. If I sing a Tibetan opera are you able to accompany me? (A {rnam thar} is a religious biography which in this case is sung.) B. We will accompany you in whatever way we can.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised componud usually refers to the situation in Tibetan opera when the main singer takes a small rest to catch his/her breath and the accompanying singers continue singing. {rams skyor byed} is also used for general singing accompaniment.

examples.english: A. I wonder how his mouth got ripped. B. (They) say (he) was drunk and fell down.
My clothes are completely ripped.
The ball rolled under the bed. If you are not careful, the thermos will fall over.
When children first learn to walk, (they) often fall over. This summer, some (snow) mountain climbers fell from rock faces. ({brag} also means 'boulder' or 'rock'. {'dzeg} is pronounced {'dzag}.)
Those children from outside ganged up and hit my child. When work is urgent, if everyone joins in together it will be finished quickly.

commentsTibetan: རུབ་རྒྱག རུབ་རུབ་བྱེད། ཁ་རུབ་རྒྱག རོབ་རྒྱག ཡུལ་རུབ་རྒྱག ཁྱི་རུབ་རྒྱག རུག་རུག་བཟོ། ལྟ་རུབ་རྒྱག ལྟ་རུག་རྒྱག
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: They ganged up just on me. Many people ganged up on him and beat him up.
If we gather everyone together, (we) will be able to get the car out of the water.

commentsTibetan: རུབ། རུབ་རུབ་བྱེད། རུབ་རུབ་བཟོ། ཁ་རུབ་རྒྱག རུག་རུག་བཟོ། ལྟ་རུབ་རྒྱག ལྟ་རུག་རྒྱག
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: This Saturday, all the students are planning to meet at my home.
In the mornings, several benefactors round up many mendicants and give them tea and noodles.

commentsEnglish: {rub rub bzo} refers to people gathering or assembling together.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The roots of the apricot tree have become completely rotten. Because those things have been buried in the ground for many years, most of them have decomposed and can't be recovered. (lit. 'taken by hand.')
A. The blue cheese is delicious. B. When chura becomes rotten, is it no problem to eat it? A. No problem.

commentsEnglish: Note that {kham sdong} in example one is often translated 'peach tree'.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to have pain in the joints or bones.

examples.english: The cold that this going around at the moment is really severe. It gives (you) body pain in (your) joints.
This place is so cold that (my) body is aching. He had such bad joint pain that he writhed around.

commentsEnglish: {rus zug rgyag} often precedes a cold or is associated with a cold.

examples.english: They are hoping that this situation can be decided in a peaceful way.
Everyone hopes that their lives will improve.

englishGloss: to fulfil or satisfy a wish or a hope.

examples.english: If you fulfil too many of your children's wishes, there is danger of them being spoiled. Aside from not fulfilling our expressed desires, worse than that, he always says things that cause trouble.

commentsEnglish: {re ba skong} is not commonly said.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: It's better to do it yourself than place your hope in others.
There is a danger that our children will dash the hopes we parents have for them.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I am hoping to win a prize in the literature competition. We shouldn't dash the hopes (our) parents have for us.

commentsEnglish: {re ba 'chang} is not commonly said.

examples.english: Following treatment, he is hoping to recover from (his) sickness. All parents hope that their children's studies will go well.
They hope to come first in the sports competiton. (lit. 'to achieve number one.')
Do you need some help? There is nothing I can do to help you, is there?
Oh please, could you help with this for a short time. He has helped us enormously with our lives.
A. Can I help? (lit. 'Can I offer help?') B. Thank you.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to get fogged or steamed up. (non.vol.)

examples.english: A. Do you want to eat steamed dumplings? B. I don't like dumplings at all.
These days, there are many kinds of steamed vegetables in restaurants.
On top of being small, the room has too many people in it and (everyone) has got hot, causing (the room) to get fogged up. (Note that in this context the non-volitional, intransitive sense is used.)
He was playing around and upset the whole crease at the back of my chuba. Some old houses in Lhasa have been taken down and new ones built.
He is in the midst of a lucky run this year! As well as being healthy, (his) business is going well.
As for business, it fundamentally depends on (your) amount of luck. Today, I was lucky and was able to get everything done.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound literally means 'the wind-horse gallops'.

examples.english: A. Why is she angry? B. I don't know.
A. You are very angry. What happened? ({bzhengs is pronounced {bzhangs}.) B. You made me angry.

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound literally means for one's {rlung} (one of the important constituents of the body) to arise.

examples.english: A. What has happened? I've lost all my permits. B. If you lose (your) passport, how will you go abroad?
These days, it's like you've lost yourself. What happened?

commentsEnglish: Though {brlags} is intransitive, the subject often takes the ergative to add emphasis or clarification. See glossary for more discussion.

englishGloss: to not have the ability to.
to be unable to stop or control.

examples.english: I am not able to do this work. (i.e., this work is beyond me.) This child is so naughty, and there is nothing that can be done.
That dog bites people and (we) can't control it.

commentsEnglish: This compound is typically used with negative auxiliaries. {brlag kha} does not have a standard written form.

englishGloss: to cross or traverse a mountain pass.

examples.english: If you cross that pass over there, (you'll) arrive at our district. He traversed many valleys and mountain passes and came to pay homage to Lhasa's Jowo.
Even though rabbits have short legs, they can still cross mountain passes. (This is a proverb. See comments below.) If you take this road, (you'll) need to traverse a high pass.

commentsEnglish: The proverb in example two means 'whatever you can do, I can also do even though I might not have your same physical attributes.' {sug lag} means both arms and legs.

examples.english: We need to implement her decisions. He merely talks from his mouth and does not carry it out. (i.e., he doesn't practice what he preaches.)
(We) will surely meet with great hardship as (we) implement this plan. ({'phrad nges} is more literary than colloquial, though is commonly said in this context. )

englishGloss: to gesture, to signal by hand.

examples.english: He seems to be really signaling me with his hand not to come. It is important that traffic police give clear hand signals.

englishGloss: to extend or reach out one's hand.

examples.english: He shook hands with me. I shook hands with that person.
The guests shook hands with one another.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to implement, to put into practice.

examples.english: We should put into practice what the teacher has said. No matter how much you say, isn't it meaningless if you can't put it into practice? (i.e., practice what you preach. {stong pa} means 'empty' or 'vacuous'.)
My friend is someone who is able to put into practice what he himself says.

commentsEnglish: The proverb in Related words and Expressions can be translated 'Talk is a water bubble, implementation a drop of gold.'

englishGloss: to get up, to stand up, to rise.

examples.english: Every morning, I get up at seven o'clock. That person is standing up.
It seems she has had some situation come up. (She) left very suddenly.
A. Is she up? ({bzhengs} is pronounced {bzhangs} and is honorific.) B. She has just got up.
Every morning, I get up and do a little exercise.

commentsEnglish: There are two different verbs that have the present tense {lang}. Both of these verbs are intransitive, but one is volitional and the other non-volitional. They have been listed separately in this database. Note that the honorific of this entry is pronounced {bzhangs}.

englishGloss: to occur, arise or rise up.

examples.english: It is not pleasant for the people if war breaks out. If it gets windy, let's go inside.
A. Has the chang fermented? B. It has.
When (you) get angry, (you) need to show tolerance. If (you) are not careful in winter, (you) could get all kinds of illnesses.
Because the wind blew so strongly, even the prayer flags were blown away.

commentsTibetan: སྒྱུར་རྩི་ལང་། གནམ་ལང་། ཆགས་པ་ལང་། རྩ་ལང་། རྩ་ལང་དུས་གཉེན་པོ་མི་སྡུག་པ་སྒོམ་ན་སེལ་ཐུབ་ཀྱི་རེད། སེམས་ཁྲེལ་ལང་། ང་ཁྱེད་རང་ལ་སེམས་ཁྲེལ་ཞེ་པོ་ལངས་བྱུང་། རྣམ་རྟོག་ལང་།
commentsEnglish: There are two different verbs that have the present tense {lang}. Both of these verbs are intransitive, but one is volitional and the other non-volitional. They have been listed separately in this database.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: Monkeys are very clever at imitating humans. Children imitiate older people.
If someone else imitates me, I am not happy. I don't like to impersonate other people.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to repay, to return, to reciprocate.

examples.english: Because we lost the ball game yesterday, today we are going to have a rematch.
He really helped (me) when I was staying in a foreign country. I really need to repay (his kindness).
Those who can distinguish between friend and foe repay goodness and evil in the right measure. (This sentence reflects apsects of literary Tibetan.)

englishGloss: to say, to speak, to tell, to talk.

examples.english: You say it. I'll write it down. No matter how many times I tell you, you don't listen.
A. You must definitely tell her about this. B. No problem. I'll tell her without forgetting.

Don't tell this secret situation to others. No matter how many times I tell you, you don't listen. (Note the use of both the humilific and honorific in this sentence. Compare this use of honorifics to sentence two in example one.)
If you don't do well with your studies, I'll tell your parents.

commentsEnglish: The imperative form of this verb, {lob}, is pronounced {lab}.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: These days, I take responsibility for importing things into our company.
A. Who is taking responsibility for the project of building a hospital? B. Tsomo is taking responsibility for that.

englishGloss: to implement a campaign or movement.

examples.english: Our government is implementing various campaigns to stop the epidemic.
We were able to obtain reasonable results from the campaign to eradicate illiteracy. ({gang 'tsham} is often said in Lhasa dialect as well as the more common {'o 'o tsam}.)
If (you) do it like this, our whole plan will collapse. There was so much rain this year, even my house collapsed.
The mo mo's have been left for too long and have all fallen apart.

englishGloss: to cast, to make from a mould.

examples.english: These days, building pillars are cast from concrete. Nomads make bullets cast from lead.
Those two appear to be relatives. (Their) faces look like they have been cast from the same mould.
A. Young girl, the water on the solar stove is about to overflow. B. OK. Before it overflows, I will pour it into the thermos.
This year, it rained so much that even the Lhasa Kyichu river overflowed. (lit. 'on both the left and right sides.')
That person is strange. Before asking, he says everything. (lit. 'his speech overflows.')
Unless farmers fertilise the fields every year, there won't be a good harvest.
Both top fertilizer and bottom fertiliser need to be put on fields. Today, we are fertilising the fields.
We finished putting fertiliser on our fields.
I left one of my things in the car. (I) will go and get it straight away.

When we went mountain climbing, he got left behind. Even if a rich boy is left to the last, he will be disappointed. (This proverb means that no one, not even the son of a wealthy man likes to be left out.)
The stallion looks back, yet is not to blame, as the stallion's remaining food has been left behind. (These are verses from a popular song. See notes below.)

commentsEnglish: The lyrics in example three are from a famous folk song. The song is a lament about those unavoidable times in one's life when it is time to say goodbye to a cherished home and move on.

examples.english: It doesn't seem like those two have had sex. Honestly, I have never slept with that girl.
I don't think it is really very good to have sexual relations before marriage.

commentsEnglish: {lus 'drel byed} refers to sexual intercourse outside of marriage. {mnyam du bsdad} is a more common way of saying 'sleeping together.'

examples.english: A. Did you answer the phone just now? B. No. A. Who answered that phone call before? B. No one.
Is it OK if I come and pick up the letter now? I have collected this month's salary.
A. How do you interpret this word? B. I interpret this word as meaning 'auspicious.'

commentsEnglish: All the tenses for this verb are pronounced {len}.

englishGloss: to return, to come or go back. (vol.)
to get in the wrong order, back to front, upside down.

examples.english: All the students went back to their own hometowns during the holidays. Our leader saw that I went back home early.
There is absolutely no benefit in practicing religion when (you) adhere to the wrong doctrine. She has lost the colour in her face.
It rained and the road collapsed. The colour has faded.

commentsTibetan: ལོག་གཏོང་། བཀའ་དྲིན་ལོག་མཇལ། དྲིན་ལན་ལོག་འཇལ། ཞེན་པ་ལོག གྲྭ་ལོག ཕྱི་ལོག ང་ནང་ལ་ལོག་འགྲོ་གི་ཡོད།
commentsEnglish: The meaning 'to return, to come or go back' is volitional and intransitive. The other senses of {log} are non-volitional, intransitive. The transitive form of this verb is {slog}.

englishGloss: to speak in a secret or special way.

examples.english: Those businessmen spoke exclusively to each other in some secret language while we were making a business deal.

I can't even understand that secret talk, let alone speak it. (i.e., 'let alone speaking in pig latin, I can't even understand it.') Hey there! Unless you refrain from speaking a lot of esoteric argot, people will grow suspicious.

commentsEnglish: {log skad} usually occurs between friends who have a particular way of saying things so that no one else understands. People who share a particular interest, or come from the same place will sometimes use {log skad} so that others won't be able to follow the conversation.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to send back, to send home.

examples.english: The teacher only sent us home after 10 o'clock!
Mother said that if we don't obey, she will send us back to the countryside.
It is not easy for a teacher to turn (someone) away.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to commit adultery, fornication or sexual perversion.

examples.english: To be lustful towards women other than your wife, is considered a sexual perversion.

Adultery is also included in the 10 non-virtues. (lit. 'the act of committing adultery.' The use of {yod} in this sentence reflects literary Tibetan rather than the spoken register. {yod red} would be more commonly said.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: Last year, I did some business and got 20,000 RMB profit. You have grown tall, haven't you?
My child passed the university (entrance) exam.
A. Your hand is bruised. What happenend? ({smug thig} is also spelled {rmug thig}.) B. Yesterday, they pinched me.
Don't pinch. It hurts. When a mother disciplines a child, (she) should only pinch them. ({gtor} means 'to smash' or 'to destroy', but here it refers to disciplining a child.)

commentsEnglish: {sha gcus rgya} literally means 'to twist flesh.'
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to show love, affection or concern for.

examples.english: Parents love their children. Don't you understand the loving things I said to you?
Words of affection don't always have to sound nice. (This proverb means that if you love someone you will not just say nice things, but also correct or criticise when needed.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The cow's coat was so sickly that it become infested with lice. The old lady got sick and became really infested with lice.
Since beggar's children are not kept clean, they always get lice.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: How similar is the way monkeys pick lice from each other and the way humans do!
A. What are you doing? B. I am picking lice out of my sister. (i.e., my sister's hair.)
These days, many young people sleep during the day and at night are nothing but lice pickers. (To call someone a 'lice picker' is an idiomatic way of accusing that person of vagrant behaviour.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: He's whistling nicely. In the morning, we need to get up when the whistle blows outside.
A. Do you know how to whistle? B. I don't know how to very well.

englishGloss: to have been influenced or affected.

examples.english: Family behaviour has a direct influence on children. His behaviour affected us.
The young people of today have been influenced in many ways by societal influences.
A. How has that film influenced people? B. I don't know what to say about that. But the film was well acted. (Note that {ltad mo} can refer to any performance regardless of the type of media.)

englishGloss: to use strength, to make an effort.
to work hard, to try hard.

examples.english: I am striving hard so that my Tibetan studies go well.
Having strengthened our resolve, we will attempt to climb Mount Everest.
Continue to strive hard. She always works very hard in all her work and studies.
A. You probably know many languages? B. Oh, no. I only know Tibetan very poorly.
A. When did she know about the situation? B. Probably from yesterday.
I know how to speak French very poorly.

commentsEnglish: This verb is traditionally categorised as intransitive {tha mi dad pa}, but Kesang Gyurme considers this verb to be transitive and non-volitional. See glossary for more details on verbal arguments.

englishGloss: to play a Tibetan dice game.

examples.english: A. Shall we play 'sho'? B. I dont know how to play 'sho'. Would it be OK if you taught me?
During Tibetan new year, the young boys from our village all play 'sho'.

englishGloss: to make an offering of something small wrapped in paper.

examples.english: Putting money in an envelope for a wedding ceremony is very prevalent in Lhasa.
I put 500 yuan in an envelope for his ceremony. (i.e., I gave him 500 yuan.)
Wrap this medicine in paper and put it in (your) bag.

commentsEnglish: {shog chag rgyag} is typically done at weddings, going-away parties, funerals and, in more recent times, birthday parties.

examples.english: I told you all about that situation. Even though I distinctly told you, you didn't listen.
He spoke the whole truth in the courtroom.

commentsTibetan: ཟེར། འཆད། ཁ་གཏམ་གཏོང་། ཤོད། གཏམ་བཤད་ཤོད། ལབ། སློབ་དཔོན་གྱིས་ཆོས་འཆད་པ་དང་སློབ་མས་གུས་བཀུར་གྱིས་ཉན་གྱི་རེད།
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to operate, to have an operation.

examples.english: These days, (surgeons here) have good skills at performing operations. The doctor operated on him.

commentsEnglish: {gshag bcos} is also spelled {gshags bcos}. Regarding example two, {am chi} is a relatively new word and is very commonly said in Lhasa dialect. {am chi} is also spelled {em chi} and {em je}. {sman pa} is the literary term.

englishGloss: to have had contact with someone.
to have worked or been associated with someone.

examples.english: The two of us have been acquainted only a very short time. Although we have been associated for many years, I am still not very familiar with him.
A. Have you two been acquainted previously? B. Earlier, we got to know each other well from the time we both lived in the countryside.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to move close together or side by side.

examples.english: Unless everyone moves closer together, we won't have a place to sit. If the chairs are moved side by side, twenty students can fit (in this room). ({chud} is pronounced {chur}.)
A. Are you two sitting side by side? B. We are sitting side by side.
A. Are your houses right next to each other? B. They are just near each other. ({ya tsa ma tsa} is literally 'up a bit, down a bit' and is a Lhasa idiom for 'near'.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Please throw out this cold tea. B. Yes. I will throw it out.
A. Did you throw out the rubbish? B. Yes, I threw the rubbish into a pit. A. Did she throw out the water? B. She did.
Miss, could you throw out this tea. A fly has landed in it. (Note that {bu mo} means 'girl', 'women' or 'daughter', but has been translated here as 'Miss', to reflect U.S. English.)

commentsEnglish: This verb is usually used for liquids and materials like flour, dust, and anything that can be easily scattered. {gad snyigs} in example two means dust and dirt in this context. In contemporary Lhasa dialect, {gad snyigs} is commonly used with the verb {dbyugs}. Originally, {gad snyigs} was dust or dirt that had been swept up and hence {gshos} was used. These days, {gad snyigs} can refer to larger items of rubbish.

examples.english: A. What is Lobsang doing? B. He is cutting wood.
These days, mountains are being cut through and a train line is being built in Tibet.

commentsEnglish: {gshog} is similar to the more colloquial expression {sbag bshags gtong}.

examples.english: Everyday, monks display offerings in front of (religious) statues. (Note that {sku 'dra} usually refer to physical representations of deities, but this term can also refer to statues in general.) Many people are presently preparing for tomorrow's meeting.
Tonight, I am going to give a banquet. Everyone, please come to my house at six o'clock. ({gshom} is pronounced {bsham}.)
King Gesar often fought many wars when subduing demons.
He gave a very big banquet to the foreign guests.

commentsEnglish: {gshom} is typically pronounced {bsham} for all tenses.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: All the old buildings in our work unit are to be demolished.
It's not easy to demolish those old houses.
It is best if you don't go to the places where old houses are being destroyed. (Note that this sentence reflects the Tibetan belief that such places are inauspicious.)

englishGloss: to peel, to skin, to pare.

examples.english: I am going to peel this banana. I was hot and peeled off the blankets.
A. Has our photo been developed? B. It is being developed now. Long ago, there was no other way to copy scriptures other than by hand. ({dpar} is also spelled {par}.)
It is better to complete homework by yourself than to copy from someone else.

commentsEnglish: In reference to the second sentence of example two, scriptures were copied by hand because it was not always possible to use a woodblock. Even today some scriptures can only be copied by hand because it is not possible to photocopy them.

examples.english: The state of human exploitation exists in many societies.
It is really exploitation not to pay the servant her exact wages.
Don't exploit that poor person. ({gtong aA} is often pronounced {btang aA.})

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to sell something without making a profit.

examples.english: Please pass me the salt. Excuse me, could you hand me that pen please?
I passed a full cup of water to him. Would it be alright if you sold to me the new car? (i.e., for the same price you bought it for.)
A. Would it be alright if you sold me the camera you bought in a foreign country? (i.e., for the same price you bought it for.) B. Yes. (I'll) offer it to you.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Have you still not signed the contract? B. (I) signed it earlier. No one will abide with this unsigned contract.
Our contract of cooperation was signed yesterday.
When there was thunder this morning, I woke up. If you don't leave quietly, the child will wake up.
Grandpa, Grandpa! Wake up. It's late. I woke her up. (Note that this is a transitive, volitional usage.)
Please wake me up at five o'clock tomorrow morning.

commentsEnglish: In example three note that the imperative of the verb {gsod} (to kill) is used. However, the meaning in this context is 'to wake up'. This verb can be both volitional and non-volitional depending on the context. The transitive, volitional counterpart is also spelled {sad} and means, 'to examine, test or try' but this sense is very rarely used in Lhasa dialect.

examples.english: This morning, my flowers were covered in frost. There was a frost on the fields and (you) couldn't see the shoots.
Even though moisture may fall, if the sky is cloudy there won't be a frost.

commentsEnglish: {snog skam thebs}, in Related Words and Expressions, is used to describe plants, crops or fields that have been badly damaged by frost.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: He is erasing the letters on the blackboard. Please cross out my name. (Note that in this context {subs} can mean 'erase' or 'rub out').
Before painting this desk, the cracks should be filled in. (lit. 'the cracks require filling in'.)
This food was enclosed in a plastic bag and since it smells, there is no way that it can be eaten.
Unless the child is watched often, she could suffocate.
She is always worried about you until you come back. Since within society these days security is not good, parents become worried.
Don't be anxious. You probably did fine on the exam.
A. Are you worried about the English exam? B. I am very worried. (Note that {sems khral} is not verbalised here.)

commentsEnglish: {sems khral} literally means 'mind taxation'. {sems khral} is commonly verbalised with {lang} and is also spelled {sems khrel}.

examples.english: They don't show any concern for us at all. Aren't you concerned for our livelihood?
If married couples show concern for each other, they will have a good relationship. The leaders showed great interest in our work.
Is there any difference between animals and people who have no concern for society? (Note that {dud 'gro} means animals which bend over and walk on all fours.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be moved, to be touched.

examples.english: Because he gave up his own work and looked after me in the hospital, I was extremely touched.
If the teacher gives us advice, we are moved emotionally. (lit. 'we have no choice but to be moved.')
If you do good deeds, others will, without question, be deeply touched.

englishGloss: to be attached to, to be fond of.

examples.english: You seem to be very attached to your homeland. That girl is in love with him.
I heard that when she was about to die, she became very attached to her children.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to overly ponder, ruminate or fixate your mind upon something.
to worry or think excessively about a particular thing.

examples.english: I wonder who is thinking about me? Today, I am not happy at all. When (you) lend something out, don't worry about it. (i.e., fixating on it won't help and your very worries could put a jinx on the safe return.)
You're always pondering over things, aren't you? We can't complete our work at all well. (i.e., your worries and concerns in themselves are an obstacle to our work.)

commentsEnglish: Tibetans believe that overly ruminating about someone can inadvertently bring harm. In the first sentence of example one, the speaker has an intuitive sense that someone is thinking about her.

englishGloss: to leave or give a memento.

examples.english: A. What did you leave your girlfriend as a memento? B. I gave her a gold bangle.

commentsEnglish: The correct present tense is {sems rten 'jog}, but {'jog} is rarely used in Lhasa dialect.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be sad, miserable or depressed.

examples.english: What good does it do to be depressed over past events? (lit. 'what benefit...')
Don't be sad. Subsequent to birth, all must eventually pass away. (This is an appropriate consolation for those in mourning.)

englishGloss: to feel distraught, dismayed or discouraged.

examples.english: Won't the mother feel very disappointed if her son talks back (to her)? (This is said as a telling off to a boy for talking back to his mother.) Don't be distraught or harm will be brought upon your body.
He is feeling very dismayed because he has lost a great deal of money. (lit. lost a lot of money to someone else's hand.)

commentsEnglish: Regarding the second sentence in example one, Tibetans say that too much worry or tension can turn your hair grey overnight.

englishGloss: to be worried, anxious or nervous.

examples.english: That mother who has lost her child is very worried. If I worry about not having found any work, what is the point of that?
Don't be anxious when you work. I was really nervous when I did the exam yesterday.
A. Does she get nervous when she teaches a lesson? B. She does a little.
A. Are you anxious? B. I am, and now I will go. (Note that {'tshab} is not paired with {sems} in this example.)

englishGloss: to be absent-minded, to be lost in thought.
to lose one's concentration, to be inattentive.

examples.english: Yesterday, I was absent-minded and completely forget your message. I was absent-minded and drank your tea. (The context here is that someone accidentally drank another person's cup of tea.)
Today, I spent the whole day mesmerised by the television. During class, some students get totally absorbed in story books.
Dont let your mind be diverted. Watch the main gate. (Note that {g.yeng} is not paired with {sems}.) I went for a walk to clear my head.

commentsEnglish: Note that {srung} is pronounced {krung} in the first sentence of example three.

examples.english: He fell in love with the girl, Dekyi, and wrote (to her) many times. (But) it appears that Dekyi likes someone else.
Those cars produced from Japan are absolutely awesome. (lit. '...are ones to fall in love with.') I don't like the manner in which you are doing that.
A. Have you fallen in love with that girl? B. Not at all. (lit. 'I haven't fallen in love with that girl at all.' {gang yang} is pronounced ga'i}.)
When someone dies, relatives should comfort (one another). Yesterday, he comforted those who were in mourning.
The other day, we went to Dekyi Drolgar's home to console her.
You should console yourself.

commentsEnglish: In the first sentence of example one, note that {spun mched} is pronounced {spin bkyag}. In Lhasa dialect, {spin bkyag} is the usual way of referring to a relative.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: This desk has cracked. If the roof splits, it will leak.
The cup slipped from my hand and cracked. (lit. 'because the cup slipped from my hand, it cracked.') My hands are chapped.

commentsEnglish: {ser ka} is also spelled {ser kha}.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: This year, it hailed a few times in our area.
If it hails heavily, the crops will be severely damaged.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to remove, to get rid of.

examples.english: The doctor gave medicine to the patient who had food poisoning and (she) was immediately cured. We are hoping that this problem will be removed.

The Triple Refuge will remove our obstacles. (Note that {gegs} often refers to spiritual obstacles or hindrances.) However much difficulty I have with (my) studies, the teacher helps (me) and is able to remove the hardship.

commentsTibetan: སྐོམ་པ་སེལ། སྡིག་པ་སེལ། ཉེས་པ་སེལ། དཀའ་ངལ་སེལ། ན་ཙ་སེལ། སྡུག་བསྔལ་སེལ། ཚ་གདུང་སེལ། ཡིག་རྨོངས་སེལ།

examples.english: Last night, a dog bit me. If (you) bite hard on dried cheese, (you) will damage (your) teeth.
If food is not chewed well when eating, it will harm (your) stomach! (Note that {tag tag} means 'exactly' or 'just right' but in this context refers to the precise result of not chewing correctly.)

englishGloss: to grind or clench one's teeth.

examples.english: Because the leader told her off, she is so angry that she is grinding her teeth.
When she sleeps, that girl really grinds her teeth.
It is very important that our company be managed properly since it was established by many people putting their captial together. ( {kung si} is a Chinese loan word.)
Tibetan farmers really like to store up grain.

commentsEnglish: This entry is similar in usage to {gsogs}, though the pronunciation{bsag} is more frequently used in everyday speech.

examples.english: The butcher is preparing to kill a yak. ({bshan pa} is also spelled {shan pa} and {gshan pa}.) Those bandits killed some nomads.

In society, the number of people who commit murder has greatly increased. You don't need to brandish an axe to kill lice. (This proverb means not to make something bigger than what it is. An equivalent English expression is, 'don't make a mountain out of a molehill.')

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to do things in order to survive.

examples.english: Though they have no place of escape, terrrorists are trying to survive under the assault of many countries.
Since I did many things to help this sick dog survive, it became well.
Nepali soldiers guard the border. My small dog protects the house well. (The pronunciation of {srung} changes to {krung} here.)
Please protect this shop well. This monk is good at adhering to (his) vows.

commentsEnglish: In most cases, the pronunciation of {srung} changes to {krung}. However, when it is used to refer to soldiers guarding a border or a monk keeping monastic vows, then {srung} is pronounced as it is written.

englishGloss: to roast, to bake, to deep fry.

examples.english: They collected all the old letters and burned them. I was absent minded while burning rubbish and the edge of (my) chuba got a little burnt.
A. When was this potato deep fried? B. It was fried yesterday. A. Then, I will eat today's baked bread.
Please fry some potatoes. (ie., deep fry some potatoes.)

englishGloss: to have a layer of fat on tea.

examples.english: Oh what a pity, this beggar's head is infested with lots of nits. The weather was too hot and the tea has got a layer of fat on it.
A. If your head gets infested with lice, how do you get rid of them? (lit. 'what is the best method'?) B. The best way to get rid of nits is to shave your head. (lit. 'make your head bald.')

commentsEnglish: {sro ma} are the eggs of a louse.
categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: That prisoner was executed. That evil leader was finally executed because he was so severely corrupt.

If (you) work in such a lousy way, you ought to be executed! (Note that this expression is said in a joking manner.) By the look of his behaviour, he's really asking for it! (i.e., he is asking to be shot.)

commentsEnglish: {srog thog gtong} has the same meaning as {dmar gsod gtong}, though the latter is not as common.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to come into a life threatening situation.

examples.english: Even if I'm facing death, I will not commit non-virtuous deeds. Even if threatened with death, I will not tell others what you have said.
The mountaineers met with life-threatening hardship.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to establish a custom or teaching.

examples.english: The teachings of the Gelukpas originated with the venerable Tsong khapa. (lit. 'Tsong khapa founded the Gelukpa teachings.')
Tumi Sambhota is the founder of Tibetan writing.

commentsEnglish: This entry can also be verbalised with {byed} though it is more often used without a verbaliser.

englishGloss: to warm up or heat up.
to dry by heat or sunlight.

examples.english: Since they don't have any work in winter, they always sit around basking in the sun. Unless I warm up (my) hands by the fire, I will freeze. (i.e., continue to be very cold.)
I will give the left-over food to beggars once it becomes hot by heating it up on the fire.

englishGloss: to whine in a spoiled manner.

examples.english: Oh how that girl likes to grizzle! Now please, don't whine so much.
He always whines to me so much.
As soon as that child gets the slightest bit sick, he really whines.

commentsEnglish: The meaning 'to grizzle, to whinge' is particular to Australian English.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to restore, to revive, to reconstruct.

examples.english: It would be nice if some of the old customs were revived. Those declining aspects of the culture definitely need to be restored. (Though this sentence reflects literary Tibetan some Lhasa dialect speakers say this in certain situations.)

commentsTibetan: ཆོས་ལུགས་སླར་གསོ་བྱེད། ཁྲིམས་སླར་གསོ་བྱེད། བྱེད་སྟངས་སླར་གསོ་བྱེད། ཁྱིམ་རྒྱུད་སླར་གསོ་བྱེད། ཉམས་གསོ་བྱེད། ཞིག་གསོ་བྱེད།

englishGloss: to lure, to beguile, to deceive.
to persuade to do something bad.
to lead someone to evil, to tempt.

examples.english: He became a drug user because that bad individual lured him into it.
He tempted me into drinking beer, but I didn't drink one drop.
No good result will come from cheating and deceiving people.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. When will they arrive in Lhasa? B. Perhaps tomorrow.
A. Have any letters arrived for us? B. Not yet. In a little while, they will.
I have been to Lhasa many times. Now we have come to lesson four.

commentsEnglish: An alternate past tense spelling of this verb is {bslebs} and an alternative future tense spelling is {bsleb}.

englishGloss: to turn upside down, inside out.
to turn over, to plough over.

examples.english: A. Have you returned the book that you borrowed? B. I already returned (it).
A. Did you give the change back to him? B. (I) did just now. (Note that {ljags bslogs} is the honorific form of this verb when the meaning is to return something.)
A. Sometimes, I put my jacket on inside out. B. Yeah, you probably also like to do your work inside out. (This sentence is said in a joking manner.)
After the Second World War ended, some soldiers who had been captured were returned to their own countries.

commentsEnglish: The intransitive form of {slog} is {log}. When {log} is used for the meaning 'to return or go back' the sense is volitional. However, with all other meanings of {log} the sense is non-volitional. See {log} for example sentences.

englishGloss: to cause or make someone or something stand up or rise.

examples.english: That fake monk always begs for money on Lhasa's streets. ({srang lam} is pronouced {krang lam}.)

Many years have passed since the founding of the yearly custom of raising tall prayer flags in Lhasa. (Note that {dar chen} are prayer flag poles found in front of monasteries. There is debate as to whether these poles are actually raised every year or, rather, every few years.)
These days, some countries are inciting powerful uprisings. This year, I will seek a bride for my son.
Nurses help patients to get up.

commentsEnglish: This verb is commonly pronounced {slong} for both present and future tenses. The non-volitional counterpart of {slong}, when meaning 'to incite, to provoke, to cause to start', is {lang}. See {lang} for example sentences. There are two different verbs which have the present tense {lang}. Both entries are intransitive, but one is volitional and the other is non-volitional.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: A. Teacher, are you teaching Tibetan these days? B. Yes, I'm presently teaching Tibetan.
I taught her a little bit of English. Please teach me how to use a computer.
I studied at Tibet University. Unless (you) study well, (you) won't be able to graduate from school.
I am going to ask (him) if I could study his manner. (i.e., his behaviour or manner of doing things.)
The lama continually advises his disciples. My parents gave me advice.
I am always giving him moral advice.
How can it be alright if parents are nothing but harsh when giving advice to (their) children?

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to give a secret signal or password.

examples.english: He sent us a cryptic message that we needed to flee quickly from that place.
(Our) older sister gave us a secret sign not to talk about that matter among many people.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The Chinese people invented such discoveries as paper and the compass. ({sogs} means 'etc.' or 'so on' and is more common in the literary register.)
It is confusing how some people these days re-create some of the good traditions of the past. (i.e., it is confusing whether they are new or old customs.)
Master Tumi invented the Tibetan writing system by modelling it on the Indian writing system.
It's confusing with so many new habits being introduced.
He always re-interprets the words of others. New names need to be coined these days for many things.

commentsEnglish: The second sentence in example two - 'He always re-interprets the words of others.' - is not necessarily used in a negative sense.

examples.english: A. You have completely squashed my bread. B. Oh, (I) didn't notice it at all. Sorry. ({'tshoms} is also spelled {'tshum}.)
Please divide this offering and give it as a blessing to everyone.

commentsTibetan: ཞབས་གསིལ། ཕྱག་གསིལ། དྲིལ་བུ་གསིལ། དབུ་སྐྲ་གསིལ། བྱུ་ར་གསིལ་གསིལ་བཟོ་དང་། དངུལ་གསིལ་མ་ཅིག་བརྗེད་རོགས་གནང་།
commentsEnglish: {gsil} is also the honorific of {'khrud}, 'to wash'. See {'khrud} for example sentences.

englishGloss: to bring up, to foster, to rear.

examples.english: He has fostered more than a few Tibetan students. Bringing up children well is the responsibility of parents. (This statement is a motivational directive and the use of {yin} reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: If you harm animals, you will accumulate much non-virtue. Showing respect to one's parents accumulates merit.
Accumulating a spark of merit is better than doing a mountain of hard work. (This is a proverb.)
Like water droplets forming an ocean, if you study one word everyday you will become an expert scholar.
I am saving money to buy a car.

englishGloss: to make up for, to supplement.
to repay, to return favours or kindness.

examples.english: The government made up those previous losses which I incurred. This month, the work unit will re-imburse the deduction in my salary.
How nice it is to get the chance to repay kindness to (your) parents!

commentsEnglish: {bsab} has an alternative spelling for all tenses; {gsab}. {kha gsab byed} communicates the same sense as {gsob} and is more common in Lhasa dialect than {gsob}.

englishGloss: to be excited, to be expectant.

examples.english: I'm very excited. He is very excited.
The child is excited about going to the Lu Khang tomorrow.

commentsEnglish: In contemporary Lhasa dialect, this verb seems to have lost it's original meaning of 'to get ready' or 'to prepare'. Nowadays, {gsor} usually refers to the feeling of being excited about a planned future event and as such is a purely colloquial expression. The original sense is transitive and volitional, but in current usage it is non-volitional, intransitive.

examples.english: Today, the precious lama offered me a gift of money. We received ten sacks of grain from their household.
Please donate some money. The lama bestowed three life protector cords upon me.

commentsEnglish: {gsol ras gnang} is an honorific verbalised compound typically used in association with monks, lamas and nuns. {gsol ras} means 'gift', 'present' or 'donation'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: I am going to clean the chimney. Otherwise, all the smoke comes inside the house.
The doctor cleaned my ear. If there is a problem, it is better to speak openly about it. (Note that {gnas tshul} also means 'matter', 'situation' or 'circumstance'.)

englishGloss: to make a smoke or incense offering.

examples.english: On auspicious days, Tibetans make incense offerings. Many people are burning incense in the Barkhor.

commentsEnglish: Incense in this case is usually juniper. {bsang} is also spelled {bsangs}.

englishGloss: to give or express an opinion.
to make a suggestion or give an idea.

examples.english: If their manner of doing things is inappropriate, please give (your) suggestion straight away.
He offered a good suggestion concerning the work just now.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to ask for ideas, opinions or suggestions.

examples.english: Beyond asking for the suggestions of everyone here, it is unacceptable to listen to what only a few have to say.
I am only asking for your opinion, I am not looking for your faults.
If you ask other people for their ideas, no additional mistakes will occur.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: My friend appears to have had a complete change of heart. He doesn't wander around aimlessly and doesn't drink a single drop of beer (anymore).
If we, as parents, don't continually give good advice to our children, even if they are good now, their minds could be quickly corrupted. (lit. 'their minds could change'.)
She has recently changed her mind.
Upon reflection, we realised that wicked person had evil intentions.
That student has a good habit of reflection. (Note the use of {yod} in this context reflects the speaker's personal association with what has been said.) We are only now considering buying a car.

englishGloss: to be considerate, understanding or thoughtful.

examples.english: No matter how considerate I am of others, no one is considerate of me.
Could you please be a little considerate of my work. That inconsiderate guy is the same as a beast.
I can empathise with you. Please show us some more consideration.
A. Do you know the meaning of this? B. No. A. If (you) ask him, (you) will know immediately. B. OK. Thank you.
A. Where has Tashi gone off to? B. I don't know. I wonder how they knew about my circumstances?
A. If I go, will the leader know? B. Perhaps (he) will know.
A. When will I know about this matter? B. You will more than likely know tomorrow.

commentsEnglish: This compound is traditionally categorised as intransitive {tha mi dad pa}, but Kesang Gyurme considers this verb to be transitive and non-volitional. See glossary for more details on verbal arguments.

englishGloss: to be amazed, to be surprised.
to be shocked, to be astonished.

examples.english: Everyone is shocked when (they) hear about the situation of America's Trade Towers being knocked down.
Upon hearing that news, I was utterly shocked.
If you tell her about this matter, she will be surprised.
You seem to be getting a cold. (You) are sneezing a lot. Some chilli has probably been burnt. I really sneezed a lot.

englishGloss: to grab, to scramble or rush for.

examples.english: I got these inexpensive clothes by making a scramble for them. (i.e., at an outdoor market.) I rushed after the kite and got it. ({bya 'phir} is also spelled {bya 'phur}.)
Those people are completely idiotic. They don't line up and do nothing but push and shove at the ticket office. ({bang} is pronounced {pang} in this example.)
It is really rude to blurt out what you have to say.

englishGloss: to act in a shamless or brazen way.

examples.english: This person is being very greedy because he is saying that all this land is his.
Do not covet people or wealth. (This is a proverb.)

commentsEnglish: {ham po} as an adjective meaning 'greedy' is common than the verbal construction {ham po byed}. For example, {mi de ham pa tsha po zhe drags 'dug} - 'That person is very greedy.'
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The food has gone moldy. Unless moldy food is thrown out, eating it will make (you) sick.
Since the apples have been left in the plastic bag for too long, they have become moldy.
In places of high humidity, even clothes get moldy.

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

englishGloss: to unashamedly seize or take over.

examples.english: For an outside person to kick out the owner of a house, is an unashamed take over. (The absence of an auxiliary verb in this sentence reflects literary Tibetan.)
You should never have the thought of seizing other people's wealth.

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

englishGloss: to be conscientious, diligent or zealous.

examples.english: A. Are you working hard at this job? B. I am working hard.
She studies very diligently. Be conscientious with (your) studies!

Far from doing his studies with any zeal, Dawa sits around like a sloth. ({go med tshor med} is an idiomatic expression for 'lazy' or 'apathetic'. It literally means 'not hearing and not perceiving'.)
Don't sit there in shock. You are still sitting there in shock. Don't be shocked!
When I saw his bad behaviour I was very shocked.

commentsTibetan: ཧང་སང་། ཧར་ལས། དངངས་སྒྲ། སེམས་འཚབ། འདྲོག ཡ་མཚན།

englishGloss: to make a puffing, panting noise.

examples.english: I can't sleep when he snores. Sometimes, I snore. So, please don't be angry.

commentsEnglish: {hor sgrag rgyag} describes the sound one makes when snoring. This is a non-volitional verbalised compound and one can never say {ngas sngur pa brgyab pa yin}. There are numerous expressions for snoring though {hor sgrag rgyag} seems to be the most commonly used but {sngur sgrag rgyag} and {sngur pa rgyag} are also used.

englishGloss: for deities to enter a medium who is in a trance.

examples.english: In the countryside, there is a custom of deities descending upon a medium in order to remove family obstacles. (e.g.,This may be to help resolve a family dispute.)
I don't like it when a situation is decided by possession through a shamanistic medium.
In springtime, the wind blows (so strongly) in our district that (we) are not able to go outside.
Last night, it must have blown up a storm. The house is full of dust. (lit.' the house is all dust.' {thal ba} is pronounced {thal la}.)

categories: rang byung gi chos nyid (aspects of nature)

examples.english: A. Who braided your hair? B. I did it myself.
If this thread is not braided into four plaits, it won't become very strong. Since your hair has been plaited into (many) small plaits, you look like a nomad girl.

commentsEnglish: This entry is also spelled {lhad ma rgyag}.

englishGloss: to be relaxed, informal or open. (vol.)

examples.english: It seems to be windy outside. The prayer flags are fluttering.

She is reserved with other people but around her mother she is very relaxed. (This sentence reflects the transitive, volitional use of {lhab lhab byed}. The verbal argument in this case is indirect ergative.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The old car was dismantled by the junk yard buyer and taken away. ({lcags ro} lit. means 'metal waste'.) I dismantled the table.

commentsEnglish: {bshig} by itself is more commonly said than the compound {lhu bshig}, as in {ngas rkang ga ril di bshig pa yin} - 'I dismantled this bike.'

examples.english: This children's toy can be used after it is assembled. I've heard that there is a car assembling plant in Lhasa.
Yesterday, I put together the old bike.

commentsEnglish: {sgrig} by itself is much more commonly said than the compound {lhu sgrig}.

examples.english: A. Are you somersaulting? B. We are somersaulting and seeing who is good or not.
A. Do you know how to somersaut? B. I don't know how to very well.
How splendid that my child can cartwheel like that!
According to what Tibetans say, if (you) yawn, they consider that (you are) hungry.
A. You are really yawning. Are you hungry? B. Of course I'm yawning, I didn't get any lunch.

commentsEnglish: The above phrase in Related Words and Expressions is a proverb which means, 'Since life is only as short as a cat's yawn, don't waste it.'

englishGloss: to turn over, to roll over.

examples.english: Since I couldn't sleep last night, I tossed and turned a lot. Nurses help patients to roll over.
Small children always turn over (their) bowls. Miss, quickly turn over the washing. (i.e., one side of the washing is dry so it needs to be turned over. {khra 'khru} is pronounced {khrang 'khru}.)
I have turned over the soil for my whole life. (This is an idiomatic expression for 'I have worked hard on the land'.)

commentsEnglish: In the second sentence of example two, {bu mo} has been translated as 'Miss' in this context to correspond with American English.

englishGloss: to be turned over or rolled over.

examples.english: I didn't turn over. (i.e., when sleeping.) He was not able to turn over that rock.
Because he got lots of money, (his) life really turned around. ({o log thebs} is an idiomatic expression which means to come into wealth.)

commentsEnglish: Note that the first two example sentences both illustrate the use of an intransitive verb with an ergative subject. In the second sentence, the focus is on the result of the attempted action.

examples.english: Hop over here on one foot. Shall we play hopscotch?
It is customarily said that if you circumambulate around mani rocks hopping on one foot, (some) bad karma will be washed away.
Ah! This water is freezing! (You'd) get an immediate chill if (you) took a swim.
The child has become cold all of a sudden. You had better put some clothes on him straight away.

commentsEnglish: Like a number of verbs, this one is also an onomatopoetic word reflecting the sound utterance made when struck with a sudden chill.

examples.english: Mongolians are adept at wrestling.
I have wrestled with him many times.
Two nights ago, I had a headache and I couldn't cope with it. If you tell a child off too much, (they) won't be able to handle it.
If (you) work for 15 hours in one day, how will (your) body be able to handle that? If you have to provide for four people on one salary, I don't think it would be possible.
Please don't do that. I'm very ticklish.
She is not ticklish at all.

commentsEnglish: While this compound is primarily used in a non-volitional way, it can also be used in the above sentence in Related Words and Expressions to mean, 'Do you want to be tickled?'.

examples.english: A. Do you want me to tickle you? (This is a playful warning.) B. No, I don't. I'm scared.
Don't tickle me.

commentsEnglish: While it is correct to use {slong} as the verbaliser with this compound, the verbaliser {za} is more commonly used as in the above sentence in Related Words and Expressions - 'Do you want me to tickle you?'.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The child became cold and is really hiccuping. When you have the hiccups, (you) should put some thick clothes on. ({gyon} is pronounced {gon}.)
If food isn't eaten slowly, (you) will get stomach pains and the hiccups.

commentsEnglish: Tibetans consider hiccups to be the result of being cold. Tibetans say if you are frightened by something or your mind is preoccupied with something else, your hiccups will go away. {ig ka rgyag} is also spelled {i ka rgyag}.

englishGloss: to be persistent in urging someone to do something.

examples.english: If, from the beginning, you didn't drink chang, no matter how persistent someone is, you shouldn't drink it.
At first, I only intended to stay in Shigatse for one day. But then, after they were so persistent (in urging me to stay), I had to stay for two days.
Whatever work you do, don't do it in a foolish, belligerent manner. (i.e., don't work without a plan or specific purpose.)

categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)

examples.english: The robber was destitute and strangled the old lady to death.
Actually, there is hope that he could be promoted, but I think his superiors might squeeze him. (i.e., they might block his promotion.)

commentsEnglish: This verbalised compound literally means 'to squeeze down on the neck or throat.' It has the same meaning as {ske btsir gtong}, though the latter is rarely said in Lhasa dialect.
categories: mi'i bya spyod kyi 'brel ba (human relationships)
